div2.p: ἄειδε, for the form see § 41. The Attic present is a)/|dw. Like Latin cano, it admits an object (mh=nin) in the accusative. Cf. w)|da/s tinas a)/|dontes (Xen. Anab. IV, 3, 27).
θεά, § 66; elsewhere called ‘Muse,’ but Homer applies no more definite name than this to the goddess of epic song.— Πηληιάδεω, for ending, § 65, § 68; scansion, § 43; composition, § 157.
Ἀχιλῆος, declension, § 86, § 87.
οὐλομένην, ‘the baneful wrath’; for spelling, § 35. Translate as closely as possible in the Greek order, so as to retain the original emphasis; here ‘wrath’ may be repeated.
μυρί’, elided vowel, § 40.1; meaning, § 109.
Ἀχαιοῖς, originally a tribal name, then used for ‘Greeks’ in general.
ἄλγε’, elision, § 40.1; declension, § 78, § 91.
ἔθηκεν, ‘made,’ a common Homeric meaning of ti/qhmi.
ἰφθίμους agrees with yuxa/s, the masculine doing duty as feminine.
Ἄιδι (Attic *(/aidh|, i. e. a(/|dh|), declension, § 96; as used by Homer, almost always indicates the god himself, ‘Hades.’
αὐτούς, ‘the men themselves,’ ta\ sw/mata, in contrast with the yuxa/s.
τεῦχε, not augmented, § 125.
κύνεσσιν (Attic kusi/ for kun + si), declension. § 78, § 82.
οἰωνοῖσι, declension, § 73, § 76.
Διός, declension, § 98.
δ’(έ), ‘while’; it will be observed that de/ must often be rendered not by this word only, but also by ‘for’ and even ‘although.’
ἐτελείετο, spelling, § 150.
βουλή, the ‘purpose’ to defeat the Achaeans and to confer honor on the injured Achilles, in answer to Thetis's prayer; all this will be developed later.
ἐξ οὗ κτλ. (kai\ ta\ loipa/ = et cetera), ‘from the time when once they quarreled and parted’; to be joined in thought with l. 1: ‘sing of the wrath from the time when’ etc.
διαστήτην, not augmented, § 125.
Ἀτρεΐδης, formation, § 157. Agamemnon is meant, as is suggested by the appositive a)/nac a)ndrw=n. In another context the word might indicate his brother Menelaus as well (cf. 3.347, 350, 361).
ἄναξ, on the hiatus, § 25, § 27, 60.
Ἀχιλλεύς, spelled with two l's (compare *)axilh=os, l. 1), § 39.

With an art that has formed a model for succeeding epic poets, Homer takes up the story in the very middle with an exciting incident. What has gone before he allows to come to light gradually. The incidents of the Iliad occupy about seven weeks (forty-nine days) of the tenth year of the siege of Troy (cf. B 134, 295, 296); the first book occupies twenty-one days of this time.
ἄρ, on the different forms of this little word, which, though indicating various shades of feeling, is often untranslatable, see § 49.1.
σφωε, enclitic pronoun, third person, accusative dual, § 110.
θεῶν, partitive genitive with ti/s.
ξυν-έηκε, the syllabic augment points to the fact that i(/hmi originally began with a consonant; on the spelling, § 41.
μάχεσθαι, syntax, § 212.
Λητοῦς, form, § 94.
υἱός, named in l. 14.
ὅ, personal pronoun, § 118.2.
βασιλῆι (Attic basilei=), declension, § 86.
ἀνὰ στρατόν, ‘through the camp.’
ὀλέκοντο, poetic verb: ‘and the soldiers kept dying.’ On neglect of augment, § 125.
λαοί, declension and Attic equivalent, § 77.
οὕνεκα, ‘because’; form, § 45.
τόν, probably demonstrative, § 118.1: ‘that’ Chryses, celebrated in epic song.
ἀρητῆρα, composition, § 156.1.
νῆας, declension, § 101; Attic nau=s (GG. 136).
λυσόμενος expresses purpose.— qu/gatra (Attic qugate/ra), § 85.— ἄποινα, probably in the form of gold, bronze, and raiment.

‘With the fillet of far-darting Apollo in his hands, upon a golden staff.’ In classical times suppliants regularly carried boughs entwined with wool, when urging their petitions, as is shown by various passages in later literature. Here the priest brings the sacred woolen fillet of his god on his own priestly staff. If ste/mmat'(a)—and not ste/mma t'(e)—is the true reading, the plural is probably used with reference to the parts of wool that composed the fillet; cf. notes on 3.29, 55. Below (l. 28) the singular occurs.
ἑκηβόλου, short ultima in scansion, § 25.1.
Ἀπόλλωνος, quantity of initial vowel, § 30.
χρυσέῳ (Attic xrusw=|), lack of contraction. § 41; synizesis, § 43; the resulting syllable scanned short, § 25, 1. As to the meaning of ‘golden’ staff, see note on l. 246.
Ἀτρεΐδα, accusative dual, § 65.
δύω, Attic du/o.
κοσμήτορε, composition, § 156.1.
ἐυκνήμιδες, ‘well-greaved’; see Introduction on Homeric armor. 30.
θεοί, scanned as one syllable, § 43.
δοῖεν, why optative? § 201.
Πριάμοιο, declension, § 73.
πόλιν, the ultima, though short, receives the ictus, § 32.

ἐύ = Attic eu)=. In the text this adverb is printed as two syllables in the fourth foot before the bucolic diaeresis ( § 11, § 19) and in the second half of the fifth foot. In other places in the verse both the contracted and the resolved forms occur.
λῦσαι ... δέχεσθαι, infinitives for imperatives, § 213.
τά, probably demonstrative, § 118.1.
ἁζόμενοι agrees with u(mei=s understood.
ἐπ-ευ-φήμησαν, ‘cried out in approval’; the temporal augment is neglected, unnecessarily, for the reading might as well be e)p-hu-fh/mhsan.
αἰδεῖσθαι, complementary to e)peufh/mhsan, which amounts to a verb of commanding: ‘to reverence the priest.’
θ’ = te.
ἱερῆα, like basilh=a (Attic basile/a_), § 86.
δέχθαι, spelling, § 131.
οὐκ ... ἥνδανε, ‘it [i. e. to respect the priest and to accept the ransom] pleased not Agamemnon in his heart.’
ἥνδανε, on the hiatus, § § 27; 61, 1.
θυμῷ, syntax, § 177 (a).
ἐπὶ ... ἔτελλεν, tmesis, § 163, § 165.
μῦθον, ‘threat.’
μή σε ... κιχείω, ‘let me not find you’ § 193).
κοίλῃσιν, declension, § 65, § 71; Attic koi/lais.
νηυσί, declined, § 101.
κιχείω, where found? § 149.
τοι, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
τήν, personal pronoun, § 118.2.
πρίν κτλ., ‘ere then shall old age overtake her.’
μιν, enclitic pronoun, here = Attic au)th/n, § 110. It may be used for masculine and neuter also.
For the hiatus between ἡμετέρῳ and ἐνί (Attic e)n) see § 25.4.
οἴκῳ originally began with a consonant, § 61.28.
ἐν Ἄργεϊ (declined like e)/pos, § § 91 and 41), the district in the Peloponnesus ruled by Agamemnon; the seat of his power was Mycenae. Cf. note on l. 79.
πάτρης (Attic patri/dos), syntax, § 175.

‘Moving to and fro before the loom and sharing my bed.’ The construction of λέχος is remarkable; it may be considered a “limit of motion” accusative § 179); but elsewhere a)ntia/w takes a partitive genitive.
σαώτερος, in emphatic position, to be translated after w(s.
κε, enclitic particle, § 49.3.
νέηαι, form, § 142.1; syntax, § 196.
ὣς ἔφατ’(ο) = Attic ou(/tws e)/fh.
ἔδδεισεν, for double d, § 62.1; n movable in spite of the following d'(e/), § 50.
ὁ γέρων, § 119 (a).
βῆ, accent, § 126.
παρὰ θῖνα, ‘along the strand.’
πολυφλοίσβοιο, imitative of the sound of the wind-swept sea.
πολλά, object of h)ra=q' (= h)ra=to, from a)ra/omai): ‘earnestly prayed.’
ὁ γεραιός, use of article, § 119 (a).
τόν, relative pronoun, § 118.4; cf. ‘that’ in English.
μευ, enclitic pronoun, § 110; contraction, § 42.
ἀμφιβέβηκας, to be translated by present tense, ‘guardest,’ § 187. The metaphor involved is illustrated by the line:
a)mfi\ d' a)/r' au)tw=| bai=n) w(/s tis peri\ po/rtaki mh/thr (P 4), ‘Menelaus strode before him [the slain Patroclus] like a cow before her calf,’ to give protection. Compare also E 299.
ζαθέην, composition, § 160.
τε ἶφι, hiatus, § 61.21.

εί ποτε κτλ., ‘if ever I roofed overhead a temple pleasing in thy sight.’ The temple plays no further part in the story of Chryses; but the altar does appear later. In the earlier times the gods were worshiped at altars in the open air; but some distinct references to temples will be noticed later in the poem (E 446-448; Z 274, 279, 297).
ἔπι, adverb, § 162, § 164.
νηόν, declension, § 77.
κατὰ ... ἔκηα (Attic kate/kausa), § 163, § 165.
ἠδ’(έ), common Homeric equivalent of kai/.
κρήηνον (Attic kra=non), from kraiai/nw (Attic krai/nw).
ἐέλδωρ, spelling, § 61.13.
‘May the Danaans pay for my tears by thy shafts.’ τίσειαν, syntax, § 201.
Δαναοί, another name for the ‘Greeks’ in general, regarded as the ‘people of Danaus,’ the mythical Argive king.
σοῖσι, meaning, § 113; declension, § 76.
βέλεσσιν, declined like e)/pos, § 91, § 83.
τοῦ, personal pronoun, § 118.2.
κατ’ Οὐλύμποιο καρήνων, ‘down from the summits of Olympus.’— Οὐλύμποιο = Attic *)olu/mpou.
καρήνων, declined, § 100.
κῆρ, accusative, ‘at heart.’
τόξα, a single bow; plural because made of parts fitted together.
ὤμοισιν, declension, § 76; syntax, § 177.
φαρέτρην, spelling, § 64.
χωομένοιο, of him ‘in his anger.’
αὐτοῦ κινηθέντος, ‘as the god started up.’
ἤιε, Attic h)/|ei, from ei)=mi.
ἐοικώς, for the original spelling cf. § 61.24.
νεῶν, declension, § 101.
μέτα, adverb, § 162, § 164.
ἕηκεν, see note on l. 8.
‘And a dreadful clang arose from the silver bow.’ With the imitative words e)/klagcan (l. 46) and klaggh/ compare li/gce bio/s (4.125), which expresses a similar idea.
ἀργυρέοιο, uncontracted, § 41.
οὐρῆας, declined like basileu/s, § 86.
ἐπ-ῴχετο, ‘he assailed.’

‘But next he sped his keen shaft at the men themselves [au)toi=si] and kept shooting.’—Either βέλος (note the long ultima) ἐχεπευκές illustrates ictus lengthening § 33) or the force of the original sigma of [s]exepeuke/s is still felt.
βάλλ’, elision, § 40.1.
αἰεί = Attic a)ei/.
νεκύων, genitive of material with purai/ (cf. GG. 506).
θαμεῖαι, to be translated in the predicate, after the Greek order: ‘thickly,’ one after another.
κῆλα = be/lea (cf. l. 51).
τῇ δεκάτῃ, ‘on the tenth day,’ like the Attic construction.
ἀγορήνδε, spelling, § 64; suffix, § 155.5.
καλέσσατο, double sigma, § 53.
τῷ, personal pronoun, § 118.2; syntax, § 176.
φρεσί, φρένες, diaphragm of the body; used by the Greeks for the seat of thought and emotion; cf. English ‘heart.’—Here (Attic ‘Hera’) and Athene (Attic ‘Athena’) were hostile to the Trojans. Why?
ὁρᾶτο, § 125. Homer uses the middle of this verb in active sense.
ἤγερθεν, form, § 136.8.
τοῖσι, dative of interest § 176), ‘rising up before them.’

δέ here has the force of a weakened dh/, ‘then,’ § 31. It can not be translated in this place by ‘but’ or ‘and’; yet by some it is believed to have once had that force, even here, surviving as a relic of the time when, in primitive language, all clauses were coördinated—when there was no “hypotaxis,” but only “parataxis.”
ἄμμε, pronoun of first person, § 110.

πλαγχθέντας, from pla/zw, —‘Now I think that we, driven back, shall return home again, if possibly we should escape death—if, in fact, both war and pestilence are at the same time to destroy the Achaeans.’
εἴ κεν ... φύγοιμεν § 208) expresses a possibility more remote than ei) ... dama=| (l. 61).
εἰ δή, ‘if in fact’ is nearly equivalent to ‘since in fact.’
δαμᾷ (future indicative, § 151) agrees with one subject only, like xrai/smh|, l. 28.
ἐρείομεν, form, § 148; hortatory.
τε, observe that this word helps out the meter and also accompanies a general statement; it is often not to be translated.
‘Who may say [potential—or “hypothetical”—optative, § 206] why Phoebus Apollo has become so much angered.’
τόσσον, spelling, § 51.1.
ὅ γ’(ε), ‘he,’ with very slight emphasis.
εὐχωλῆς, ἑκατόμβης, genitives of cause; the vow may have been unfulfilled, the hecatomb neglected.
‘In the hope that when he has shared in the savor of unblemished lambs and goats, he may be willing to avert destruction from us’; cf. § 198.
αἰ = Attic ei).
κνίσης, partitive genitive with a)ntia/sas.
βούλεται, subjunctive? § 147.
ἡμῖν, dative of advantage (interest), ‘from us’; literally ‘for us.’
ἀπὸ ... ἀμῦναι, tmesis, § 163.
ἦ τοι, often ‘to be sure,’ here little more than ‘well.’
κατ’ ... ἕζετο = Attic e)kaqe/zeto.
τοῖσι, cf. l. 58.
Θεστορίδης, composition, § 157.
What makes ὅς a long syllable? § 37.— τὰ ἐόντα = Attic ta\ o)/nta, ‘the present’: τὰ ἐσσόμενα = ta\ e)so/mena, ‘the future’; τὰ πρὸ ἐόντα, ‘the past.’
τε ... τε ... τε, ‘both ... and ... and.’
νήεσσι, form, § 101.
εἴσω, adverb, to be translated before Ἴλιον, which is an accusative of limit of motion.
‘By means of his seer's art, which Phoebus Apollo had given to him.’
ἥν, possessive adjective, § 113; not an Attic prose word.
τήν, relative, § 118.4.
οἱ, enclitic pronoun, § 110. Homer uses this word commonly as a personal pronoun, while in Attic Greek it is normally an indirect reflexive only.
σφιν, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
κέλεαι, form, § 142.1. Calchas felt himself bidden to speak on account of his preëminence among the seers; cf. l. 62.
μυθήσασθαι, ‘to interpret,’ ‘to explain.’
Note that the ultima of Ἀπόλλωνος is long before ἑκατηβελέταο § 37). For declension of the latter word see § 65.
ἐρέω, form, § 41.
σύνθεο, form, § 142.2, a.
ὄμοσσον, spelling, § 53.
ἦ μέν § 31) = Attic h)= mh/n, used in asseverations: ‘yea verily’ or ‘in very truth.’
πρόφρων, ‘with all your heart,’ agreeing with subject of o)/mosson (GG. 571), but belonging in sense with the understood subject (‘you’) of a)rh/cein.
ἔπεσιν ( § 91, § 50) καὶ χερσίν, ‘in word and in deed.’
ἦ γὰρ κτλ., ‘for truly I think I shall enrage a man.’
χολωσέμεν, infinitive, § 137.2.
Ἀργεΐων, ‘Argives,’ a third name for the Greeks, the other two being Δαναοί (l. 42) and *)axaioi/.

Ἀργέιοι meant originally the people dwelling in *)/argos, which at first seems to have indicated the plain of central Thessaly, neighboring to *(ella/s. But the name *)/argos (or *)/argos *)axaiiko/n, as it is four times called) was early extended to the whole Peloponnesus. The Thessalian district is once called ‘Pelasgic Argos,’ in distinction (B 681).—The Ἀχαιοί once dwelt in southern Thessaly—in *(ella/s and *fqi/h, apparently adjacent but distinct districts. The important fact is that the poets use these names (*)arge/ioi and *)axaioi/) freely to indicate all the Greeks; while the name so used later—*(/ellhnes—stands in Homer for a single tribe only, that dwelt in *(ella/s (of southern Thessaly). Even of the Homeric Hellas the boundaries are indefinite, and traces of an application of the name more extended than its original use appear in late parts of the Homeric poems (I 447, 478, Od. 1.344, Od. 4.726, 816, Od. 15.80).
οἱ is dative singular, as is shown by the fact that it is enclitic: ‘him [in English, ‘whom’] the Achaeans obey.’
κρείσσων, spelling, § 56.
βασιλεύς, supply e)sti/, as very often. —On omission of a)/n or ke with the present general protasis, see § 197.
χώσεται, subjunctive, § 144, II.
‘For even if he swallows his anger for that day, indeed, yet [a)lla/] he keeps a grudge afterward in his heart, until he satisfies it.’
εἰ ...καταπέψῃ, in same construction as xw/setai (l. 80).
τε ... τε, not translatable, accompanying the general statement, as often in Homer.
ὄφρα τελέσσῃ (spelling, § 52), present general protasis § 197).— ὄφρα is poetic only; the Attic equivalent here is e(/ws, me/xri, or a similar word.
στήθεσσιν, declension, § 91, § 52.
φράσαι εἰ, ‘consider whether.’

θαρσήσας, ‘pluck up courage’; as the present of this verb indicates a state or condition, ‘to be courageous,’ the aorist may denote the entrance into that condition (GG. 464); this principle is frequently illustrated in the text of Homer.
μάλα, ‘surely,’ ‘without fail,’ strengthens εἰπέ. Account for the hiatus; § 61.16.
θεοπρόπιον, note that the last syllable, though short, receives the ictus; § 33.
οὐ, translate the negative later with tis (l. 88), before which in fact it is repeated.
ᾧ τε, the te is not translatable, § 123.3: ‘by prayer to whom, Calchas, you reveal oracles to the Danaans.’
ἐμεῦ § 110) ζῶντος ... δερκομένοιο, genitive absolute.
σοί, after e)pi/ in composition.
ἐποίσει, future of e)pi-fe/rw.
κοίλῃς, cf. l. 26.
Δαναῶν, partitive genitive with ou)/ tis (l. 88).
Ἀγαμέμνονα εἴπῃς, account for the hiatus; § 61.16.
πολλόν, ‘by far,’ declension, § 105.
θάρσησε, cf. note on l. 85.
ηὔδαε, αὐδάω.
οὐδ’(έ), ‘for ... not’; cf. notes on ll. 5 and 124.
τοὔνεκα, form, § 45.

πριν ... πρίν (l. 98) = Attic pro/teron (or pro/sqen) ... pri/n: in translation omit the former pri/n. What construction follows pri/n in Attic Greek after a negative clause? See note on B 414 and cf. GG. 644 b and d.
Δαναοῖσι, for dative cf. l. 67, h(mi=n.
ἀπώσει, future of a)p-wqe/w.
ἀπὸ ... δόμεναι, tmesis, § 163.
δόμεναι, form, § 137.1, b. The subject ‘they’ (supply tina/) is purposely indefinite.
κούρην = Attic ko/rhn. Cf. the accusative plural ko/ras (Xen. Anab. IV, 5, 9).
Explain θ’, comparing l. 23.
Χρύσην, here the name of the place, not of the person.
ἱλασσάμενοι, spelling, § 53.
πεπίθοιμεν, form, § 128. ‘Then may we propitiate and persuade him.’
μιν = au)to/n.
μένεος, form, § 91. ‘With rage his gloomy heart was brimming’ (‘was greatly filled’).—On φρένες cf. note, l. 55.
ὄσσε δέ οἱ § 61.6), ‘and his eyes’; syntax of oi(, § 176.
ἐίκτην, pluperfect dual from e)/oika § 61.24), ‘were like.’

κάκ’ ὀσσόμενος, ‘with evil look,’ a phrase contrasting with e)u\ frone/wn, l. 73. The penult of the adjective kaka/ (cf. 3.86, doli/x') receives an acute accent, as is regular when there is elision of the originally accented syllable. The rule applies likewise to pronouns (e)/m', l. 133), verbs (ei)/s', l. 566), etc.; but prepositions and conjunctions lose their accent if the accented syllable is elided (GG. 34 a, b).
προς-έειπεν § 61.16) = Attic prosei=pen.
‘Evils are always dear to your heart to prophesy.’
μαντεύεσθαι § 211) limits fi/la, ‘dear for prophesying’; the original dative force of the infinitive is here quite apparent (GG. 562).
ἐσθλόν = Attic a)gaqo/n, here in sense of ‘pleasant,’ ‘gratifying.’— What is the metrical quantity of the ultima of εἶπας in its position before e)/pos? § 61.16.
ὡς δὴ τοῦδ’ ἕνεκα, ‘that doubtless for this reason,’ defined in the following line.
σφιν, see l. 73.
οὕνεκα, ‘because,’ as in l. 11.
Χρυσηίδος, composition, § 158.— The ‘ransom of the maid Chryseis’ means the ransom offered for her.
βούλομαι, ‘prefer.’
Κλυταιμνήστρης, genitive after the comparative idea in probe/boula. The correct ancient spelling of this name is *klutaimh/strh (Attic -a_).
ἐπεὶ οὔ ἑθεν κτλ., ‘since she is not inferior to her,’ literally ‘since she [Chryseis] is not worse than she [Clytaemnestra].’
οὔ ἑθεν, why not ou)x? § 61, § 6; 110.
χερείων = Attic xei/rwn.

δέμας κτλ., accusatives of specification. This line seems to summarize the excellent qualities of the Homeric woman: de/mas, ‘figure,’ fuh/n, ‘growth,’ ‘stature,’ fre/nas, ‘sense,’ e)/rga, ‘handiwork.’ The Homeric man should have fuh/, fre/nes, and a)gorhtu/s, ‘power of discourse’ (Od. 8.168).
τι, ‘at all.’
καὶ ὥς, ‘even so,’ i. e. although all this is true.—With do/menai supply ‘her’ as object.—After τό γε supply e)sti/, the very common Homeric ellipsis.
βούλομ’, elision, § 40.3.
ἔμμεναι, form, § 137.6.
ἤ, ‘rather than.’
οἶος, ‘alone,’ not to be confused with oi(=os, ‘such as.’
ἔω (Attic w)=), subjunctive of ei)mi/, in a purpose clause introduced by ὄφρα, which is here a final conjunction (Attic i(/na); compare l. 82, an example of the temporal use.
οὐδὲ ἔοικεν, account for the hiatus; § 61.24. ‘It is not seemly at all’ for me to lack a prize.
τό γε, ‘this,’ demonstrative § 118.1), referring to the following clause.
ὅ μοι § 176) γέρας κτλ., ‘that my prize goes elsewhere.’
ἠμείβετο, cf. a)p-ameibo/menos (l. 84).
γάρ, [your demand is unfair and impossible,] ‘for’ etc. It is perhaps as well, however, not to attempt to render ga/r, if the translation is likely to be cumbersome. ‘Why!’ often gives it (GG. 672).
‘For we do not longer [e)/ti] know of common goods treasured up anywhere in abundance.’ In translation, ou)de/ may be rendered as two words (‘and ... not,’ ‘for ... not’) if it seems better.
ἴδμεν, form, § 57.
ξυνήια = Attic koina/, here a substantive.
κείμενα, the familiar passive, in meaning, of ti/qhmi = ‘deposit.’
πολλά is a predicate adjective.
τὰ ... τά, § 118.4 and 1: ‘what we plundered from the cities —that is distributed.
πολίων (Attic po/lewn) declined, § 103.
ἔξ, why accented? § 166.
‘And it is not right for the soldiers to gather these things again and make a common store of them’; literally ‘to bring together these things collected again.’
τήνδε, Chryseis.
θεῷ, ‘in honor of the god.’
πρό-ες (pro-i/hmi), ‘let go forth,’ ‘yield.’
Ἀχαιοί, ‘we Achaeans’; note the person of the verb of which *)axaioi/ is subject.
αἴ κε, Attic e)a/n.
δῷσι, form, § 136.6; this is easily recognized as the protasis of the more vivid future—or “simple future”—condition (cf. GG. 650).— ἐξαλαπάξαι, ‘to sack,’ purpose.
δὴ οὕτως, pronounced as if written d' ou(/tws, § 43.

ἀγαθός περ ἐών, ‘even though you are brave.’ per has the force of kai/ often in dependent clauses (cf. l. 81) and in constructions with the participle, such as this line illustrates; the participle is concessive. Sometimes both kai/ and per occur with the same participle (as ll. 217, 577). kai/per (one word) with concessive participle is familiar in Attic Greek (GG. 593 b).
μὴ ... κλέπτε νόῳ, ‘do not seek to deceive me in your heart’ (locative).

παρελεύσομαι (from par-e/rxomai), ‘outstrip,’ ‘overreach,’ metaphor from racing.—Achilles has frankly demanded that Agamemnon give up Chryseis; and he offers, in return, an unsubstantial chance of payment when the city of Troy is taken—a somewhat remote possibility. So, Agamemnon thinks, Achilles is holding out to him an illusory hope, and is keeping some ulterior motive hidden.

ἤ, Latin an, ‘or perhaps,’ ‘is it that,’ introduces the second part of a double question, the first being implied and more or less indefinite. Most editors prefer h)= (‘truly’) here. Pope gives the idea of the line thus:
Shall I my prize resign
With tame content, and thou possess'd of thine?
A more literal rendering is: ‘is it that you wish—so that you yourself may keep your prize—me on the contrary [au)ta/r] to sit in “tame content” [au)/tws] bereft [deuo/menon] of mine?’
ἔχῃς, introduced by o)/fra (= Attic i(/na), expresses purpose.
ἔμ’, accented; cf. note on ka/k', l. 105.
δευόμενον, said to be Aeolic; the Attic lacks the u, which is the vocalized v.
κέλεαι, cf. l. 74.

ἀλλά, as usual, indicates that something is to be said quite different from the preceding context; it is derived from a)/lla, i. e. ‘otherwise.’ Do not translate by ‘but,’ unless this word is clearly demanded by the sequence of ideas; here ‘yet’ will do. Compare note on ll. 81, 82.
ἄρσαντες, ἀραρίσκω.
ὅπως ἀντάξιον ἔσται, § 200 (a). As the conclusion of this condition understand eu)= e(cei, ‘it will be well.’
εἰ ... κε, Attic equivalent? Cf. l. 128.
δώωσιν, form, § 149 (5).
ἐγὼ δέ § 31; cf. l. 58), ‘then I.’
κεν ... ἕλωμαι, syntax, § 192.
τεόν, § 113.
Αἴαντος, the son of Telamon is always meant, unless the poet expressly indicates the other Ajax, the son of Oïleus.
ἰών, ‘going’ to your hut, or Ajax's, etc.
Ὀδυσῆος, declined like *)axilh=os, l. 1.
κεν κεχολώσεται, an instance of ken with the future perfect indicative, a construction foreign to Attic Greek; see § 190.
ὅν, syntax, § 179.
κεν ... ἵκωμαι, protasis of the more vivid future condition (cf. GG. 650, 616 a). With what prefix is i(/kwmai used in the equivalent Attic?
ἦ τοι, ‘to be sure.’
καί, ‘even’ or ‘also.’
νῆα (Attic nau=n), declension, § 101.
ἐρύσσομεν, ‘let us launch,’ form, § 144, II; double s, § 53.
ἒν δ’(έ), ‘and there,’ in the ship; for accent see § 164.
ἀγείρομεν, where found? § 144, II.
ἔς, ‘within,’ ‘therein,’ § 164.
θείομεν, another hortatory subjunctive; on spelling, § 144, l.— ἄν (Attic a)na/), ‘on board,’ form, § 46.

βήσομεν, § 144, II; this causative first aorist is not supplied in Attic Greek by bai/nw, but by biba/zw. So the Attic equivalent is biba/swmen. —The subject of ἔστω is εἷς τις, to which ἀνὴρ βουληφόρος is in apposition; ἀρχός is a predicate nominative. ‘Let somebody—a man of good counsel—be captain.’
Ὀδυσσεύς, here with two s's, with only one in l. 138; § 39.
‘That you may offer sacrifices and propitiate’ etc.
ἱλάσσεαι, mood and tense, § 144, II; double s, § 53.
τόν, object of prose/fh.
ὑπόδρα ἰδών, why is the hiatus possible? § 61.23.
On translating the tense of ἰδών see § 186.
Agamemnon's threat to rob Achilles of his prize, Briseis, is quite sufficient to call forth the passionate speech that follows.
ὤ μοι (dative of interest), exclamatory, ‘ah me!’
ἐπι-ειμένε, ‘clothed in,’ vocative of perfect participle of e)pi-e/nnumi. Why is i of e)pi- not elided? § 61.20.
πείθηται, syntax, § 194.
ὁδὸν ἐλθέμεναι, ‘so as to go on an expedition.’

ὁδόν, accusative of the space or way over which an action extends; the construction is somewhat akin to that of the cognate accusative. Cf. l. 496, Z 292.— ἐλθέμεναι, form, § 137.1, a; syntax like ma/xesqai, l. 8. The expression may refer to going to ambush, one of the bravest feats of Homeric warfare (l. 227); others understand it of the journey just proposed.
ἤλυθον = Attic h)=lqon.
αἰχμητάων, declension, § 65.
μαχεσσόμενος, scansion, § 32; spelling, § 53; = Attic maxou/menos. What is the force of the future here? Cf. luso/menos, l. 13.
μοι, ‘in my sight.’
ἤλασαν, ‘drove away.’
μέν, same as mh/n.
ἐριβώλακι, prefix, § 160.
ἦ, ‘truly.’
With πολλά supply e)sti/.
οἴρεα (from ou)=ros) = Attic o)/rh (o)/ros).
σκιόεντα, ἠχήεσσα, composition, § 159.—Why does not τε (before h)xh/essa) suffer elision? § 61.5.
τιμὴν ἀρνύμενοι, ‘to win recompense’; the present participle here expresses purpose and attendant circumstance (GMT. 840).
πρὸς Τρώων, ‘from the Trojans.’—τῶν οἴ τι κτλ., ‘all this you neither heed nor regard at all.’
μετατρέπῃ, how else might the form have been written? § 142.1, a.
ἀφαιρήσεσθαι, future in indirect discourse: ‘you threaten you will take away.’
ἔπι, why accented on the penult? § 166.
πόλλ’, for the accent cf. note on ka/k', l. 105.
υἷες, declension, § 107.
μέν, again the same as mh/n, § 31.
σοὶ ἶσον, ‘equal to you,’ i. e. ‘equal to yours,’ a conciseness of expression that will be noticed more than once again (e. g. 3.238).—Why is ε of ποτε not elided? § 61.27.
ἶσον has short initial vowel in Attic.
ὁππότ’ (spelling, § 51.1) ... e)kpe/rswsi, supply the omitted particle, to make the clause normal Attic Greek. Cf. § 197.
τὸ πλεῖον, ‘the greater part.’ Later (I 328, 329) Achilles claims to have sacked twelve cities by sea, and eleven by land in the Troad.
χεῖρες ἐμαί, ‘my hands,’ in Attic would be ai( e)mai\ xei=res.
ἀτάρ, same as au)ta/r, l. 51, etc., § 31.
ἤν in present general condition, as in Attic (GG. 650); so differing from the construction of ll. 163, 164, in form, rather than in force.
After γέρας supply e)sti/.
ὀλίγον τε φίλον τε, a prize ‘little but none the less dear.’
νῆας, declension, § 101.
ἐπεί κε (= Attic e)ph/n or e)pa/n) κάμω is equivalent to what sort of protasis? Cf. h)/n pote ... i(/khtai, l. 166.
Φθίηνδ’(ε), composition, § 155.5.
ἴμεν, where found? § 137.7.
ς’, for soi/, § 40.4.
‘Nor do I intend, without honor here as I am, to amass wealth and riches for you.’ a)fu/ssein, literally, is ‘to draw’ full draughts of a liquid; its use here is metaphorical, of course.
φεῦγε μάλ’(α), the imperative strengthened as in l. 85, ma/la ei)pe/.
ἐπ-έσσυται (from e)pi-sseu/w), for translation see § 187; for double s, § 39.
εἵνεκ’ ἐμεῖο § 110) = Attic e)mou= e(/neka.—Why πάρ’ and not par', i. e. pa/ra and not para/? § 167.
κε ... τιμήσουσι, form, § 146; syntax, § 190.
μητίετα, form, § 67.
ἐσσι, form, § 136.2.
διοτρεφέων βασιλήων § 86). The poet regularly represents kings as cherished by Zeus, king of the gods, just as minstrels and harpists are in favor with the Muses and Phoebus Apollo.
καρτερός, spelling, § 58.
εἰ ... ἐσσι, simple present supposition, as in Attic Greek (GG. 647).
που, ‘doubtless.’
σῇς § 113), Attic σαῖς.
σέθεν, where found? § 110.
κοτέοντος (agreeing with se/qen), ‘in your wrath.’

ὡς means ‘as’; after this line a correlative clause, ‘so shall I take away Briseis,’ would be expected; but after an interruption (th\n me\n ... pe/myw), which disturbs the construction, the main thought is loosely resumed with e)gw\ de/ ke ktl. (l. 184).
ἔμ’ (for accent cf. l. 133), one of the two accusative objects of the verb of depriving; but compare the construction of l. 161.
νηὶ ἐμῇ, ‘a ship of mine,’ the regular Attic expression also. Agamemnon had 100 ships, according to B 576.
κ’ ἄγω, syntax, § 192.
Βρισηίδα, formation, § 158.
κλισίηνδε, suffix, § 155.5.
τὸ σὸν γέρας, ‘that prize of yours.’
ὅσσον, spelling, § 51.3.
σέθεν, why genitive? § 175.
καί, ‘even’ or ‘also.’
ἶσον, neuter cognate accusative with fa/sqai (fhmi/): ‘to speak on a footing with me.’ Yet considerable freedom of speech—for princes, at least—was recognized in the Homeric assembly (cf. I 32, 33).
ὁμοιωθήμεναι § 137.1, b) ἄντην, ‘to make himself like me [‘to make himself my peer’], face to face’; the passive infinitive is apparently used reflexively here.
Πηλεΐωνι, formation, § 157.—ἐν δέ οἱ κτλ., ‘and his heart in his shaggy breast.’
δέ οἱ, on the hiatus, § 61.6; syntax, § 176.
ἐρυσσάμενος, original spelling, § 61.19.

παρὰ μηροῦ, ‘from the thigh,’ where the sword hung suspended in its sheath by a strap that passed probably over the right shoulder. The sword hung at the left side, so that the right hand could more easily draw it from its sheath.

The four optatives in this and the following line stand in indirect questions, in the secondary sequence (after mermh/ricen), for deliberative subjunctives of the original thought § 209). Achilles said to himself: tou\s me\n a)nasth/sw (‘shall I force these men to rise,’ with reference to a violent dismissal of the assembly); *)atrei+/dhn d' e)nari/zw; h)e\ xo/lon pau/sw e)rhtu/sw te qumo/n;
ὃ δ’(έ), here and in some other places in Homer, does not imply a change of subject. What is the Attic use? See GG. 549 b.
ἧος = Attic e(/ws.

ἧλθε δέ, another instance of de/ meaning ‘then’; see notes on ll. 58 and 137. At just the right moment, when the situation is getting more and more perplexing, the goddess appears on the scene, and the difficulty is solved. This device—the interference of a god—is common in the Attic drama (deus ex machina).
οὐρανόθεν, suffix, § 155.2.
πρό, ‘forth’ or ‘forward.’—ἧκε, ἵημι.
στῆ, accent, § 126.
ὄπιθεν = o)/pisqen, in Attic prose.
κόμης, syntax, § 172.
οἴῳ φαινομένη, ‘appearing to him alone.’
ὁρᾶτο, what is the Attic equivalent? Cf. note on l. 56.
θάμβησεν, ‘was struck with wonder’; see note on qarsh/sas, l. 85.
δεινὼ κτλ., ‘for her eyes shone terribly.’
δεινώ, adjective with adverbial force.
φάανθεν, form, § 136.8. The expression reflects Athene's epithet, glaukw=pis (l. 206).
μιν, with pros-hu/da (cf. hu)/dae, l. 92).
φωνήσας, ‘began’ and ‘addressed’ (proshu/da). On scansion of this line see § 4.
τίπτ’(ε), form, § 48.—What is the ‘aegis’ of Zeus? See Introduction, 29.—εἰλήλουθας, ἔρχομαι.
‘Is it that you may see?’ etc.
ἴδῃ, form, § 142.1, a.
Ἀτρεΐδαο, declension, § 65.
ἔκ, I will speak ‘out.’
ἐρέω, cf. l. 76.
τελέεσθαι, tense, § 151.
ἂν ... ὀλέσσῃ § 53), syntax, § 192.
αὖτε, ‘again,’ ‘in turn.’
παύσουσα, what does the tense express? Cf. l. 13.
τὸ σὸν μένος, ‘this anger of yours’; cf. l. 185.
πίθηαι, form, § 142.1; syntax, § 198.
μηδὲ ... ἕλκεο § 142.1), ‘draw no further.’
ἦ τοι, ‘to be sure,’ ‘yet.’
ὀνείδισον, literally ‘upbraid,’ here may be rendered: ‘threaten with reproachful words’ (e)/pesin).
ὡς ἔσεταί περ, ‘how it shall even come to pass.’ On the force of per, cf. note on l. 131.
ἔσεται = Attic e)/stai (l. 212); a third form, par-e/ssetai, is seen in l, 213; a fourth, e)ssei=tai, will be met, B 393.
‘Some day even thrice as many splendid gifts shall come to you, on account of this insolence’ of Agamemnon.
ὕβριος, genitive, declined like po/lis, § 103.
ἴσχεο, πείθεο, formed like e(/lkeo, l. 210.
εἰρύσσασθαι, ‘to observe,’ ‘obey’; the subject is me understood; the object, e)/pos.
καὶ ... περ, see note on l. 131.
θυμῷ, syntax, § 177 (a).
κεχολωμένον agrees with me understood.
ὅς κε ... ἐπιπείθηται is the protasis of what kind of condition? Cf. GG. 616 a.
ἔκλυον, the gnomic aorist § 184) is regarded as a primary tense.

ἦ, ‘he spoke’ = Attic e)/fh; common in the Attic formula, h)= d' o(/s, Latin inquit, ‘said he’; not to be confused with the adverb h)=, ‘truly. This whole sentence, it will be observed, may be well translated nearly, if not quite, in the Greek order.
σχέθε, form, § 154.2.
ὦσε, ὠθέω.
βεβήκει, meaning of tense, § 188.
ἔς, why accented? § 166.
ἐπέεσσιν, form, § 91.
κυνὸς ὄμματ’ ἔχων, cf. kunw=pa, l. 159; the poet makes the dog typical of shamelessness; the deer, of cowardice.
κραδίην, § 58.
πόλεμον, with ictus on the ultima, § 32.
θωρηχθῆναι § 137.3) limits te/tlhkas, l. 228.
λόχονδ’(ε), cf. N 277, e)s lo/xon, e)/nqa ma/list' a)reth\ diaei/detai a)ndrw=n, ‘to an ambush, where most of all the valor of men is clearly seen.’— ἀριστήεσσι, declension, § 88.
τέτληκας, on force of tense, § 187.—τὸ δέ τοι κτλ., ‘for this seems to you to be death.’
κήρ, note accent, and cf. l. 44, kh=r.
λώιον (in Attic poetry lw=|on), how compared? GG. 182, 1.
δῶρ’ ἀποαιρεῖσθαι, supply an object, as antecedent of o(/stis, ‘to deprive of gifts [him] whosoever opposes you in speech.’ On the conditional relative sentence, see § 197.
Supply the place of the omitted protasis by ‘else,’ i. e. ‘were it not so.’
λωβήσαιο, construction, § 207.
ἔπι, adverb, ‘besides.’ For ictus on ultima, see § 38.

Achilles held a staff, put into his hand by a herald, as a sign that he had the right to address the assembly; on ending his speech he threw it down (l. 245). On the other hand, Agamemnon held no temporary scepter, but a permanent one (B 101 ff.), for he was a ‘scepter-bearing king.’— ναὶ μὰ κτλ., ‘verily by this staff.’
τό, relative; cf. to/n, l. 36, th/n, l. 72.
ἐπεὶ δὴ πρῶτα (cf. l. 6) ktl., ‘since once for all it is parted from its stump.’
ὄρεσσι, double s, § 52.

λέλοιπεν, translation, § 187. Vergil renders the thought (Aen. XII, 208, 209):
cum semel in silvis imo de stirpe recisum matre caret.
‘Since once for all cut from its stump in the forest, it [the scepter] is severed from its parent tree.’
ἑ, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
μιν, here for skh=ptron, neuter; cf. l. 29 (min = au)th/n) and l. 100 (min = au)to/n).
παλάμαις, declension, § 72.
δικασπόλοι, appositive to ui(=es (l. 237).

οἵ τε, use of the enclitic, § 123.3. In these days there seems to have been no written law; the ‘decrees’ or ‘dooms’ (qe/mistes) of Zeus were probably the spoken words of the ‘Zeus-cherished kings,’ which had come to have a certain stability.
πρὸς Διός, ‘on behalf of Zeus,’ or ‘at the bidding of Zeus.’— εἰρύαται, form, § 142.4, a; force of tense, § 187.
The important words, to be taken closely with nai\ ma\ to/de skh=ptron (l. 234), begin here.
ἦ ποτε, ‘surely one day.’
Ἀχιλλῆος, objective genitive with poqh/.
υἶας, declension, § 107; syntax, § 179.
δυνήσεαι, form, § 142.1; Attic dunh/sei.
εὖτ’ ἄν = Attic o(/tan.
θνῄσκοντες, ‘being slain.’
πίπτωσι, in protasis of what sort of condition? Cf. GG. 628, 650.
ἔνδοθι, suffix, § 155.3.
χωόμενος, with ultima used for long syllable, § 32.
ὅ τ’, elision and meaning, § 40, § 2; 123, 7.
οὐδέν, ‘not at all,’ in origin a cognate accusative.
ποτί = Attic pro/s.
γαίῃ = Attic gh=|.

χρυσείοις (= Attic xrusoi=s), cf. shorter form, xruse/w|, l. 15.— πεπαρμένον, from pei/rw. The wooden staff seems to have been enclosed in a sheath, which was fastened on with nails; both sheath and nails may have been of gold. See Tsountas and Manatt, The Mycenaean Age, pp. 167-169, and Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, p. 250.
ἑτέρωθεν, suffix, § 155.2.
τοῖσι, ‘before them,’ cf. note on l. 58.
τοῦ § 118.4) ... a)po\ glw/sshs, ‘from whose tongue.’
καί = ‘moreover,’ if translated at all. Cicero quotes the line (Cato Maior, 10, 31): ex eius lingua melle dulcior fluebat oratio.
μέλιτος, why genitive? § 175.
ῥέεν = Attic e)/rrei.

τῷ, dative of interest, ‘for him,’ ‘in his day.’ The sense is: ‘he had already seen two generations of mortal men perish.’ Estimating a generation as a period of thirty years, some ancient commentators reckoned Nestor's age as seventy.

μερόπων, perhaps ‘mortal,’ was anciently but improperly derived from mei/romai, ‘divide,’ and ὄψ, ‘voice,’ and taken to mean ‘articulately speaking.’ Compare Swinburne's
men upon earth that hear
Sweet articulate words
Sweetly divided apart. —Atalanta in Calydon.
ἐφθίαθ’, where found? § 142.4, a.—The former οἵ is relative; the latter (oi(), the personal pronoun, to be taken with a(/ma: ‘together with him.’
τράφεν, form, § 136.8. Note the poet's simple order, which may properly be kept in translation: ‘were bred and born.’
ἠγαθέῃ, prefix, § 160; lengthened initial vowel, § 35.
ὢ πόποι indicates amazement; translate freely, ‘'tis past belief!’
ἦ, as before (l. 78), ‘truly.’
γηθήσαι, form, § 136.4; it agrees with the nearer subject only. Lines 255-257 contain a less vivid future—or “possible”—condition in its normal form; cf. GG. 651 (1).
κεχαροιατο, tense, § 128; ending, § 142.4, d.
σφῶιν, with marname/noiin in agreement, syntax, § 174. On the form σφῶιν, see § 110; πυθοίατο, § 142.4, d; μαρναμένοιιν, § 73.
‘(You) who are superior to the (other) Danaans in counsel, and superior in fighting.’
πέρι, accent, § 164.
βουλήν, accusative of specification; so, too, ma/xesqai.
Δαναῶν, why genitive? Cf. *klutaimnh/strhs, l. 113; se/qen, l. 186; e)mei=o, l. 259.
δέ = ga/r.
ἤδη γάρ ποτε, ‘for once on a time (gone by).’
ἠέ = Attic h)/, ‘than.’
περ = ‘even.’
ὑμῖν, dative by attraction to case of a)rei/osin (a)ndra/sin). What case would be expected?
ἀνέρας, form, § 85.—Why does not οὐδέ suffer elision? § 61.23.
ἴδωμαι, syntax, § 191.
For oi(=on *peiri/qoon etc. we should expect oi(=os [h)=n] *peiri/qoos etc.; but again we find attraction—to the case of toi/ous (l. 262).
Καινέα, form, § 90.
The line is wanting in the best MSS.
Θησέα, form, § 90.— ἀθανάτοισιν, on quantity of initial vowel, § 34.
κάρτιστοι, predicate adjective: ‘they were the very [dh/] bravest men that were ever reared on earth.’
κεῖνοι, spelling, § 120.
τράφεν, form, § 136.8.
μέν = mh/n, as usual.
ἔσαν (Attic h)=san), § 125.

φηρσίν, Aeolic for Attic qhrsi/n or qhri/ois, ‘wild beasts.’ The name refers to the rude Thessalian *ke/ntauroi, ‘Centaurs.’ “Such a name is not likely to have been assumed by the tribe itself, but is rather an opprobrious term applied to them by their enemies” (Ridgeway, The Early Age of Greece, vol. i, p. 178).
κατ’ ἔμ̓ αὐτόν § 112), ‘by myself alone,’ i. e. ‘independently,’ so that my valor could be clearly seen.
τῶν, demonstrative, § 118.1.
ἄν ... μαχέοιτο (Attic ma/xoito), ‘would fight.’
μευ occurred l. 37.
βουλέων, case and scansion, § 70.
ξύνιεν, ‘heeded’; where found? § 136.7.
ὔμμες = Attic u(mei=s, § 110.
Addressed particularly to Agamemnon.
τόνδ’(ε), Achilles, one of the two objects of the verb of depriving.
ἀγαθός περ ἐών, cf. note on l. 131.
ἀποαίρεο, form, § 48; Attic a)fairou=.
ἔα (i. e. e)/ae), ‘suffer’ her to remain with him.
πρῶτα, cf. note on l. 235.
Now Nestor turns to Achilles.
ἐριζέμεναι, where found? § 137.1, a.

οὔ ποθ’ ὁμοίης ἔμμορε τιμῆς, ‘never shares in a common honor’ with other men, i. e. he has superior dignity; Agamemnon was a “scepterbearing king”; Achilles was not, for his father still ruled; therefore Achilles should yield precedence to Agamemnon.
ἔμμορε (mei/romai), form, § 39; translated by present, § 187.
Note that καρτερός is an adjective of the positive degree; cf. l. 178.—Achilles's mother was Thetis, a goddess of the sea.
ἀλλ’(ά), ‘yet.’
πλεόνεσσιν, Attic ple/osi or plei/osi. For syntax, cf. the dative in the phrase toi=si d' a)nista/menos, l. 58.
δέ, cf. l. 58.

p.l: λίσσομ’(αι), i. e. e)gw\ de/ ei)mi o( lisso/menos (Nägelsbach^{1}), ‘for it is I, Nestor, that beseech you.’

div2.p: Ἀχιλλῆι, dative of advantage, ‘for Achilles's sake.’
μεθέμεν, form, § 137.2.
πέλεται = e)sti/.
πέρι, as in l. 258.
πάντων, syntax like that of *danaw=n, l. 258.
πάντεσσι, cf. pa=sin, l. 283.

ἅ τιν’(α) ktl., things ‘in which I think somebody will not obey.’ By tina Agamemnon evidently means himself.—In translation distinguish carefully among πέρι ... ἔμμεναι (l. 287), κρατέειν, ἀνάσσειν, and σημαίνειν: ‘to be superior,’ ‘to have power over,’ ‘to lord it,’ ‘to dictate.’

290 and 291. ‘If the immortal [ai)e\n e)o/ntes] gods did make him a warrior, therefore do his abusive words rush forward [like so many warriors to the front] for utterance?’ Others render: ‘therefore do they [i. e. the gods] permit him to utter abuses?’ If the latter translation be accepted, proqe/ousin must come, not from pro-qe/w, ‘run forward,’ but from pro-ti/qhmi, and be equivalent to Attic pro-tiqe/asi—a sole instance of the form.— ἔθεσαν, for the meaning cf. note on l. 2.
What part of speech is οἱ? Observe the accent on ultima of the previous word.
μυθήσασθαι indicates purpose.
γάρ, cf. note on l. 123.
πᾶν ἔργον, ‘in every matter.’
ὅττι, spelling, § 51.2.
ἐπιτέλλεο, formed like e(/lkeo, l. 210.
A weak line, “athetized,” i. e. rejected as spurious, by some ancient critics.
σῇσιν, cf. teo/n, l. 282 and § 113. With σὺ δ’ ἐνὶ φρεσὶ βάλλεο σῇσιν, compare Vergil's tu condita mente teneto (Aen. III, 388).
298 μαχέσσομαι, for spelling cf. l. 153. What is the Attic equivalent?
σοί, note the emphatic repetition: ‘by force (of hands) I will not fight with you—no, not with you or anybody else’; ‘you all’ is subject of a)fe/lesqe.
τῶν, emphatic repetition of tw=n a)/llwn (l. 300), partitive genitive with ti.
οὐκ ἄν τι φέροις, ‘you had better not carry away anything,’ potential optative, used—in mock courtesy—with the force of a prohibition. Cf. B 250.
ἀέκοντος ἐμεῖο = Attic a)/kontos e)mou=. Cf. a)/kontos *ku/rou, Xen. Anab, I, 3, 17.
εἰ δ’ ἄγε μὴν πείρησαι, ‘come now! just try it.’ ei) d' a)/ge is interjectional, and perhaps for an earlier ei=) a)/ge, i. e. ei)=a a)/ge. Cf. Vergil's eia age (Aen. IV, 569).
γνώωσι, form, § 149; ‘may witness (it).’— καὶ οἵδε, ‘these men here too.’
ἐρωήσει, see note on B 179.
δουρί, declined, § 97; Attic do/rati.
ἀν-στήτην, on the prefix see § 46; -sth/thn, cf. l. 6.
ἀγορήν, cf. l. 54; ‘the assembly’; the word never means ‘market-place’ in Homer.

The lodge of Achilles is described in 24.448-456: it was built for him by his Myrmidons, of pine timbers; the roof was thatched; the door was fastened by a single great bolt of pine; adjoining it was a great courtyard enclosed by stakes, set close together. Elsewhere (16.231) we infer that the courtyard (au)lh/) contained an altar of *zeu\s e(rkei=os.
ἐίσας, spelling, § 61.27.
ἤιε, cf. l. 47.
Μενοιτιάδῃ, the first introduction of the ‘gentle’ Patroclus is as the ‘son of Menoetius.’
ἅλαδε, force of suffix, § 155.5.
ἐείκοσι, spelling, § 61.9.
βῆσε, transitive first aorist; cf. bh/somen, l. 144, and note.
ἀνά is an adverb; cf. a)/n, l. 143; for its accent (not retracted), cf. § 168.
ei(=sen, a causative first aorist, containing the root of e(/zeto, l. 68.
ὑγρὰ κέλευθα, ‘their ways in the sea’ (cf. Isaiah xliii, 16: “a way in the sea, and a path in the mighty waters”).
313, 314. The scholiast compares Euripides, Iphigenia in Tauris, 1193 qa/lassa klu/zei (washes away) pa/nta ta)nqrw/pwn kaka/.
‘The savor went heavenward, curling around in the smoke’; that is, permeating the smoke.
λῆγ’(ε), imperfect third singular; cf. imperative lh=g', l. 210.— τήν, relative § 118.4) ‘with which’ he had threatened. (Cf. GG. 530 a.)
ἐπ-ηπείλης’(ε), cf. the present a)peilei=s, l. 161.
τώ, relative.
χειρός, syntax, § 172.
ἑλόντ’(ε) agrees with ‘you two’ (sfw=i) understood.
ἀγέμεν, form, § 137.2; syntax, § 213.
εἰ ... κε, Attic equivalent? Cf. l. 128.
δώῃσιν, form, § 149 (5).
ἐγὼ δέ, ‘then I,’ see note on l. 58.
κεν ... ἕλωμαι, syntax, § 192.
τό, ‘this,’ demonstrative.
καὶ ῥίγιον, ‘even more shivery’; more disagreeable or dreadful than the present mission.
βάτην, Attic e)bh/thn.

παρά, ‘along.’ The ships of the Greeks stretched in lines along the shore; Odysseus's occupied a central position; while the two ends—the most dangerous positions—were guarded by the ships of Telamonian Ajax and Achilles (11.5-9).
γε, why is e not elided? § 61.23.
οὐδ(ὲ) ... gh/qhsen *)axilleu/s, ‘and Achilles felt no thrill of joy’; on the force of the aorist, cf. l. 85.
ταρβήσαντε, note the tense, ‘struck with fear.’
βασιλῆα, form, § 86.
h(=|sin, ‘his,’ form, § 113.
καί, ‘too.’
ἆσσον, comparative of a)/gxi, ‘near’; superlative, a)/gxista.
μοι, ‘in my sight.’
ὔμμες, supply e)ste/.
ὅ, relative, § 118.4.
σφῶι, § 110.
Πατρόκλεες, declension, § 102.
σφωιν, enclitic pronoun, § 110.
ἄγειν, syntax, § 211.
μάρτυροι = Attic ma/rtures, of third declension.
πρός, ‘before’; cf. the meanings that have been already pointed out in idiomatic uses, ll. 160 and 239.
τοῦ βασιλῆος ἀπηνέος, ‘that king unkind’: the order is like to\n *xru/shn ... a)rhth=ra (l. 11).
δὴ αἶτε, pronounced as if d' au)=te § 43).
γένηται, in this more vivid future protasis note the omission of ke, § 197.
ἀμῦναι, syntax, § 211.
τοῖς ἄλλοις, dative of advantage (interest); translate with ‘from.’
γάρ receives the ictus (as in a few other lines) in spite of its quantity § 33).
θύει, ‘rages.’
‘And he does not know at all how to look at the same time to the past and to the future,’ i. e. ‘to consider carefully.’
πρόσσω and ὀπίσσω are spelled in Attic with one sigma.
‘How his Achaeans shall fight safely beside the ships.’
ὅππως § 51.1) introduces a dependent interrogative (not purpose) clause, with the future indicative § 200).
οἱ, ‘for him,’ ‘his’ § 176).
μαχέονται, form, § 151; cf. the more common future, maxesso/menos, l. 153.
παρὰ νῆας, ‘along past the ships’; cf. note on l. 327.
γυνή, in apposition to h(/, § 118.3.
ἑτάρων, with no/sfi.
ἔφ’ (e)/pi), for the accent cf. § 166.
πολλά, cf. l. 35.
χεῖρας ὀρεγνύς, toward his mother, who dwelt in the sea.
‘Mother, since you gave me birth once for all, though for a short life, honor at least ought the Olympian to have granted me.’

γε, appended to the aorist e)/tekes, gives emphasis to the single past act; with minunqa/dion e)o/nta, per has its usual force, as noted in l. 131; with timh/n, per has the force of ge, a meaning that will be noticed again (e. g. l. 508). —The form ὄφελλεν = Attic w)/feilen. But to express this thought in Attic Greek xrh=n or e)/dei with infinitive and subject accusative would be used (GG. 460).
νῦν δ’(έ), ‘but as it is.’
αὐτός, of course not in person, but ‘by his own order.’
ἀπούρας, on the form see § 63.3.
πατρί, Nereus.
ἁλός, syntax, § 175.
ἠύτε = Attic w(/sper.
δάκρυ χέοντος (with au)toi=o), ‘as he wept.’
σε φρένας, construction, § 180.
εἴδομεν, on the digamma, § 61.23; subjunctive, § 143.
It is better to translate ταῦτα πάντ’(α) with a)goreu/w (deliberative subjunctive, in question of appeal) and to understand the words with i)dui/h|.
ἰδυίῃ § 61.23) = Attic ei)dui/a|, and agrees with toi.

The home of Chryseis was Chryse; and to this she is restored (l. 430 ff.). Naturally the question arose in ancient times, “How was she taken, then, when Thebe fell?” And the answer had to be made that either (1) she was visiting in Thebe at the time when Achilles captured that town, or (2) on the same expedition on which Achilles took Thebe he stormed Chryse also. Thebe was the home of Andromache before her marriage to Hector; she was the daughter of King Eëtion. Achilles's own prize, Briseis, was taken in the spoil of the captured town Lyrnessus.
ἐνθάδε, suffix, § 155.5.
δάσσαντο, cf. de/dastai, l. 125; and for spelling, § 54.
σφίσιν, here a reflexive pronoun, and therefore accented § 111.4).
ἑκατηβόλου, cf. l. 75.
Ἀπόλλωνος, long initial vowel here, § 30.
εὐξαμένου, on translation of the tense, § 186.
ἦεν = Attic h)=n.
ἐπασσύτεροι betrays in the u for o its Aeolic origin.
ἄμμι, Attic h(mi=n, § 110; this word with u)/mmi, u)/mmes, etc., is Aeolic.
ἑκάτοιο, cf. l. 75.
πρῶτος, ‘I was first’ to urge.
Ἀτρεΐωνα, form, § 157.
ἠπείλησεν μῦθον, ‘made a threat’; mu=qos is a word of varied connotations, which the Greeks felt the meaning of; our English translation must take its cue from the context.
ὅ, relative use of the article, § 118.4.
τὴν μέν, ‘the one’ damsel; th\n de/ (l. 391), ‘the other.’
Χρύσην, here the town, not the priest.
πέμπουσιν, ‘are escorting.’
νέον κλισίηθεν κτλ., ‘only now, heralds led away [literally ‘went leading’] from my lodge.’
With ἔβαν § 136.7) the participle contains the leading idea, as with Attic oi)/xomai. Cf. w)/|xeto ple/wn (Xen. Anab. II, 6, 3), ‘went sailing off,’ ‘sailed away.’
κλισίηθεν, for suffix cf. ou)rano/qen, l. 195.
Βρισῆος, from nominative *briseu/s, declined like basileu/s, § 86.
περίσχεο, περι-έχω.
ἐῆος, form, § 99.
394, 395. ‘Go to Olympus and beseech Zeus, if ever you gladdened his heart at all, whether by word or by deed.’
Δία has the ictus on -a, § 38.
ὤνησας, ὀνίνημι.
πολλάκι, Attic polla/kis.
σεο, enclitic pronoun, § 110; limits a)/kousa.
πατρὸς ἐνὶ μεγάροισιν, ‘in the halls of my father,’ Peleus.
ἐνί receives the ictus on -i, § 38.
εὐχομένης, ‘boasting,’ agrees with seo (l. 396).
ἔφησθα, form, § 136.3.
Κρονίωνι, for syntax compare l. 67, h(mi=n.
οἴη ἐν ἀθανάτοισιν, you ‘alone among the immortals.’
ὑπελύσαο, form, § 142.1. ὑπ- means ‘from under’ the weight of his bonds.
ὦχ’, i. e. w)=ka.
μακρόν, ‘high.’
αὖτε, ‘again,’ ‘in turn.’
ou(= § 113 πατρός, Poseidon.
ὅς, with force of demonstrative, § 123.4.
ὑπέδδεισαν, for spelling cf. l. 33.
οὐδέ ἑ, account for hiatus; § 61.6.
ἑ refers to Zeus.
τῶν μιν μνήσασα, ‘remind him of this.’
λαβὲ γούνων ( § 97, § 172); not a peculiar act here, but the regular custom of suppliants in Homer.

‘In the hope that he may perhaps be willing to give aid to the Trojans, and to hem in the others at their ships' sterns and about the sea— the Achaeans.’ Achilles disdainfully sets the Achaeans' name at the very end, simply mentioning them as tou\s de/ at first (Cauer, Die Kunst des Übersetzens^{2}, p. 90).
αἴ κεν ἐθέλῃσιν § 136.6), in syntax like ai)/ ke pi/qhai, l. 207.
ἐπὶ ... ἀρῆξαι, tmesis, § 163.
ἔλσαι, εἴλω.

κτεινομένους, agreeing with *)axaiou/s: letting them be ‘slain.’— ἴνα πάντες κτλ., Pope gives the sense:
and bring
The Greeks to know the curse of such a king.
ἐπαύρωνται, ‘get acquainted with’; literally ‘partake of’ (e)pauri/skw).
ὅ τ’ ἄριστον κτλ., cf. l. 244.
αἰνά, adverbial accusative with tekou=sa, ‘after bearing you unto trouble’ (cf. Job v, 7).

ὄφελες παρὰ νηυσὶν ... ἧσθαι once meant ‘you ought to be sitting beside the ships’; cf. l. 353; and if ai)/qe be translated ‘ah!’ we may keep the rest of the sentence in its literal meaning. A wish in present time, impossible of fulfilment, is implied; cf. Xen. Anab. II, 1, 4, a)ll' w)/fele me\n *ku=ros zh=n.—The force of h(=sqai (l. 416) is ‘to be staying’ or ‘to be passing the time’ rather than ‘to be sitting,’ which is literal.

ἐπεί νύ τοι αἶσα κτλ., supply e)/sti, ‘since your measure of life is [i. e. ‘endures’] for but a brief space, not at all for very long.’ For the adverbs in the predicate, adjectives might be expected; but this Homeric construction has several parallels. Cf. 4.466, mi/nunqa de/ oi( ge/neq' o(rmh/: ‘his onset was [endured] for a brief space.’—For quantity of ultima of μάλα, cf. § § 37; 62, 2.—That Achilles had a choice between two destinies is told in I 410-415. He might have a long, inglorious life or a short, glorious one; as is well known, he chose the latter. There is no hint of the choice in the present context, however.
νῦν δ’(έ), ‘but as it is.’
περὶ πάντων, ‘above all.’
ἔπλεο, ‘you were’ and still are; or simply ‘you are’, form, § 142.1.
τῷ, ‘therefore,’ § 117.
κακῇ αἴσῃ, ‘unto an evil doom.’ Cf. § 178.
ἐρέουσα, ‘in order to tell’; cf. luso/menos, l. 13.
τερπικεραύνῳ, form and meaning, § 59.

ἀγάννιφον, spelling, § 39; prefix, § 160. When Olympus is called snowy, the poet has in mind those parts only that do not extend above the level of the clouds. On the other hand, the region where the gods dwell is the ever bright summit, high above the clouds and remote from the sight of men; here there is neither rain nor snow, but only perpetual fair weather, as the poet of the Odyssey sings (Od. 6.42-45). This summit reaches up into heaven (ou)rano/s).
αἴ κε πίθηται, syntax, § 198.
μήνι’(ε), ‘rage on.’
Αἰθιοπῆας, as if from nominative *ai)qiopeu/s. But elsewhere *ai)qi/opas, as if from *ai)qi/oy, is found.
χθιζός agrees with subject of e)/bh. Homer commonly uses temporal adjectives where the English idiom employs adverbs.
ποτί, cf. l. 245.
ἀπεβήσετο, tense, § 153.
γυναικός, genitive of cause.

ἀέκοντος, with a pronoun (like au)tou=) understood, is probably in the genitive absolute construction: ‘against his will.’ Others make it stand in an objective relation to bi/h| = ‘with violence done to him unwilling,’ ‘despite his unwillingness.’
ἀπηύρων, § 63.4.
στείλαντο, ‘furled.’

‘The mast they let down into [literally ‘made approach’] its crutch, lowering it with the forestays quickly.’ The forestays were untied from the bow; and the mast thus released was bent back into its crutch.
τὴν δ’(έ), the ship.
εὐνάς, stones for ‘anchors,’ ‘mooring-stones’; these they let go (e)k ... e)/balon) from the bow, while they made the stern cables (prumnh/sia) fast (kata\ ... e)/dhsan) to the shore.
βῆσαν, cf. bh/somen, l. 144.
νηός, declined, § 101.
χερσί, ‘arms.’
ῥέξαι, in same sense as r(e/cas, l. 147.
ἱλασόμεσθα, ending, § 142.3; mood, § 144, II; cf. i(la/sseai, l. 147.
τοί, form, § 115.
οὐλοχύτας, sacrificial barley, ‘barley for strewing’ (xe/w, ‘pour’); cf. Od. 3.441, which has to do with the description of a sacrifice: e(te/rh| d' e)/xen ou)la\s

p.l: e)n kane/w|, ‘and in his other hand he [Aretus] had barleycorns in a basket.’ This barley was sprinkled on the consecrated victims before they were sacrificed.

div2.p: ἠμὲν (i. e. h)= me\n [= mh\n]) δή ποτε ... πάρος, ‘surely once before.’
πάρος = Attic pro/sqen.
ἐμέ, with ietus on the ultima; this would be justified by the pause § 32), even if the next word did not begin with a liquid § 38).
ἴψαο, in formation like u(pelu/sao, l. 401.
ἠδ’ ἔτι καὶ νῦν, ‘and now too, again.’ h)d' (h)= de/) is correlative with h)me/n (l. 453). The clauses may be bound together in English by rendering (freely) h)me/n, ‘as,’ and h)de/, ‘so.’
ἐπικρήηνον, cf. note on l. 41.
αὐέρυσαν, formation, § 63.1; understand ‘the heads’ of the victims as object. With ἔσφαξαν and ἔδειραν, understand ‘the victims’ as object.
κατὰ ... ἐκάλυψαν, tmesis, ‘covered up.’

δίπτυχα (supply kni/shn) ποιήσαντες, ‘making it [the fat] doublefolded’; i. e. ‘folding it about’ the thigh-pieces, on both top and bottom. —ἐπ’ αὐτῶν κτλ., ‘and on them they put raw pieces.’ They cut bits of meat as primal offerings from all the limbs; these were burnt along with the thigh-pieces as a sacrifice to the god (in this instance, Apollo), who was believed thus to become a partaker of the rite.
ἔπι § 162), ‘thereon.’
πεμπώβολα § 108.5), ‘five-tined spits,’ for roasting several pieces of meat at once (Van Leeuwen). Cf. o)beloi=sin, l. 465.
κατὰ ... ἐκάη, § 163.
ἐπάσαντο, πατέομαι.
τἆλλα, § 44.

ἀμφ’ (adverb) ὀβελοῖσιν ἔπειραν, ‘they pierced them around with spits.’ Cf. Verg. Aen. 1, 212: [viscera] pars in frusta secant veribusque trementia figunt. ‘Some cut the flesh in bits and pierce it quivering with spits.’
τετύκοντο, τεύχω, § 128.
τι ... ἐδεύετο (= Attic e)dei=to, cf. deuo/menon, l. 134), ‘felt any lack,’ ‘went ungratified.’
δαιτός, genitive of material.
ἐίσης, ‘adequate,’ ‘sufficient.’
‘But when they had satisfied [literally ‘dismissed’] their desire for drink and food.’
πόσιος, declined like po/lis, § 103; cf. u(/brios, l. 214.
ἐξ ... ἕντο, § 163.
ἕντο = Attic ei(=nto, from i(/hmi.

ἔρον, second declension = Attic e)/rwta, third declension.—Cf. Vergil's imitation, Aen. VIII, 184:
Postquam exempta fames et amor compressus edendi.
‘When hunger had been satisfied and desire to eat had been appeased.’
κοῦροι = Attic ko/roi. Cf. kou/rhn and note, l. 98.
ἐπεστέψαντο ποτοῖο, ‘filled up to the brim with wine.’
ποτοῖο, genitive of material.

‘And then they passed it around to all, after they had first made libation with the cups.’ With a ladle they poured some wine into every man's cup, for him, in turn, to spill upon the ground, as an offering to the gods. The custom is said still to continue in Persia. (Cf. Fitzgerald's translation of the Rubáiyát, quatrain xxxix of the fourth edition, and note on the same.)
ἐπαρξάμενοι δεπάεσσιν § 78), literally ‘after having begun with the cups’ (instrumental dative); the verb is limited to this ritualistic use.
πανημέριοι, agreeing with the subject, ‘all the rest of the day.’
ἦμος = Attic o(/te.
ἠέλιος = Attic h(/lios.
ἐπὶ κνέφας ἦλθεν, ‘darkness came on’ § 163).
Ἠώς, declined, § 92.
ἀνάγοντο (a)n-h/gonto), ‘they put to sea,’ the regular Attic prose word.
θ’ means what? Cf. l. 23.
πρῆσεν, see note on B 415.
481, 482. ἀμφὶ δὲ κῦμα κτλ., ‘and around the stem of the ship the purple billow gurgled loud as she sped along.’
διαπρήσσουσα, spelling, § 56.
κατά, ‘over against,’ ‘opposite’; in nautical term, ‘off.’
ἐσκίδναντο = Attic e)skeda/nnunto.
νέας, spelling, § 29.
διογενής, on quantity of initial syllable, § 34.
ὑός (= ui(o/s), spelling, § § 29; 107, 1.
πωλέσκετο, meaning of suffix, § 154.1.
πόλεμον, by what principle is the ictus permitted to rest on the ultima? § 32.
φθινύθεσκε, suffixes, § 154.2.
ποθέεσκε, § 154.1.
ἀυτήν, ‘war-cry,’ not the same word as au)th/n.
πτόλεμον = Attic po/lemon.
ἐκ τοῖο, ‘thereafter,’ with reference not to what has immediately preceded, as would be natural, but to the meeting of Achilles and Thetis (cf. l. 425).
δυωδεκάτη, cf. dwdeka/th (l. 425); which is Attic?
καὶ τότε δή, ‘then it was that.’
ἴσαν = Attic h)/|esan or h)=|san.
λήθετο = Attic e)p-elanqa/neto.
ἐφετμέων, declined like boule/wn, l. 273.
ἑοῦ, § 113; what in Attic? Cf. GG. 551 d, 554 a.
ἀνεδύσετο, tense, § 153.

κῦμα, accusative of the space or way over which an action extends; cf. A 151, Z 292, and the different construction in A 359. For the meaning, compare the merman's words to his mate:
"Go up, dear heart, through the waves;
Say thy prayer, and come back to the kind sea-caves!"
She smiled, she went up through the surf in the bay. Matthew Arnold, The Forsaken Merman.
ἠερίη, construction like that of panhme/rioi (l. 472) and xqizo/s (l. 424).
οὐρανὸν Οὔλυμπόν τε, cf. note on l. 420.
εὐρύοπα, ‘far-thundering,’ third declension accusative (as if from eu)ru/oy) of a first declension noun, eu)ru/opa (nominative).
γούνων, cf. l. 407.
ὄνησα, cf. w)/nhsas, l. 395.
τίμησόν μοι υἱόν, note the metrical scheme, --- - -u u -uu-uu --, with moi remaining long in spite of the hiatus; so, too, *sminqeu= (l. 39).
ἄλλων, a genitive of comparison (i. e. originally separation), as if w)kumorw/tatos were a comparative adjective; the English point of view, however, requires ‘of all’ after the superlative.
ἔπλετ’(ο), cf. e)/pleo, l. 418.
ἀπούρας, cf. l. 356.
σύ περ = su/ ge.
τόφρα ... ὄφρα, ‘so long’ ... ‘until.’
ὀφέλλωσιν, ‘magnify.’
νεφεληγερέτα, § 67.
ὣς ἔχετ’ ἐμπεφυυῖα, ‘so she clung, fast clasping.’ Cf. genua amplexus ... haerebat, Verg. Aen. III, 607, 608.
ἐμπεφυυῖα is, literally, ‘grown on.’ a vigorous metaphor.
νημερτές, composition, § 161.
ἐπεὶ οὔ τοι κτλ., ‘since no fear rests upon you.’
ἔπι, accent, § 167; quantity of ultima, § 37.
‘Sorry doings, to be sure! in that you will compel me to fall out with Here, when she shall vex me with reproachful words.’ Why does not λοίγια suffer elision? § 61.18.
ὅ τε, § 123.7.—ἐφ-ήσεις, ἐφ-ίημι.
ἐρέθῃσιν, in form like e)qe/lh|sin, l. 408.
καὶ αὔτως, ‘even as it is.’
καί τε, the second of these words is not a conjunction here, nor has it any translatable meaning; it simply accompanies the general statement, as often in Homer. See on l. 81.
μελήσεται = Attic melh/sei. For ke with the future indicative, cf. l. 139 and § 190.
ὄφρα τελέσσω, ‘until I accomplish them.’ For omission of ke, § 197.
εἰ δ’ ἄγε, see note on l. 302.
ὄφρα, ‘in order that.’
τοῦτο, supply e)sti/.
ἐξ ἐμέθεν, § 155.2.
ἐμόν, understand te/kmwr, ‘pledge,’ and again supply e)sti/.
ἔπ’(ι), ‘thereto.’
Κρονίων, formation, § 157.
κρατός, declension, § 100.

μέγαν δ’ ἐλέλιξεν κτλ., Vergil's annuit et totum nutu tremefecit Olympum (Aen. IX, 106). These three lines (528-530) are said to have been quoted by the sculptor Phidias when he was asked after what model he should fashion his great statue of Zeus at Olympia (Strabo VIII, p. 354).
διέτμαγεν, formation, § 136.8.
ἄλτο, where found? § 131.
Ζεὺς δέ, supply e)/bh from the context.
ἑόν, cf. e(ou=, l. 496.
ἀνέσταν, formation, § 136.7.
σφοῦ, § 113.
πατρός, genitive limiting e)nanti/on, ‘before.’ Cf. note on the kindred verb a)ntia/w, l. 31.
ἐπερχόμενον, agrees with a pronoun (e. g. e() understood, object of mei=nai.
οὐ δέ μιν κτλ., ‘and Here, on seeing him, was not unaware’ etc.
μιν is object of i)dou=s'(a).
συμφράσσατο, spelling, § 54.
οἱ is dative after su/n in composition.
δὴ αὖ, synizesis, § 43.
τοι φίλον ἐστίν, ‘it is your pleasure.’
ἐόντα (as well as frone/onta, l. 542) is in agreement with the understood subject (se) of the infinitive dikaze/men (l. 542).
κρυπτάδια (accusative plural neuter) φρονέοντα (accusative singular masculine) δικαζέμεν, ‘to consider and give judgment on secret matters.’
542, 543. οὐδέ τί πώ μοι κτλ., ‘and you never bring yourself with any heartiness to tell me a plan that you are considering.’
ὅττι, cf. l. 294.
ἐπι-έλπεο, why is the -i of the prefix not elided? § 61.13.— μύθους, ‘counsels.’
εἰδήσειν (Attic ei)/sesqai), from oi=da.
χαλεποί, supply ei)de/nai, ‘hard for you to know.’
ἔσοντ’(αι) has mu=qoi understood as subject.— On ἀλόχῳ περ ἐούσῃ, see note on l. 131.
ἀλλ’ ὃν μὲν [μῦθόν] κ’ ἐπιεικὲς [ᾖ τινα] ἀκουέμεν, ‘but whatsoever counsel it is fitting for anybody to hear,’ etc.
πρότερος [σοῦ], ‘sooner than you.’
εἴσεται, see ei)dh/sein, l. 546.
ὃν [μῦθον] may well be translated in the plural, to conform, in English, to tau=ta (l. 550).
ἐγών, § 110.
ἐθέλωμι, formation, § 136.1.
ἕκαστα § 61.11), ‘one by one.’
ποῖον (predicate adjective with reference to mu=qon), ‘what a charge is this that you have spoken!’ On mu=qon, see note on l. 388.
καὶ λίην, ‘assuredly.’
πάρος (here = Attic pa/lai) with the Greek present is to be translated by the perfect tense in English (cf. GG. 454 d); compare the Latin iam dudum with the present.
ἅσς’(α), form, § 124.
ἐθέλῃσθα, formation, § 136.3.
δείδοικα, spelling, § 62.1.—μή σε παρείπῃ κτλ., ‘lest it prove that Thetis has talked you over’ (GMT. 93).
πολέας, form, § 106.

δαιμονίη (masculine daimo/nie), a common term of address, means properly a person whose conduct is so unusual or unexpected that he (of she) seems to be influenced by some untoward divinity. Sometimes a single word, sometimes a short clause, selected with reference to the context, will convey this meaning in English: ‘Here, I do not understand you,’ or ‘my misguided wife!’ Either the poet is unconscious in allowing god to address god in this inappropriate way, or he is displaying a kind of humor in letting gods mimic the speech of men.
πρῆξαι, § 64.—ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ θυμοῦ κτλ., ‘but you will be the more removed from my heart,’ i. e. out of favor with me.
ἔσεαι, Attic e)/sei.
τὸ δέ τοι κτλ., cf. l. 325.

εἰ ... ἐστίν, simple present condition with nothing implied (GG. 647): ‘suppose this is as you say [ou(/tw], 'tis my own affair [or ‘my pleasure’], I presume.’ In this idiomatic use me/llei = Attic e)/oike: me/llei ei)=nai = ‘it is like to be’ (present tense), ‘it is, very likely,’ or ‘presumably.’
τοι, dative of advantage (interest), ‘for you,’ i. e. ‘from you’: cf. l. 67, h(mi=n.
χραίσμωσιν, ‘ward off,’ an aorist which previously (ll. 28 and 242) has been met in the sense of ‘help’; its subject is ὅσοι θεοὶ εἴς’ κτλ., ‘all the gods that are on Olympus.’
ἀσσον, see note on l. 335.
ἰόνθ’ = i)o/nta, agreeing with e)me/ understood; that this pronoun of the first person is to be supplied, is indicated distinctly enough by the clause o(/te ... e)fei/w.
ἐφ-είω (i(/hmi) is inflected like qei/w, § 149 (2).
ἔδδεισεν, account for double d. § 62. 1.
καθῆστο, κάθ-ημαι.
φίλον, its force? § 114.
ἐπὶ ἦρα (used by Homer in this formula only) φέρων, ‘bearing kindly service,’ ‘doing favor.’
ἦ δὴ λοίγια ἔργα, cf. l. 518, where the expression is exclamatory; but the construction here is obviously different, for a complete predicate is supplied by ta/d' e)/ssetai ktl.
τάδ’(ε), meaning, § 120.
ἐλαόνετον, literally ‘drive,’ ‘run’ (transitive); here figuratively, ‘keep going,’ ‘keep up.’

p.l: ἐσθλῆς ἦδος (= h(donh/), ‘enjoyment of a goodly feast.’— ἐπεὶ τὰ χερείονα (= xei/rona, cf. l. 114) νικᾷ, ‘since worse matters prevail.’ ta\ xerei/ona means ta\ kaka/ (cf. l. 107), ‘rather’ than ta\ a)gaqa/.

div2.p: καὶ αὐτῇ περ νοεούσῃ, ‘although she is herself discreet.’
καὶ ... περ, see note on l. 131.
νεικείῃσι, inflected like e)qe/lh|sin, § 136.6; for -ei- see § 150.— σὺν ... ταράξῃ, tmesis.
580 εἴ περ, ‘just suppose.’
στυφελίξαι, supply h(ma=s. The conclusion—‘he can do it’—is understood. Cf. l. 136.
καθάπτεσθαι, syntax, § 213.
ἵλαος, § 77.
τέτλαθι, § 136.9.
ἐν with o)fqalmoi=sin, ‘before.’
θεινομένην, in agreement with se (l. 587): ‘lest I see you being beaten.’
ἀντιφέρεσθαι limits a)rgale/os. Cf. manteu/esqai, l. 107.
ἤδη γάρ ... ἄλλοτε, cf. h)/dh ga/r pote, l. 260.
μεμαῶτα, ‘eager,’ agrees with me.
κάππεσον = kate/peson. For kap-, § 47.
μειδήσασα, translation of tense, § 186.
παιδός, ‘from her son.’
χειρί, ‘with [or ‘in’] her hand.’

οἰνοχόει (oi)=nos, xe/w) ... ne/ktar, the poet seems unconscious of the original meaning and thinks only of the main idea, ‘poured.’ Compare Xen. Anab. II, 4, 12: h)=n de\ [to\ tei=xos] w)|kodomhme/non, ‘the wall was built’; yet oi)kodome/w is literally to ‘build a house’ (oi)=kos and de/mw, ‘build’). Other examples are not uncommon.
ἀφύσσων, ‘drawing off,’ or ‘dipping’ with a ladle. The gods who are used to Hebe and Ganymedes as cupbearers make merry over the awkward Hephaestus.
ἐνῶρτο, ἐν-όρνυμι.
γέλος, second declension in Homer (= Attic ge/lws, third declension); cf. similar nouns in this book: ma/rturoi (l. 338) and e)/ron (l. 469).
φόρμιγγος and Μουσάων (l. 604), like daito/s, limit e)deu/eto.
κακκείοντες (kata/ and kei=mai), cf. note on 16.852.
ἔβαν, cf. l. 391.
ἧχι = Attic h(=|, ‘where.’
ἀμφιγυήεις, ‘lame in both legs,’ ‘the halting god,’ according to the ancient interpretation: “both-foot-halting god,” Chapman renders it. Many prefer a modern interpretation: ‘strong in both arms.’

ἰδυίῃσι (Attic ei)dui/ais) πραπίδεσσιν, ‘with cunning mind.’ Other works of this god that are mentioned in the Iliad are: the aegis and scepter of Zeus (B 101, O 308 ff.); the arms of Achilles (18.478 ff.); the wonderful golden maidens who supported the lame god's steps (18.417); the automatic tripods (18.373 ff.); the breastplate of Diomedes (8.195) that formerly belonged to Glaucus (Z 235). Still other works are told of in the Odyssey.
θεοί and ἀνέρες, appositives to a)/lloi.
τιμήσαι, construction, § 199.
Ἀχαιῶν limits nhusi/n.

οὖλος, syntax, § 169. Countless dreams are kept ready for service, according to the poet of the Odyssey (Od. 19.560-567); those that are true pass forth by a gate of horn; the false by a gate of ivory.
ἀγορευέμεν, syntax, § 213.
κάρη § 100), accusative of specification.
13, 14. ἀμφὶς ... φράζονται, ‘counsel in two (diverse) ways’; ‘are at variance’ about the fate of Troy.
ἐπέγναμψεν, ‘brought over.’
Νηληίῳ υἷι § 107), ‘to the son of Neleus.’ *nhlhi/w|, adjective, is equivalent to *nhlh=os, genitive.
τῖ̓(ε), imperfect, = Attic e)ti/ma.
τῷ ... ἐεισάμενος, ‘having likened himself to him,’ ‘assuming his likeness.’
Ἀτρέος, form, § 90.
οὐ χρή, ‘it befits not.’ Do not say, ‘it is not necessary.’
παννύχιον agrees with a)/ndra. How do you account for the fact that the ultima, though naturally short, receives the ictus? § 32.
ἐπιτετράφαται, form, § 142.4, c; ‘are entrusted.’
ξύν-ες, ξυν-ίημι.
σευ, with kh/detai.
33 σῇσιν ἔχε φρεσί, ‘guard (this) in your heart.’
εὖτ’ ἄν, cf. A 242.
ἀν-ήῃ (i(/hmi), like qh/h|, § 149 (2).

δὲ λίπ’ (the reading of the best MS., Venetus A, and probably of Aristarchus) is written d' e)/lip' in other MSS. The latter reading is quite as likely as the former to be a correct interpretation of the original. This is one of many instances that illustrate the arbitrary character of editing with reference to the use of the augment.
αὐτοῦ, ‘there’ on his couch.
φρονέοντ’(α) agrees with to/n (l. 35), ‘considering’ those things (ta/).
τελέεσθαι is probably future § 151).
ἔμελλον, ‘were meant,’ ‘were destined.’
φῆ § 126), ‘he thought.’
νήπιος, § 170.
Arrange thus: ἐπιθήσειν ἔμελλεν, which is like the Attic in construction and meaning.
γάρ receives the ictus, § 33.
ἔπ’(ι), for the accent see § 166.
μιν ἀμφέχυτο, ‘was poured around him,’ ‘murmured in his ears.’
νηγάτεον: the most reasonable meaning proposed for this doubtful word is ‘shining,’ ‘glistening,’ an epithet appropriate to a linen chiton.
σκῆπτρον, wrought by Hephaestus and given by him to Zeus, from whom it descended to Agamemnon (ll. 101-108).
The dawn of the twenty-second day of the poem, which is not ended until Book 7, l. 380; it is the first great day of battle. See note on A 8.
Ζηνί, declension, § 98.
ἐρέουσα, ‘to announce,’ ‘to herald.’
κηρύκεσσι ... κέλευσεν, regular construction in Homer. What follows keleu/w in Attic Greek? Cf. GG. 570 c.
κηρύσσειν, § 56.
βουλήν, object of i(=ze. The principal ‘elders’ (ge/rontes) are enumerated, ll. 404-408.
Νεστορέῃ, agreeing with νηί, used instead of *ne/storos. Cf. *nhlhi/w|, l. 20.
βασιλῆος is in apposition to *ne/storos, the implied genitive.— Πυλοιγενέος, formation, § 155.4.
ἠρτύνετο = h(/rmoze, ‘framed.’ The root a)r, ‘fit,’ ‘fit together,’ is seen also in the Homeric a)rari/skw, etc.
διὰ νύκτα, ‘through the night,’ a Homeric idiom; cf. dia\ ... u(smi/nas, l. 40. How would the idea be expressed in Attic prose? Cf. Xen. Anab. IV, 6, 22: e)/kaon pura\ polla\ dia\ nukto/s.
57, 58. μάλιστα ... ἄγχιστα, ‘he bore a very close resemblance to Nestor in particular’ (ma/lista).
ᾤχετ’ ἀποπτάμενος, ‘flew off and was gone,’ ‘went flying off.’ See note on A 391. For ictus on -os see § 32.
αἴ κεν ... θωρήξομεν (form, § § 144, II; 145), for construction see § 198.
ἣ θέμις ἐστίν, ‘as is usual,’ like our “as is the rule.” The relative agrees with the predicate noun.
ἄλλοθεν ἄλλος = Latin aliunde alius.
ἐρητύειν, syntax, § 213. The object is ‘them,’ i. e. the Achaeans.
ἠμαθόεντος, formation, § 35, § 159.
Protasis of past contrary to fact—or “unreal past”—condition (GG. 649).
ἔνισπεν, second aorist of e)ne/pw, ‘tell.’
‘We should call it a deceit [on the part of an unfriendly god], and should retire rather’ than credit it; i. e. should turn our backs upon it On this use of the potential optative see § 207.
νῦν δ’(έ), like A 417.
ἔξ, why accented? § 166.
σκηπτοῦχοι βασιλῆες, see note on A 234.
ἐπεσσεύοντο, on double s see § 39.
ἠύτε, ‘even as’; see note on A 359.
εἶσι, sometimes, as here, has a present meaning in Homer (not future, as in Attic).
μελισσάων, spelling, § 56.
ἁδινάων, a word of uncertain derivation: ‘restless,’ ‘murmuring.’ Here, ‘murmuring bees’; for other shades of meaning see notes on 16.481, 18.124, 316.
αἰεὶ νέον ἐρχομενάων, ‘always pouring forth anew’; ‘with ever fresh flights.’
ἐπ’ ἄνθεσιν would be e)p' a)/nqh (accusative) in Attic prose.
εἰαρινοῖσιν, formation, § 35.
αἳ μέν ... αἳ δέ, translate as in Attic (GG. 549 a).
-τε marks the general character of the statement.
πεποτήαται, form, § 142.4, a; meaning, § 187.
τῶν, an important word, ‘of them.’ the Achaeans.
ὄσσα δεδήει (dai/w, on tense, § 188), ‘rumor was ablaze,’ spread like fire.
τετρήχει (tense, § 188), tara/ssw.
σφεας, enclitic pronoun, § 110; to be read as one syllable, § 43.
σχοίατ’(ο), syntax, § 198. 1. So, too, ἀκούσειαν.
σπουδῇ = Attic mo/gis.
ἐρήτυθεν, Attic ending? § 136.8.

ἀργεϊφόντῃ, epithet of Hermes: this may scarcely be translated ‘slayer of Argus,’ for Homer does not show any knowledge of the story of Io, which was probably later. In fact. dia/ktoros a)rgei+fo/nths belongs to a list of holy formulas, not in every instance clearly understood by the Greeks themselves, but probably inherited from very ancient ritual songs. Others are: po/tnia *(/hrh, nefelhgere/ta *zeu/s, di=a qea/wn, doth=res e)a/wn, *(ermei/as a)ka/khta, kudi/sth *tritoge/neia. It has been suggested that ‘the bright-appearing’ (cf. a)rgh/s and fai/nw) was possibly the original sense of ‘argeïphontes.’
Ἑρμείας, ending, § 66.
Thyestes was a brother of Atreus and after the latter's death succeeded to the kingship during the minority of Agamemnon.
Θυέστ’(α), § 67; = *que/sths.
φορῆναι, form, § 131; syntax, § 211.
Ἄργεϊ παντί, the whole Peloponnesus. See note on A 79.
ἀνάσσειν, in same construction as forh=nai.
ἐν-έδησε, ἐν-δέω.
σχέτλιος, ‘harsh god!’ Cf. nh/pios, l. 38.
ἐκπέρσαντ’(α) agrees with me understood. Cf. A 541.

ἀπονέεσθαι, for long initial vowel see § 34. The present of this verb usually has a future meaning, like the presents mentioned in note on 16.852. Translate, ‘should sack and return’ or ‘should sack before returning.’
δυσκλέα, shortened from dusklee/a. It is probably better to read dusklee/).
Ἄργος, syntax, § 179.
‘Such is the pleasure, doubtless, of Zeus, who is above all in might.’ On μέλλει εἶναι cf. A 564.
κάρηνα, declension, § 100.
καί, ‘too.’
‘For this is shameful even for future men to hear.’
πυθέσθαι limits αἰσχρόν. Cf. a)ntife/resqai, A 589, manteu/esqai, A 107. The next two lines and a half explain τόδε.
τοιόνδε τοσόνδε τε λαόν, ‘so brave and so many soldiers.’
δ’(έ) = ga/r. See note on A 5.
πέφανται, singular, for n belongs to the theme, not to the ending.
εἰ ... κ’(ε), with optative; see on A 60.

ὅρκια πιστὰ ταμόντες, ‘after sacrificing trusty oath sacrifices,’ ‘after offering sacrifices for a faithful treaty’; in this idiom o(/rkia is cognate object of tamei=n, ‘sacrifice.’ Properly the verb means ‘to cut’ the throat of the victim; cf. 3.292.
ἀριθμηθήμεναι, where found? § 137.1, b.
[εἰ] Τρῶες μέν [κ’ ἐθέλοιεν] λέξασθαι, ‘if the Trojans should be willing to assemble themselves.’
λέξασθαι = sullegh=nai kai\ a)qroisqh=nai e)n tau)tw=| (scholium).
ἐφέστιοι ὅσσοι ἔασιν (= Attic ei)si/n), ‘all that are at home.’
Again understand ei) at the beginning of this clause and of the next (l. 127).
οἰνοχοεύειν, syntax, § 211.
ἕκαστοι, each deka/s.
The conclusion of the conditions (ll. 123-127).
δευοίατο, for the Attic equivalent cf. notes on A 134, 468.—See note after l. 483 as to relative numbers of Achaeans and Trojans.
πλέας, short form of ple/onas.
πολλέων, cf. polla/wn (l. 117), and for scansion, § 43.
πλάζουσι occurred A 59 (plagxqe/ntas).
εἰῶς’(ι) = e)a/ousi.
δή, ‘already.’
βεβάασι, form, § 133, foot-note.
δοῦρα § 97), ‘timbers.’ After a neuter plural subject Homer uses a singular or plural verb at his pleasure.
ἥατ’(αι), form, § 142.4, b.
ποτιδέγμεναι (from prosde/xomai), § 131.
αὔτως, ‘still’ unaccomplished.
ὡς ἂν ἐγὼ εἴπω, ‘as I shall direct,’ protasis of the more vivid future condition (GG. 632 A, 650; GMT. 529).
πειθώμεθα, hortatory subjunctive.
οὐ ... ἔτι ... αἱρήσομεν, ‘no longer is there hope that we shall take.’
μετὰ πληθύν, ‘among the crowd,’ a distinctly Homeric idiom; remarkable here because used with a verb of rest. Cf. A 221, 222, bebh/kei ... meta\ dai/monas.

φή, ‘like,’ is noted in the scholia as the reading of Zenodotus, but the MSS. here all have w(s. It is interesting to know that this ancient particle of comparison has been preserved in one other place in Homer (14.499) by the requirement of the meter.
ευρός τε νότος τε, i. e. the wind between these two points, ‘a southeast wind.’ See note on I 5.
ὤρορ’(ε), where found? § 128. Distinguish from perfect o)/rwren, l. 797.
ὡς δ’ ὅτε, common Homeric formula to introduce a simile; ‘and as [happens] when’ etc.—κινήσῃ, κε or a)/n omitted, § 197.
λάβρος, with adverbial force, ‘violently.’
ἔπι, ‘thereto,’ yielding to the assault of the wind.
ἠμύει, the subject is lh/ion.
ἀλαλητῷ, ‘with shouting.’
ἵστατ’(ο) (in sense of a)ni/stato as explained by scholium), ‘stood up,’ ‘stood aloft.’
ἱεμένων § 61.22), ‘eager to go,’ agrees with a pronoun, ‘of them,’ understood.
What is the force of κεν with the aorist indicative ἐτύχθη (= e)ge/neto)? GG. 467 c, 468 b.
ὑπέρμορα, ‘beyond the decrees of fate,’ i. e. that had not been determined by fate.
This interference of the goddesses is to be placed side by side with that in A; see note on A 194.
ὢ πόποι, see note on A 254.
ἀτρυτώνη, see note on a)rgei+fo/nths, l. 103. The original meaning was perhaps ‘the unwearied,’ ‘the invincible.’
κάδ, § 47; translate with the verb, as if kata-li/poien.
εὐχωλήν, ‘as a boast’ in apposition to *(ele/nhn (l. 161).
νῆας, on the quantity of the ultima see § 32. But the force of a lost sigma of [s]a/lade (cf. Lat. sal) may have been still felt.
ἀίξασα, on the tense, § 186; with βῆ, ‘she darted away.’ Cf. notes on l. 71 and A 391.
μῆτιν has the ictus on the ultima, although it is short; see § 33.
ἑσταότ’(α), i(/sthmi.
ἐυσσέλμοιο, on double s see § 39.
μιν, syntax, § 179.
κραδίην, θυμόν, syntax, § 180.
πεσόντες, ‘tumbling,’ of disorderly embarkation, because hasty. Embarking in good order would be expressed by e)mba/ntes, as is suggested by a scholium.

μηδέ τ’ ἐρώει [Monro (Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 332) accepts as better the reading of four MSS., mhd' e)/t' e)rw/ei], ‘and do not delay’; with this verb associate the noun e)rwh/ (16.302), ‘cessation.’ But e)rwh/sei, ‘shall run,’ ‘shall gush out’ (A 303), seems to be a different word; with it is to be associated a corresponding noun, e)rwh/ (3.62), ‘rush,’ ‘thrust,’ ‘blow.’
φωνησάσης, translate by present, § 186.
θέειν, syntax, § 211; ‘he started to run.’
This Eurybates is to be distinguished from the herald of Agamemnon, mentioned A 320.
ὅς, why long? § 61.6.
Ἀγαμέμνονος limits ἀντίος, ‘to meet’; compare the similar con struction with the adverb e)nanti/on, A 534.
οἱ, dative of interest, meaning here ‘from him.’ The scepter became the symbol of his authorization to speak on behalf of Agamemnon to the kings who were his peers and to the common soldiers.
κιχείη, optative in protasis of past general condition; on the form cf. subjunctive kixei/w, A 26.
ἐρητύσασκε, meaning of suffix? § 154.1.
δαιμόνι’(ε), ‘sir! your conduet is unaccountable’; cf. note on A 561.
κακόν, on quantity of the ultima see § 37.

δειδίσσεσθαι § 62), elsewhere in Homer transitive, and perhaps here too; ‘it is not befitting to terrify you, like a low-born man.’ Others understand it (here only) as intransitive, ‘it is not becoming for you to be afraid.’
οὐ γάρ πω σάφα οἶσθ’(α), οἷός [ἐστι] νόος κτλ., ‘for you do not yet clearly know what [literally ‘of what sort’] is the purpose of the son of Atreus.’
βουλῇ, the council of the ge/rontes.
οἷον ἔειπεν, ll. 56-75.
‘May he not in his wrath (as I fear he may) do some harm to the sons of the Achaeans.’ This distinctly Homeric construction expresses an object of fear with the desire to avert it. See GMT. 261.
θυμός, ‘spirit.’
βασιλῆος, Agamemnon, if the statement is not general.
Note the emphasis continually laid on the belief that the Homeric king rules by divine right.
‘And, again, whatsoever man of the people he saw and found bawling out.’ For the occasion of their shouting cf. l. 151, toi\ d' a)llh/loisi ke/leuon ktl.
ἐλάσασκεν, ‘would strike’ § 154.1).
δαιμόνι’(ε), cf. note on l. 190.
ἐναρίθμιος, ‘counted in,’ ‘of account.’
μέν = mh/n § 31).

ἀγαθόν, a neuter substantive in the predicate, as often in Attic Greek, instead of a predicate adjective (a)gaqh/). Cf. foberw/taton d' e)rhmi/a (Xen. Anab. II, 5, 9), ‘solitude is a most fearful thing.’
Omitted in most MSS. The interpolator evidently had in mind I 99, but made a bad metrical blunder when he used basileu/h| for bouleu/h|sin.
σφίσι, ‘them,’ i. e. his subjects, is introduced very awkwardly.
ἠχῇ the ‘roar’ of voices is meant. Cf. a)lalhtw=|, l. 149.
τε, as oiten, marks the general character of the statement.
Θερσίτης, the significance of the name is of some interest (the ‘Bold’); the first element is qe/rsos, said to be Aeolic for qa/rsos.
μοῦνος = Attic mo/nos.
The sense of lines 213-215 is: ‘who knew how to say many uncivil things, so as to quarrel with kings in a reckless and unseemly way, and to prate whatever he thought was ridiculous to the Argives.’
Why is ὅς long? § 61.16.
ἔπεα ... ἄκοσμά τε πολλά τε, ‘words both disorderly and many’ is literal.
ἐριζέμεναι, syntax, § 212.
