After ἀλλ’ supply le/gein or a similar verb.
εἴσαιτο = Attic do/ceie, optative in protasis of a past general condition. See GG. 616 b, 618, 651 (2).
αἴσχιστος ἀνήρ, ‘the ugliest man’ in predicate relation to the subject of h)=lqen. Compare ka/rtistoi, A 266 and note. “The most ill-favored wight was he ... of all the Grecian host” (J. S. Blackie).
ὑπὸ Ἴλιον, Troy was situated on a hill.
e)/hn = h)=en (A 381) = Attic h)=n.
ἕτερον πόδα, ‘in one foot,’ accusative of specification.
συνοχωκότε (form, § 127), ‘bent together,’ ‘cramped.’
κεφαλήν, for construction cf. po/da, l. 217.—ψεδνὴ κτλ., ‘and sparse was the woolly hair that grew thereon.’
ἔχθιστος ... μάλιστ’(α), cf. note on l. 58.
ὀξέα κεκληγώς, ‘with shrill cries.’
λέγ’(ε), ‘he kept telling over,’ ‘recounting.’
τῷ, Agamemnon. It was because Thersites had the crowd behind him that he dared to be so insolent.
μακρὰ βοῶν, ‘bawling loud.’
τέο (Attic ti/nos or tou=), § 122.1; genitive of cause with e)pime/mfeai,
δὴ αὖτε, § 43.
πλεῖαι, supply ei)si/.
εὗτ’ ἄν = what in Attic prose? GG. 628. A present general protasis.
ἤ, introducing a question; cf. note on A 133.
ἔτι, ‘besides.’— ἐπιδεύεαι = Attic e)pi-de/ei, ‘you want.’
οἴσει (with ke), § 190.
τις (l. 229) ... *trw/wn i(ppoda/mwn, ‘a Trojan horseman.’
υἷος, genitive, § 107.
ἄποινα, ‘as a ransom,’ in apposition to o(\n [xruso/n], l. 229.

γυναῖκα, the genitive (gunaiko/s) would be expected, to correspond with xrusou= (l. 229); but either the poet loses sight of a specific verb, or perhaps he has in mind poqe/eis, which takes the accusative, as A 492.— μίσγεαι and κατίσχεαι (l. 233) are present subjunctives, the ending -eai being shortened from -hai ( § 28, § 29).
ἥν τ’(ε) ... kati/sxeai, purpose clause.
αὐτός, with ictus on ultima, § 33.
Understand tina/, ‘a man,’ as subject of ἐπιβασκέμεν.
πέπονες, ‘weaklings’; cf. Achilles's word, ou)tidanoi=sin, A 231.— ἐλέγχε’(α), ‘reproaches,’ ‘wretches.’
Ἀχαιίδες, οὐκέτ’ Ἀχαιοί, imitated in Vergil's words (Aen. IX, 617), O vere Phrygiae (neque enim Phryges).
πεσσέμεν, cf. katape/yh|, A 81; what is the metaphor involved?
χἠμεῖς, form, § 44.
οὐκί, generally found at end of sentence and of verse = Attic ou)/.
ἕο, accented, § 111.4; a genitive after the comparative a)mei/nona.
ἕο has the ictus on the ultima, § 38.
ἀλλὰ μεθήμων [ἐστί], ‘but he is remiss,’ he lets things pass. Thersites perhaps has in mind how Achilles stopped in the very act of drawing his sword on Agamemnon (A 219).
The very words used by Achilles, A 232.
ποιμένα λαῶν, the full significance of this phrase is discussed by Socrates, as related by Xenophon, Memorabilia, III, 2, 1. Cf. note on 3.179.
ὑπόδρα ἰδών, cf. A 148.
ἠνίπαπε, peculiar formation, § 129.
ὅσσοι ... ἦλθον, ‘of all that came.’
‘Therefore [τῷ, cf. A 418] you had better not speak with kings passing through your mouth.’
ἂν ... ἀγορεύοις is potential optative with the force of a prohibition—in mock courtesy; cf. A 301.

ἀνὰ στόμα may be rendered freely, ‘on your tongue’ or ‘on your lips’; cf. Xen. Cyropaedia, I, 4, 25: pa/ntes to\n *ku=ron dia\ sio/matos ei)=xon kai\ e)n lo/gw| kai\ e)n w)|dai=s, ‘all had Cyrus on their lips both in speech and in songs.’
Before προφέροις and φυλάσσοις, which are in the same construction with a)goreu/ois, understand ou)k a)/n: ‘you had better not heap reproaches on them and watch (your chance for) going home.’
τῷ, cf. l. 250.
ἣσαι ὀνειδίζων, ‘you keep on reproaching’; for this meaning of h(=mai cf. A 415, 416. Thersites sat down later (l. 268).
διδοῦσιν, for dido/-nsin § 133).
κιχήσομαι, first aorist subjunctive, probably; the corresponding indicative, kixh/sato, occurs Z 498 and elsewhere. Cf. § 145.
ὥς νύ περ ὧδε, ‘even as you now are.’
μηκέτ’ ... ἐπείη, what sort of wish? § 201. Odysseus emphatically says Ὀδυσῆι instead of e)moi/.
ἀπὸ ... δύσω, tmesis.
φίλα, meaning, § 114.
αἰδόα, ‘nakedness.’
[σε] αὐτόν, ‘you yourself,’ object of a)fh/sw.
πεπληγώς, ‘scourging.’
σκήπτρου ... χρυσέου, cf. note on A 246.
τάρβησεν, see notes on A 85, 331.
ἀλγήσας, ‘smarting with pain.’
ἀχρεῖον ἰδών, ‘with a foolish look.’
ἀχνύμενοι, on account of disappointment about going home.— ἡδύ, ‘sweetly,’ ‘pleasantly,’ ‘heartily.’
τις, ‘many a one.’
εἴπεσκεν, force of suffix, § 154.1.
πλησίον, substantive (from plhsi/os); with ἄλλον, ‘his neighbor.’
ὢ πόποι, cf. A 254.
δή, ‘already.’
βουλάς (a kind of cognate accusative) τ’ ἐξάρχων ἀγαθάς, ‘taking the lead in good counsels.’
κορύσσων, ‘arming (with helmet),’ here metaphorically, ‘marshaling’ (po/lemon).
ἄριστον, in predicate relation to to/de, ‘this is by far the best deed that he has done.’
ὅς, introducing a causal clause; ‘in that he restrained that slanderer—impudent as he was—from his harangues.’
ἀγοράων, syntax?
θην, ‘I rather think,’ in irony.
πάλιν αὖτις ἀνήσει (a\n-i/hmi), ‘will impel him back here again.’
φάσαν, note the plural with collective subject, plhqu/s.
οἱ πρῶτοί τε καὶ ὕστατοι, ‘both the nearest and the farthest.’ But οἱ may be the pronoun, a dative of reference.
πᾶσιν ... μερόπεσσι βροτοῖσιν, ‘in the sight of all mortal men.’
θέμεναι, for meaning cf. note on A 2; for form cf. do/menai, A 98.
ἐκτελέουσιν, tense, § 151.
Cf. l. 113. With ἐκπέρσαντ’(α) supply se.
ὥς τε (Attic w(/sper), ‘like.’
ἤ (the MS. reading) is superfluous to the sense; h)/ ... h)/, or te ... te, would be natural enough, but not h)/ ... te. Some editors read h)=.

‘Surely there is toil enough for a man in weariness to return,’ i. e. to cause him to return home. Supply tina/ as subject of νέεσθαι. It is possible, by adopting one or more of the emendations proposed for this line, to get a more usual construction and perhaps better sense; but they are all without MS. authority.
καὶ γάρ, ‘for even,’ as sometimes in Attic Greek (GG. 672 d).
θ’, in general statement.
εἰλέωσιν, to be read with synizesis; for meaning cf. e)/lsai, A 409. How is the mood accounted for? Cf. e(/lwmen, l. 228, and § 197.
ἡμῖν, dative of interest; cf. tw=|, A 250.
ἔννατος, for e)/nvatos. Compare e)na/th, l. 313, where digamma is neglected. This line does not quite accord with l. 134, where the nine years are said to be already gone.
μιμνόντεσσι = me/nousi (in Attic prose), dative plural of me/nwn (l. 292)
κενεόν (Attic keno/n), ‘empty-handed,’ agrees with tina/ understood, the subject of the two infinitives.
μή (instead of ou)), because the relative clause is the protasis of a condition.
ἔβαν ... φέρουσαι, ‘carried off’; see notes on A 391, B 71.

χθιζά τε καὶ πρωίζ’(α), ‘yesterday or the day before’; the sense is: ‘a day or two from the time when the ships gathered at Aulis,’ or ‘hardly had the ships gathered at Aulis,’ when etc. Others render: ‘but a day or two ago, when’ etc., making the phrase epitomize the nine intervening years between the mustering at Aulis and the present moment.
δαφοινός, meaning of prefix, § 160.
ἀτάρ, ‘while.’
τέκνα, object of o)durome/nh, which, though often taking a genitive of cause, is sometimes used transitively (T 345, 24.714, 740).

δ’ ἐλελιξάμενος is probably for an original de\ velica/menos, aorist of e(li/ssw § 61.15), which naturally means ‘coiling himself up.’ Similar formations occurring elsewhere also (as from e)leli/zw) have been noted and corrected by editors.
ἀμφιαχυῖαν (commonly called perfect of a)mfia/xw) is probably another example of a word not transmitted in its original form.
ἀρίζηλον (=a)ri/dhlon), meaning of prefix, § 160.
ὅς περ ἔφηνεν, ‘who also revealed him’ or ‘the very god that’ etc. (GG. 216.)
θαυμάζομεν, imperfect. Homer does not use the historical present. see § 182.
ἐτύχθη, ‘came to pass’; cf. l. 155.

θεῶν, with ἑκατόμβας. This line is usually connected with the following one instead of the preceding. But the punctuation of our text seems to have been that of Cicero's (cf. De Divinatione, II, 30, 64).
εἰς ὅ κεν = Attic e(/ws (a)/xri, me/xri, e)/ste) a)/n.

Γερήνιος. When Pylos was sacked by Heracles, so the old story ran, and Nestor's eleven brothers were slain, Nestor alone escaped, for he was being cared for e)n *gerh/nois (scholium), a Messenian people or place. So he was called Gerenian. It is altogether probable, however, that the story is fanciful, and that the name is a relic of a remote past which even the later epic poets themselves were unfamiliar with.
ὢ πόποι, cf. A 254, where Nestor begins with the same words.— ἥ δή, ‘surely now.’
‘In what way, then, will our compacts and oaths come out?’ That is, ‘what, then, will become of our compacts and oaths?’ The allusion is evidently the same as in ll. 286-288.
βήσεται conforms to the neuter plural subject o(/rkia only; cf. note on l. 135.

‘Then may all plans and counsels of men be burned’ to nothing! If these pledges given by you—worthless as they turn out to be—are typical of all such, better that they all be brought to naught than continue to mislead.
σπονδαὶ ἄκρητοι, ‘libations unmixed’ (with water). The wine furnished by the contracting parties was mingled in token of cementing the contract.
ἐπέπιθμεν § 57) = e)pepoi/qemen.
αὔτως, ‘in vain.’
πολὺν χρόνον ... ἐόντες, to be rendered by the English perfect. Cf. A 553.
ἔθ’ (ἔτι) ὡς πρίν § 30), ‘still as before.’
δ’(έ) = dh/.
ἕνα καὶ δύο, ‘one or two’; for kai/ compare xqiza/ te kai\ prwi/za, l. 303. The words are in apposition to tou/sde.
Ἀχαιῶν limits toi/, ‘who of the Achaeans.’

αὐτῶν, perhaps a neuter objective genitive with ἄνυσις, ‘accomplishment of them,’ i. e. of the plans. But it is probably better to take au)tw=n as a predicate genitive of possession referring to the ‘one or two’ Achaeans and translate: ‘but they shall not achieve anything.’
πρὶν ... πρίν, used as in A 97, 98.
ἰέναι limits bouleu/ws)(i) (l. 347).
Διὸς αἰγιόχοιο, construction, § 174 (3).
ἀστράπτων, nominative when the accusative would be regular to agree with *kroni/wna (l. 350).
τινα, ‘every man.’

τίσασθαι (ti/nw), ‘take pay for.’—Ἑλένης ὁρμήματα κτλ., ‘the efforts and groans about Helen’ is the better of the traditional interpretations: i. e. the efforts and groans that we Greeks have put forth for her.
ἐπίσπῃ (e)fe/pw), ‘meet’ death: for we shall slay him on the spot.
φρήτρηφιν § 155.1), in the same construction as fu/lois.
γνώσῃ, i. e. gnw/seai.
ὅς κτλ., ‘whoever of the leaders is cowardly and who of the soldiers, and whoever is brave.’
ἔῃσι, form, § 136.6; for the syntax cf. GG. 616 a. 621 a.
κατὰ σφέας (to be read with synizesis), for meaning compare A 271.
μαχέονγαι, future, § 151.
εἶεν, in a hardly attainable wish. see § 202.
με ... βάλλει. ‘plunges me.’
ἦρχον χαλεπαίνων, ‘was first to be angry.’
εἰ δέ ποτ’ ἔς γε μίαν [βουλὴν] βουλεύσομεν, ‘if ever our plans shall converge into one plan,’ i. e. ‘if we shall ever plan in accord.’
ἀνάβλησις, on the suffix, § 156.2.
ξυνάγωμεν = Latin committamus. *)/arha is the personification of proelium or pugnam. Cf. Vergil's proelia ... conserimus (Aen. II, 397 f.).
τις, ‘every man,’ as in l. 355.
ἀσπίδα θέσθω, ‘let him make his shield ready.’ ‘Let him gird on [peri-qe/sqw, ‘put on’] his shield’ is the interpretation of a scholiast.
ἀμφὶς ἰδών seems to be for an original a)mfi\ vidw/n § 61.23), ‘looking on both sides of,’ ‘seeing to’; with a(/rmatos.
ὥς κε ... κρινώμεθ’(α), ‘that we may strive together [literally ‘seek a decision’] in hateful war.’ For the syntax of the clause, § 196.
μετέσσεται, ‘shall intervene.’
εἰ μή, ‘except that,’ ‘until.’
τευ, enclitic pronoun, § 122.2; ‘many a man's.’
στήθεσφιν, § 155.1.
ἀσπίδος ἀμφιβρότης, the big shield. Cf. Introduction, 23.— χεῖρα, accusative of specification.—As subject of καμεῖται understand tis, ‘many a man.’
ὃν δέ κ’(ε) ... noh/sw, protasis of the more vivid future condition.
μιμνάζειν limits e)qe/lonta, which agrees with o(/n (l. 391).
οὔ οἱ, why not ou)/x oi(? § 61.6.

ἄρκιον, ‘sufficient,’ ‘secure.’ The latter meaning applies here: ‘it shall not be assured to him hereafter to escape dogs and birds of prey,’ or freely, ‘he shall have no security hereafter from dogs and birds of prey.’ —For the form ἐσσεῖται see note on A 211.
κῦμα, supply i)a/xh|.
προβλῆτι σκοπέλῳ, in apposition to a)kth=| (l. 395), to which it gives a more definite conception.
κύματα (l. 396) παντοίων ἀνέμων, ‘waves driven by all the various winds.’
γένωνται, subject understood, a)/nemoi.

ἄλλος δ’ ἄλλῳ (Latin alius alii) ἔρεζε κτλ., ‘one man made sacrifice to one of the ever-living gods, another man to another.’ This implies that particular divinities were worshiped by different tribes.—Lines 400-410 illustrate the commonest of the metrical pauses, § 16

βοὴν ἀγαθός, ‘good at the martial cry,’ epithet of a brave man. It is to be noted that the trumpet (sa/lpigc) was not used by Homeric heroes; the word occurs but once, in fact, and then in a simile (18.219). Signals for attack and retreat were given by powerful shouting on the part of the leaders.

ἀδελφεόν, Attic a)delfo/n, cf. keneo/n, l. 298.—The subject of the clause ὡς ἐπονεῖτο is introduced in advance, and made object of the principal verb (proleptic accusative): ‘he knew his brother, how he was toiling’; i. e. ‘he knew how his brother was toiling.’ Compare “You find yourself ... watching the storms how they gather,” Kinglake's Eothen, Examples in older English are not uncommon.

Pope paraphrases this line:
Oh thou! whose thunder rends the clouded air,
Who in the heaven of heavens hast fix'd thy throne,
Supreme of gods! unbounded and alone!
See also notes on A 420, B 458.
πρὶν ... πρίν, cf. note on A 97.—For construction of δῦναι and ἐπὶ ... ἐλθεῖν (tmesis), § 213.
κάτα, for accent on penult cf. § 164.
πρηνές, predicate adjective limiting me/laqron, after which it is to be translated ‘headlong’; the use is metaphorical, the adjective commonly being applied to living creatures.

βαλέειν, form, § 137.4.—Instead of the Homeric με ... βαλέειν, what construction follows pri/n in Attic Greek after a negative clause? Cf. Xen. Anab. I, 1, 10: kai\ dei=tai au)tou= mh\ pro/sqen katalu=sai pro\s tou\s a)ntistasiw/tas pri\n a)\n au)tw=| sumbouleu/shtai. GG. 644 b and d.
αἰθαλόεν, ‘smoke-begrimed’ roof; the me/garon had no chimney; and the roof and walls became stained with smoke from the hearth and from braziers and torches used for illuminating at night.
πρῆσαι, here ‘burn’; cf. A 481, where the sense is ‘puffed out.’

πυρός, ‘with fire,’ a kind of partitive genitive, where an instrumental dative would be expected; prh/qw is used with the genitive after the analogy of verbs of sharing and filling, which regularly take a partitive genitive (of material).
δηίοιο, η is short in scansion, § 28.
Ἑκτόρεον, for *(/ektoros, cf. *nhlhi/w|, l. 20; *nestore/h|, l. 54.
δαΐξαι with subject me (l. 414) is also included in the pri/n construction: ‘and until I have rent Hector's tunic on his breast so that it is ragged [or ‘into shreds’] with my bronze.’
πολέες, declension, § 106.
λαζοίατο, why optative? § 201.
ὀδάξ, cf. note on T 61.
δέκτο, form, § 131.
ἱρά = Attic i(era/.
ἀμέγαρτον, used like r(wgale/on (l. 417): ‘so that it was unenviable’; i. e. ‘to a sad extent.’
ὑπείρ-εχον, for an original u(pe/r-sexon.
Ἡφαίστοιο = puro/s.
μηκέτι ... λεγώμεθα, ‘let us no longer be gathered’ is a traditional rendering; others translate the verb, ‘talk with one another.’

ἀμβαλλώμεθα, for meaning cf. a)na/blhsis, l. 380. With reference to this word an interesting digression of the scholia is worth repeating: e)rwthqei\s gou=n *)ale/candros, pw=s th=s *(ella/dos e)kra/thse, “mhde\n a)naballo/menos” ei)=pen.
ἀγειρόντων, imperative.
ἴομεν, subjunctive, § 143.
θᾶσσον is rendered by Nägelsbach ‘the sooner the better.’
ἐγείρομεν, aorist subjunctive, § 144, ll.—For the construction ὄφρα (‘in order that’) κε κτλ. see § 196.
κρίνοντες, ‘marshaling’ (literally ‘separating’) into tribes and clans; cf. l. 362.
ἐρίτιμον, force of prefix, § 160.

ἀγήραον ἀθανάτην, ‘ageless,’ ‘immortal,’ not precisely equivalent in meaning. The distinetion is nicely drawn in the ancient myth of Tithonus, the husband of Dawn (Ἠώς); being a mortal, he asked for immortality (a)qanasi/an) from her who was a goddess; this he received and lived on forever; but because through ignorance he did not ask for agelessness (a)ghrasi/an) as well, he presently became subject to the troubles of old age. The goddess could not grant his request for death, but changed him into a cicada.
ἠερέθονται, spelling, § 35.
καρδίῃ, with e(ka/stw| (l. 451), § 180.
ἄλληκτον, spelling, § 39.
τε, what is its force here? Cf. l. 90.
τῶν, ‘of them,’ with xalkou=.
θεσπεσίοιο, freely, ‘countless,’ with reference to the shields and weapons.
παμφανάουσα shows the reduplicated root fan. Compare paifa/s: sousa, l. 450.
αἰθέρος, the clear air above the denser a)h/r. The top of Olympus is in this element; so Zeus is spoken of, l. 412, as ai)qe/ri nai/wn.
τῶν can not be translated at this point; it is later repeated (l. 464), when care must be taken to render it.
δουλιχοδείρων, spelling, § 35.

Ἀσίῳ ἐν λειμῶνι, ‘in the Asian meadow.’ So the words were understood by Vergil, who speaks of the birds ‘that seek everywhere for food through the Asian meads, in the sweet pools of Caÿstrus’: [volucres] quae Asia circum dulcibus in stagnis rimantur prata Caÿstri. Georgics, I. 383, 384.

Again he alludes to the Asia palus (Aen. VII, 701, 702), home of swans. [*)asi/w, i. e. *)asi/ew, genitive of *)asi/as, is a common reading also; the sense then is, ‘the meadow of Asias,’ who is said to have been a king of the Lydians.]

προκαθιζόντων, occurring where a finite verb parallel with potw=ntai might be expected, agrees with the genitives that have preceded, either o)rni/qwn (l. 459) or its appositive nouns (l. 460). The Homeric order should be preserved in translation: ‘as they noisily keep settling to the fore.’

σμαραγεῖ δέ τε λειμών, Vergil's
sonat amnis et Asia longe
pulsa palus (Aen. VII, 701, 702), ‘the river and the Asian mead resound with echoes far and wide.’
προχέοντο, the ultima remains short before *skama/ndrion: cf. l. 467 also. This is a metrical irregularity.
αὐτῶν, ‘of the men themselves.’
τε, not to be translated, § 123.3.
ἁδινάων, see note on l. 87.
αἵ τε and (l. 471) ὅτε τε, § 123.3.
δεύει, ‘wets,’ a distinet verb from deu/omai, ‘want.’
τούς, not to be translated at this point; it is repeated in l. 476, where it must not be neglected.
ῥεῖα = Attic r(a|di/ws.
τερπικεραύνῳ, § 59.
ζώνην, ‘waist,’ means a woman's ‘girdle’ usually.
βοῦς, a noun of common gender; with tau=ros (l. 481) in apposition, ‘bull’; in the plural, meaning ‘herds,’ bo/es is feminine, as l. 481 and A 154.
ἀγέληφι, syntax, § 177 (a).
ἔπλετο, ‘is,’ § 184.
ἡρώεσσιν, ‘among the warriors,’ with e)/coxon.

Then follows, after an invocation of the Muses, the “Catalogue of the Ships,” a summary of the forces gathered at Troy. It is particularly valuable as an epitome of very ancient Greek geography. It has little excuse, however, for being thrust into the narrative at this point, where it makes but a tedious interruption. It is recognized by crities as the latest accretion to the poem, belonging probably to the seventh century B. C.

Altogether 1,186 ships of the Greeks are enumerated; there were 120 men in each ship of the Boeotian contingent, the poet relates; and he later gives the number in each of the ships of Philoctetes (from Methone, etc.) as 50. On the basis of these data it is impossible to figure with any exactness the number of men whom the Greeks believed to have gone against Troy. A scholium on B 122 states that the number of Greeks is said by some to have been 120,000, by others 140,000; the Trojans, without reckoning allies, numbered 50,000 (according to 8.562, 563).

Following are the introductory lines of the Catalogue:
e)/spete nu=n moi, *mou=sai *)olu/mpia dw/mat' e)/xousai,—
u(mei=s ga\r qeai/ e)ste pa/reste/ te i)/ste te pa/nta,
h(mei=s de\ kle/os oi)=on a)kou/omen ou)de/ ti i)/dmen—
oi(/ tines h(gemo/nes *danaw=n kai\ koi/ranoi h(=san.
plhqu\n d' ou)k a)\n e)gw\ muqh/somai ou)d' o)nomh/nw,
ou)d' ei)/ moi de/ka me\n glw=ssai de/ka de\ sto/mat' ei)=en,
fwnh\ d' a)/rrhktos, xa/lkeon de/ moi h)=tor e)nei/h,
ei) mh\ *)olumpia/des *mou=sai *dio\s ai)gio/xoio
qugate/res mnhsai/aq', o(/soi u(po\ *)/ilion h)=lqon.
a)rxou\s au)= nhw=n e)re/w nh=a/s te propa/sas.
With them may be compared Vergil's Aeneid, VII, 641-646; VI, 625, 626.
The description of the advancing host of Achaeans is resumed.
*dii\ w(/s (cf. § 33, § 37, end), ‘as under the might of Zens.’
εἰν, § 35, end.
πεδίοιο, syntax, § 171.
ὠκέα, spelling, § 29.
ἀγοράς, what kind of accusative? GG. 536 a.
δέγμενος § 131), ‘awaiting the time when’ (o(ppo/te).
ναῦφιν = new=n, § 155.1.
μῦθοι ... ἄκριτοι, cf. a)krito/muqe, l. 246.
ἐπ’ εἰρήνης, ‘in the time of peace.’
ὄρωρεν, cf. l. 146.
πολλά, ‘often.’
τοιόνδε τοσόνδε τε, see note on l. 120.
ὄπωπα, § 127.
πεδίοιο, syntax, § 171.
ἄλλη δ’ ἄλλων γλῶσσα, in Latin alia aliorum lingua: ‘some speak one tongue, others another.’
πᾶσαι ... πίλαι, according to Aristarchus, means ‘the whole gate’; he contended that there was but one great gate of Troy, the ‘Scaean,’ known also as the ‘Dardanian’ (X 194).
ὀρώρει, pluperfect (on translation of the tense see § 188).
πόλιος, the last two syllables must be pronounced as one (-yos); and this one is lengthened ( § 32, § 33).
The remainder of the book (ll. 816-877) mentions the allies of the Trojans.
κλαγγῇ τ’ ἐνοπῇ τ’(ε), syntax, § 178.
ὄρνιθες ὥς, scanned --- -; for the quantity of -θες see § 37.
περ = kai/, ‘also,’ and belongs with gera/nwn. Cf. A 131.
πέλει οὐρανόθι πρό, ‘rises in heaven, to the fore,’ ‘rises before heaven.’

Vergil (Aen. X, 264-266) condenses the simile thus:
quales sub nubibus atris
Strymoniae dant signa grues, atque aethera tranant
cum sonitu, fugiuntque notos clamore secundo.
‘As beneath the stormy clouds Strymonian cranes proclaim their approach, sweeping noisily through the air and fleeing before the winds “with clamor in their train.”’
χειμῶνα, ‘winter.’
ἐπ’(ί) with genitive = ‘toward’ here.

The existence of pygmies was known to Herodotus also, who had heard of some little men living in a remote (and rather indefinite) country reached by journeying south and west from Libya (Herod. II, 32). Accounts of African pygmies are familiar enough from the reports of numerous travelers of our own day. So, while Homer's battles between pygmies and cranes belong to the realm of fairyland, it is not to be doubted that he had a basis of fact for his mention of the diminutive men.
ἔριδα, form, § 80.
κατέχευεν, on translating the tense, § 184.
κλέπτῃ δέ τε νυκτὸς ἀμείνω (accusative singular agreeing with o)mi/xlhn, l. 10), ‘but better for a thief than night.’
The order for translation is: e)pi\ to/sson, e)pi\ o(/son, (a man can see) ‘only so far as’ etc.
πεδίοιο, syntax § 171.
ἐπ’ ἀλλήλοισιν ἰόντες = Attic e)p' a)llh/lous i)o/ntes.

Tennyson says of Paris in Oenone:
A leopard skin
Droop'd from his shoulder, but his sunny hair
Cluster'd about his temples like a god's.
προκαλίζετο, ‘challenged’ by his attitude, not by speech.
μακρὰ (cognate accusative) βιβάντα, ‘with long strides.’
ὥς τε λέων ἐχάρη, ‘as a lion rejoices,’ § 184.
κεραόν, on quantity of the ultima, § 32.

p.l: σεύωνται, § 197.1. The apodosis (katesqi/ei) of this general condition is accompanied by te, which while untranslatable often marks a general statement.

div2.p: ἐξ ὀχέων, ‘from his chariot.’ Homer may use a plural form with reference to the different parts of which an object is composed. Cf. A 14, 45.
The use of chariots in Homer is limited to a comparatively few conspicuous warriors; the great majority of the fighting men go afoot. Sec Introduction. 27.
φίλον ἦτορ, ‘in his heart,’ accusative of specification.

ἀπέστη, gnomic aorist like e)xa/rh (l. 23); so too e)/llabe (l. 34), a)nexw/rhsen (l. 35), ei(=le (l. 35).—The simile is imitated by Vergil (Aen. II 379-382):
Improvisum aspris veluti qui sentibus anguem
pressit humi nitens, trepidusque repente refugit
attollentem iras et caerula colla tumentem:
haud secus Androgeus visu tremefactus abibat.

‘Like a man treading among prickly briers, who unwittingly sets foot upon a snake, and quivering recoils from it with a start as it rears its angry crest and swells its dark-hued neck: even so did Androgeus trembling at the sight start to retreat.’
ὕπο, ‘beneath,’ adverb.
ἔλλαβε, spelling, § 39.
παρειάς, with μιν, syntax, § 180.
Δύσπαρι, ‘evil Paris,’ in striking contrast with the following ei)=dos a)/riste. A similar antithesis is noticed in Tennyson's Oenone: “Beautiful Paris, evil-hearted Paris.”
αἴθ’ ὄφελες κτλ., construction, § 203.
τε ... τε, here equivalent to ‘or’; cf. B 303, 346.
ἔμεναι § 137.6), as subject supply se.
ὑπόψιον may be translated as a substantive, ‘object of others' [a)/llwn] suspicion.’
φάντες, ‘thinking.’—As subject of ἔμμεναι supply se.
ἀριστῆα πρόμον = a)/riston pro/maxon. For Paris as pro/maxos cf. l. 16. [Some editors make a)risth=a, subject of e)/mmenai, and pro/mon a predicate noun after it.]
οὔνεκα καλὸν εἶδος ἔπ’ (ι), ‘because you have a fair form.’
ἔπ’ (ι), accent, §167.
The words ἀλλ’ οὐκ κτλ. may be Hector's own, not the reported gibes of the Achaeans; but if a comma be read for the colon (after ἔπ’), they may be regarded as a continuation of the Achaeans' thought.
βίη is might for offense; ἀλκή, strength for defense.
ἦ τοιόσδε ἐών, ‘really, being such a one,’ did you do so and so? ‘Is this the man that sailed the deep’ etc., is the English idiom.
ἐπιπλώσας and μιχθείς (l. 48) are best translated as finite verbs parallel with a)nh=ges (l. 48), although of course denoting prior action.
νυόν, ‘allied by marriage,’ here.
πῆμα, χάρμα (l. 51), and κατηφείην (l. 51) are accusatives in apposition to the whole preceding sentence (cf. GG. 539): ‘(to be) a great distress’ etc.

οὐκ ἂν δὴ μείνειας § 206) ktl., ‘you had better not wait for martial Menelaus,’ ironical advice. For construction cf. B 250. Most editors put an interrogation point at the end of the line, making a taunting question.
The protasis, ‘if you should wait,’ is understood. ‘Then you would know what sort of man he is whose blooming wife you have.’
οὐκ ἂν ... χραίσμῃ, construction, § 192.
Ἀφροδίτης has initial syllable short, § 4.
ἥ τε κόμη τό τε εἶδος, in apposition to dw=ra.
ὅτ’ ἐν κονίῃσι μιγείης, ‘vhen haply you roll in the dust,’ less vivid future protasis. The use of the plural koni/h|si suggests the particles that compose the whole; cf. o)xe/wn, l. 29.

56, 57. ἦ τέ κεν ἤδη κτλ., the protasis—here wanting—may be supplied by ‘else’: ‘else surely you had already worn a chiton of stone.’ This is generally understood to mean ‘you would have been stoned to death’; but it may be that the allusion is to a mound of stones heaped up as a covering over the dead. Cf. II Samuel xviii, 17:
And they took Absalom, and cast him into a great pit in the wood, and laid a very great heap of stones upon him.
The Homeric line may easily carry both meanings; the same pile of stones that caused the death might serve as the dead man's barrow also (Studniczka).
ἕσσο, ἕννυμι.
κατ’ αἶσαν, ‘in just measure,’ ‘after my deserts.’
ὑπὲρ αἶσαν, ‘unduly.’
Paris means, ‘with your words you have cut me to the quick.’
εἶσιν, ‘goes,’ ‘is driven.’
δουρός, ‘a timber.’
τέχνῃ, ‘with art,’ ‘skilfully.’
As subject of ὀφέλλει understand ‘the axe’; it increases the effect of the man's blow by its sharpness.
ἐρωήν, cf. note on B 179.
Τρῶας καὶ πάντας Ἀχαιούς, in apposition to a)/llous, ‘the others, the Trojans’ etc.
ἀμφ’(ί) with dative, like Attic peri/ with genitive.
ἑλὼν ... οἴκαδ’ ἀγέσθω, ‘let him take and carry home with him.’
εὖ strengthens πάντα, ‘each and every one.’ The treasures referred to were brought away from the palace of Menelaus when Helen eloped with Paris.
οἱ δ’ ἄλλοι, in apposition to ‘you,’ the subject of nai/oite (l. 74), and toi/, the subject of nee/sqwn (l. 74): ‘as for the rest, you’ etc.
φιλότητα, in same construction as o(/rkia.
ταμόντες, cf. B 124.
ναίοιτε, syntax, § 204.
τοὶ δέ, the Greeks.
Ἄργος ἐς ἱππόβοτον κτλ., in this formula there is probably a trace of the original meaning of Argos, the district in Thessaly. Cf. note on A 79.
ἔβαλλον, irregular, but quite Homeric, for ba/llontes, which would be expected in a construction parallel with titusko/menoi.
μῦθον, ‘challenge’; cf. note on A 388.
κέλεται, ‘he proposes.’
Τρῶας and *)axaious are in apposition to a)/llous.
αὐτόν, ‘himself.’
οἴους, ‘alone,’ in agreement with au)to/n and *mene/laon (l. 90).

ἀκὴν ἐγένοντο, ‘were hushed’; ἀκήν, an adverb, was originally an accusative case. No wonder they were silent, as a scholiast suggests: Paris, the adulterer, now coolly proposes a duel with the injured husband; already having taken the wife, he asks for the opportunity of taking the husband's life also.
φρονέω κτλ., ‘my mind is [Monro, Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 238] that Argives and Trojans should now be parted.’
πέποσθε = pepo/nqate. Another reading, pe/pasqe, is often preferred. The forms arise from pepoq-te or pepaq-te; q becomes sigma before another lingual mute and t is aspirated.
Ἀλεξάνδρου κτλ., ‘on account of the beginning that Alexander made.’
τέτυκται, ‘is prepared.’
τεθναίη, διακρινθεῖτε, syntax, § 204.
οἴσετε, form, § 153.
ἄρν’(ε), dual. The ‘white ram’ is an offering to the sun; the ‘black ewe,’ to the earth, black being the appropriate color of victims offered to the chthonian deities.

The Greeks, being strangers (cei=noi) in the land, propose to sacrifice to Zeus— *zeu\s d' e)pitimh/twr i(keta/wn te cei/nwn te, cei/nios, o(\s cei/noisin a(/m) ai)doi/oisin o)phdei=. ‘For Zeus is the protector of suppliants and strangers, the strangers' god, who attends on strangers to whom respect is due’ (Od. 9.270, 271).
ἄξετε, tense, § 153.
Πριάμοιο βίην, ‘the might of Priam’= ‘mighty Priam.’—The expression ὅρκια τάμνῃ

p.l: αὐτός evidently does not mean that Priam ‘by his own hand’ may perform the sacrifice, for Agamemnon does this (l. 273).

div2.p: παῖδες ... ἄπιστοι, Paris is particularly meant by this general charge.
108-110. General truths.
οἷς may be masculine or neuter: ‘among what men’ or ‘in what affairs an old man has a part.’ On ὁ see § 119.
μετ-έῃσι, § 136.6; on omission of a)/n or ke in the present general protasis, § 197.
πρόσσω καὶ ὀπίσσω, for meaning cf. A 343.
ὅπως ... γένηται, syntax, § 199.
ἵππους, horses harnessed to chariots.
ἐπὶ στίχας, ‘in rows,’ like 18.602.
ἐκ ... ἔβαν, from the chariots; there was no cavalry in Homeric warfare. See Introduction. 27.
ἀμφίς, ‘between,’ separating Achaeans and Trojans.
ἄρν’ = a)/rna.
οἰσέμεναι, tense, § 153.
τήν, relative.
εἶχε, as his wife.
Λαοδίκην, appositive to th/n (l. 123).
δίπλακα, ‘double mantle,’ substantive (or adjective with xlai=nas understood) in apposition to i(sto/n (l. 125), ‘web.’ See Introduction, 12,
ἐνέπασσεν, ‘was weaving therein.’
ὠκέα, spelling, § 29. 130. νύμφα φίλη, ‘dear child.’
οἵ, relative; the antecedent is oi(/ (l. 134), ‘those.’
ἕαται, form. § § 29; 142, 4, b. The meaning is ‘rest’ rather than ‘sit,’ for they are standing, as is shown by the next line.
τῷ νικήσαντι (syntax, § 176), to be translated as if tou= nikh\santos.

κε marks the participle as conditional; the only other instance, in Homer, of this use of ke is in l. 255; it is very likely suggested by the form of l. 71, o(ppo/teros de/ ke nikh/sh|, where ke is of course regular with the subjunctive.
κεκλήσῃ, ‘you shall be called,’ is nearly equivalent to ‘you shall be.’
ἀνδρός, mentioned in ll. 52, 53.
ἄστεος, Sparta.
τοκήων, Leda and her husband Tyndareus; but Helen's father was Zeus (l. 199).
ὀθόνῃσιν, here used as a veil. Cf. note on 18.595.

οἳ δ’ ἀμφὶ Πρίαμον κτλ. The names are to be translated as nominatives; cf. Xen. Anab. III, 5, 1: oi( d' a)mfi\ *tissafe/rnhn kai\ *)ariai=on a)potrauo/menoi a)/llhn o(do\n w)/|xonto, oi( d' a)mfi\ *xeiri/sofon kataba/ntes e)stratopedeu/onto ktl. ‘Tissaphernes and Ariaeus and those that were with them’ ... ‘Chirisophus and his followers.’
Οὐκαλέγων τε καὶ Ἀντήνωρ, a free use of nominatives where accusatives, in the same construction as *pri/amon, etc., might be expected.
ἐπὶ Σκαιῇσι πύλῃσιν, cf. note on Z 373.

δενδρέῳ, scansion, § 43; like xruse/w|, A 15. The note of the cicada is described as ligurh/n, ‘shrill,’ ‘clear,’ in the familiar Anacreontic (32, l. 14), and perhaps the difficult λειριόεσσαν is intended to convey a similar meaning here; it is commonly translated ‘delicate.’

ἱεῖσιν, Attic i(a=sin (i(/hmi), ‘send forth’: from i(e/-nsin § 133). In connection with this curious association of the aged councilors with cicadas, the story of Tithonus (note on B 447) may be recalled; but of course the poet here limits the likeness to the voice alone.
οὐ νέμεσις = ou) nemeshto/n, ‘it is no cause for blame.’
πάσχειν with πολὺν χρόνον has the force of a perfect in English. Cf. note on A 553.
πῆμα, in apposition to ‘she,’ i. e. Helen, the subject of li/poito. The verb is used in passive sense § 185).
πάροιθ’ (ε), with ἐμεῖο, ‘beside me.’
ἵζευ, § 42.
πηούς, connections by marriage.
μοι, ‘in my sight,’ a true dative § 176).
ὡς = i(/na, ‘in order that.’
ὅς τις ὅδ’ ἐστὶν Ἀχαιὸς ἀνήρ, ‘who this Achaean man is,’ repeats in the form of an indirect question the object of e)conomh/nh|s (l. 166), to/nd' a)/ndra pelw/rion.

κεφαλῇ, ‘in stature,’ dative of respect, a subdivision of the instrumental use § 178); cf. kefalh=| (l. 193), w)/moisin (l. 194), and also the accusatives of specification, a closely related construction, kefalh/n and w)/mous, l. 227.
ἔασιν, cf. B 125.
Helen's dutiful reply to Priam's kindly address of l. 162: ‘rev erend in my sight are you, dear father, and awful.’
ἑκυρέ, ‘father-inlaw,’ once began with sv, the force of which consonants still survives in this line.
For δϝεινός see § 62.
ὡς ὄφελεν ... ἁδεῖν § 203), ‘oh that death had been my choice —evil death!’—ἁδεῖν, ἁνδάνω.
γνωτούς, with special reference to her brothers, Castor and Polydeuces (l. 237).
παῖδα, cf. Od. 4.12-14:
*(ele/nh| de\ qeoi\ go/non ou)ke/t' e)/fainon, e)pei\ dh\ to\ prw=ton e)gei/nato pai=d' e)rateinh/n, *(ermio/nhn, h)\ ei)=dos e)/xe xruse/hs *)afrodi/ths.
‘To Helen the gods never again gave offspring, when once she had borne a lovely daughter, Hermione, who had the looks of golden Aphrodite.’— ὁμηλικίην, ‘companionship,’ i. e. ‘companions.’
τά γ’ οὐκ ἐγένοντο, ‘this came not.’
τό, ‘therefore.’
ἀμφότερον, ‘both,’ an appositive to the following nouns, basileu/s ... ai)xmhth/s.

τε after basileu/s is pleonastic. On the whole line cf. Xen. Memorabilia, III, 2, where Socrates is represented discussing the meaning of the words, in close connection with the other phrase commonly applied to Agamemnon, poime/na law=n (e. g. B 243):
‘Why does Homer praise Agamemnon in these words— a)mfo/teron, basileu/s t' a)gaqo\s kratero/s t' ai)xmhth/s?

Is it not because he would be a mighty warrior not if he alone should struggle nobly against the enemy, but if he should lead all his army to fight bravely; and a good king, not if he should direct his own life only with success, but if he should lead his subjects also to prosperity?’
κυνώπιδος agrees with e)mou=, implied in e)mo/s. Cf. Z 490.
εἴ ποτε ἔην γε, ‘if such he ever was’; an expression of painful doubt whether the past was really true.

‘In very truth, many were the sons of the Achaeans under your command, it now appears [r(a],’ is a literal rendering; but the English idiom requires, ‘many are the sons of the Achaeans under your command, I now see.’ The Greek and the English take different points of view: the Greek suggests, ‘I was formerly somewhat mistaken in my view; it now appears [a)/ra] that all the time certain facts were true’ (and still continue so); the English lays emphasis on the present situation only, implying what the Greek states, just as the Greek implies what the English states. Compare similar examples, I 316, II 33, 60, etc.
ἐλέχθην, ‘was numbered’ (root leg), or possibly ‘was posted’ (root lex, cf. leca/sqwn, I 67).

Ἀμαζόνες: the tradition, recorded in the scholium, is that the Amazons, who lived by the Thermodon, overran Phrygia the Great, on a marauding expedition, in the time of the Phrygian leaders, Mygdon and Otreus. Priam went to the aid of the Phrygians, whose vast force greatly impressed him. It will be observed that the later story that the Amazons with their queen Penthesilea came to aid Priam against the Greeks scarcely tallies with this Homeric allusion in which Priam appears as the Amazons' enemy. In this myth of the Amazons' invasion of Asia Minor some scholars see a record of the incursions of northern tribes with their warlike women. Various peoples of the north had customs which agree remarkably with those ascribed to the Amazons; and it is not impossible that an extravagant version of their migrations survived in the Amazon myth. Another theory about the matter is set forth by A. H. Sayce in The Hittites, pp. 78-80, where it is maintained that the story of the Amazons has its origin in “the armed priestesses of the Hittite goddess.”
μείων μέν, supply e)sti/.
ὤμοισιν, στέρνοισιν, cf. l. 168 and note.
ἰδέ = kai/.
ἰδέσθαι limits eu)ru/teros, ‘broader to look upon.’
κτίλος has short ultima in spite of the following w(/s.

Ἰθάκης κραναῆς, cf. Od. 4.605-608:
e)n d' *)iqa/kh| ou)/t' a)\r dro/moi eu\re/es ou)/te ti leimw/n:
ai)gi/botos, kai\ ma=llon e)ph/ratos i(ppobo/toio.
ou) ga/r tis nh/swn i(pph/latos ou)d' e)ulei/mwn,
ai(/ q' a(li\ kekli/atai. *)iqa/kh de/ te kai\ peri\ pase/wn.

‘In Ithaca there are neither broad runs nor any meadowland at all; it is grazed by goats and more lovely than a land where horses are pastured. For none of the isles that lie upon the sea is suited to horse driving or even rich in meadows; and of Ithaca this is true above all.’
τὴν δ’ ... ἀντίον ηὔδα = th\n de\ ... proshu/da.

ἤδη γὰρ ... ποτ’(ε), cf. A 260. Menelaus and Odysseus came to Troy on an embassy before hostilities actually began; the incident is referred to elsewhere also (11.138-141). Their purpose was to demand Helen. At that time Antenor, son of Hicetaon, entertained them and frustrated a treacherous plot against their lives. After the capture of Troy, as the scholiast continues, Agamemnon gave orders to spare the home of Antenor, marking it by a suspended leopard skin.
ἀγγελίης, genitive of a)ggeli/h, with e(/nek)(a), ‘on a message about you.’
σεῦ is objective genitive with a)ggeli/hs. For the order cf. l. 100: Ἀλεξάνδρου ἕνεκ’ ἀρχῆς. [Some understand a)ggeli/hs as nominative=a)/ggelos, and take seu= with e(/nek)(a).]
στάντων, partitive genitive.
ὑπείρεχεν, cf. B 426.
ὤμους, accusative of specification.

ἄμφω δ’ ἑζομένω, in apposition to the following nominatives, of which the first only, *)odusseu/s, is expressed; the second, *mene/laos, is implied. It is as if the poet had continued, *mene/laos d' h(=tton geraro/s.
ἦ, ‘although,’ ‘yet.’
γένει, in sense of geneh=|, ‘in birth,’ ‘in years.’
ὑπαὶ ... ἴδεσκε § 154.1), ‘kept looking down.’
κατὰ χθονός, ‘down on the ground,’ with o)/mmata ph/cas. In this construction the genitive probably illustrates the local use (cf. § 171, § 173).
σκῆπτρον, why did he hold a scepter? Cf. A 234.
φαίης κεν § 207), ‘you [indefinite subject] would have thought.’
ζάκοτον ... τιν’(α), ‘a very surly fellow,’ because he kept his eyes on the ground; ἄφρονα ... αὔτως, ‘a mere [or ‘perfect’] dolt,’ because he seemed not to know enough to gesticulate with the staff.
ἐρίσσειε, force in English, § 207; cf. fai/hs ken above (l. 220).
‘Then we were not so much amazed at seeing Odysseus's looks’ as we were at his words (scholium). His oratory was an agreeable surprise.
θεὸς ὤς, on the scansion, § 37.
κεν ... γνοίην, potential optative; in this instance the present indicative would better conform to the English idiom.
τ’ is for toi, § 40.4; or possibly te (cf. A 521).
ἰδέειν, form, § 137.4.
τώ μοι κτλ., ‘whom the same mother bore that bore me.’
μοι μία, ‘one with me,’ is short for ‘the same as my mother.’ mi/a here = h( au)th/, and the dative is either a true dative or possibly “sociative.”
The idea is, either they did not come at all, or although they came, they do not wish to take part in the battle.

243, 244. The poet of these lines does not recognize the story, if he knew it, of the alternate immortality of the Dioscuri. It is mentioned, however, in the Odyssey (Od. 11.302-304). The lyric poet Pindar relates (Nemean X, 49-90) the story of the slaying of Castor, who was mortal; and he tells how immortal Polydeuces, with the consent of Zeus, shared his immortality with his brother:
metameibo/menoi d' e)nalla\c a(me/ran ta\n me\n para\ patri\ fi/lw|
*di\ ne/montai, ta\n d' u(po\ keu/qesi gai/as e)n gua/lois *qera/pnas,
po/tmon a)mpipla/ntes o(moi=on.

‘And shifting their abode by turns, they spend one day in company with their father Zeus, and the next they pass under the hidden places of the earth, in the recesses of Therapne, fulfilling a like destiny.’—Nemean X, 55-57.
θεῶν: with o(/rkis pista/ as in l. 269.
ὅρκια, offerings for cementing oaths, namely a)/rne du/w kai\ oi)=non (l. 246).
ὄρσεο, form, § 153.
τάμητε, note the change to plural subject, ‘you all.’
ἀμφὶ γυναικί, Attic peri\ gunaiko/s. Cf. peri\ sei=o, l. 137.
τῷ δέ κε νικήσαντι, cf. l. 138.
ἕποιτο, syntax, § 204.
ναίοιμεν, syntax, § 204.
νέονται, with future meaning.
ἂν ... ἔβη, ‘mounted’ the chariot.
δίφρον, accusative of limit of motion.
Σκαιῶν, for *skaia/wn. Supply pula/wn (pulw=n).
ἔχον, ‘guided.’
ἐξ ἵππων, ‘from their chariots’; cf. notes on ll. 29, 113.
ἄν, supply w)/rnuto.
ὅρκια, cf. l. 245.
μίσγον, ‘mingled’ the wine of the Greeks with that of the Trojans. Wine unmixed with water (B 341, spondai\ a)/krhtoi) was used in such ceremonies.
The knife (ma/xairan, l. 271), ‘which always hung by the great scabbard of his sword.’
ἄωρτο (for which a)/orto has been proposed as the proper spelling) is pluperfect of a)ei/rw, and means, literally, ‘was suspended.’
τάμνε τρίχας, as a sign that the victim was consecrated for sacrifice.
ἀρίστοις, with *trw/wn kai\ *)axaiw=n.
Ἠέλιος, case, § 169.
οἵ, ‘ye that,’ includes Hades and Persephone and in particular the Erinyes. Cf. T 258-260:
i)/stw nu=n *zeu\s prw=ta, qew=n u(/patos kai\ a)/ristos, *gh= te kai\ *)he/lios kai\ e)rinu/es, ai(/ q' u(po\ gai=an a)nqrw/pous ti/nuntai, o(/tis k) e)pi/orkon o)mo/ssh|.
Τρῶας ... ἀποδοῦναι (syntax, § 213)=Attic *trw=es a)podo/ntwn or a)podo/twsan.
τιμήν, ‘recompense,’ ‘fine.’
ἀποτινέμεν, in same construction as a)podou=nai.
ἥντιν’ ἔοικεν, ‘whatever 'tis seemly’ (to pay).
ἣ ... πέληται expresses purpose; ‘so that it shall be in remembrance [literally ‘be in motion’] among men to come also.’

οὐκ instead of mh/ is found in this protasis because the negative modifies e)qe/lwsin alone, with which it forms one idea, ‘refuse’; the construction is Attic also. If the negative were unattached, and modified the whole clause, it would be mh/.
αὐτὰρ ἐγώ, ‘I for my part.’
ἧος, cf. A 193.
ἀπὸ ... τάμε, tmesis.
ἀπὸ ... εἵλετο, tmesis.
δεπάεσσιν modifies ἀφυσσόμενοι, not e)/kxeon (l. 296)
ἔκχεον, supply xama/dis (l. 300).
‘Whichever party may be first to commit wrong contrary to the oaths’—protasis of what sort of condition? GG. 651 (1).
σφ’(ι), ‘their,’ § 176.
ῥέοι, syntax, § 201.
αὐτῶν agrees with a genitive implied in sf)(i) (l. 300). Preserve the Greek order in translation: ‘their own and their children's.’
ἄλλοισι δαμεῖεν, ‘become subject to others.’
ἄλλοισι, for prose u(p' a)/llwn, is properly a dative of interest § 176), but commonly called dative of agent.
ἐν = ‘before.’

Why did Priam take away with him the two lambs that he had contributed to the sacrifice? A scholium says, ‘to bury them; for it was usual for citizens of the land to bury their oath-victims, and for strangers to cast theirs into the sea.’ (Cf. T 267 f.)

χῶρον ... διεμέτρεον, cf. l. 344, which means, ‘and they [the combatants] stood near each other in the measured space.’ It is suggested in the scholia that certain bounds were determined for the contestants, retreat beyond which was an acknowledgment of defeat. These limits may well have served also to keep the spectators from crowding in. How far the contestants were separated at the beginning of the struggle, the reader is not told.

‘They shook the lots,’ says the poet; then after repeating the people's prayer, which is made while the shaking takes place, he recurs to the thought more definitely (l. 324) and adds, ‘Hector shook’ the lots.
ἀφείη, construction, § 209.
‘Grant that he die and enter the house of Hades.’
δός is to be understood before filo/thta ... gene/sqai. If this line stood by itself, apart from the preceding verse, it could be brought under § 213, as equivalent to filo/ths ... gene/sqw.

324, 325. The man whose lot jumped out of the helmet first was chosen —in this instance—to hurl the spear first. As it was an advantage under the present circumstances to have this first chance, Hector looked away, in shaking the helmet, to avoid any charge of unfair play.
κατὰ στίχας, ‘in rows.’

ἔκειτο (in meaning, passive of ti/qhmi), ‘were placed,’ conforms to its neuter plural subject teu/xea. Its connection with the former subject, i(/ppoi, is so loose that in translating i(/ppoi another predicate, e(/stasan, had better be supplied.
Paris came light-armed, to fight as a bowman (cf. ll. 17 f.). Now in preparing for the duel, he arms as for a hand-to-hand contest.
He puts on his brother's breastplate, for apparently he had not brought his own, as the duel was unexpected. He had one at home, however (Z 322).
ἥρμοσε, if intransitive (cf. P 210, T 385), has qw/rhc under stood as subject; if transitive (cf. Od. 5.162, 247), has ‘he’ (Paris) as subject and qw/rhka understood as object.
His sword and shield were suspended by straps passing over his shoulders, the sword strap probably over the right shoulder, the shield strap probably over the left. Cf. A 190.
ὅ οἱ παλάμηφιν ἀρήρει, ‘which fitted his hand.’
ἑκάτερθεν ὁμίλου = e)c e(kate/rou o(mi/lou. The Greek point of view is characteristically ‘from’ the object; we say, ‘in either throng,’ ‘each in his own army.’
δεινὸν δερκόμενοι, ‘glaring dreadfully.’
πρόσθε, ‘first,’ like pro/sqen, l. 317.
ἔρρηξεν, the understood object is a)spi/da.
οἱ αἰχμή, ‘its point’; οἱ (dative of interest, § 176) refers to xalko/s, ‘the bronze’ head of the spear.
ὤρνυτο, ‘poised himself.’
ἄνα, vocative of a)/nac.—do\s ti/sasqai o(/ ktl., ‘give me vengeance on him who’ etc.
τις ... καὶ ὀψιγόνων ἀνθρώπων, ‘many a one of men to come also.’
ἐρρίγῃσι, form, § 136.6.
φιλότητα παράσχῃ (par-e/xw), ‘proffers hospitality.’
διά, scansion, § 36.
ἀνασχόμενος, ‘raising his arm’ to deal the blow.
αὐτῷ, i. e. the fa/los, on which see Introduction, 33.
τε καί, for translation cf. B 303, 346, 3.40.
κακότητος, genitive of cause, a common Attic construction; cf. Xen. Anab. VII, 4, 23, timwrh/sasqai au)tou\s th=s e)piqe/sews, ‘to punish them for the attack.’
ἄγη, ἄγνυμι.
παλάμηφιν, here ablatival genitive, § 155, § 1; 175.
κόρυθος, syntax, § 172.
ὀχεύς, appositive to o(/s.—te/tato, tei/nw.
ὀξύ, cognate accusative with no/hse, ‘had directed a quick glance.’

ἱμάντα βοός (genitive of material) ktl., ‘strap made from the skir of an ox slain with might.’ This means a strong strap; for, as the scholiast explains, the leather made from diseased animals, that die natural deaths, is inferior.
κταμένοιο, aorist middle with passive meaning, § 185.
κεινή (note the accent) = Attic kenh/.
τρυφάλεια, see Introduction, 33.
ἔγχεϊ χαλκείῳ: the warrior regularly carried two spears; Menelaus's first spear only has been thrown (ll. 18, 367, 368).
θεός, feminine, as A 516, etc.
καλέους’(α), tense, § 151.
ἴε = Attic h)/|ei (ei)=mi).
ἑανοῦ, ‘robe’ § 172).
ἐτίναξε, ‘shook’ her; supply min.
μιν, object of prose/eipen.
οἱ § 176), i. e. Helen, has ναιεταούσῃ in agreement.
ἤσκειν has n movable, although the imperfect of a contract verb.
μιν refers to the wool spinner; the subject of φιλέεσκεν is Helen.
φαίης, with indefinite subject.
δαιμονίη, ‘wonderful goddess!’
πῃ ... πολίων, § 173.
Φρυγίης and Μῃονίης limit poli/wn (l. 400).
ὑποστρέψειας, § 201, § 204.
Ὄλυμπον, accusative of limit of motion.
εἰς ὅ κε = Attic e(/ws a)/n.
ποιήσεται, § 144, II.

If I do go, Helen reasons, the Trojan women will reproach me for being the cause of renewed hostilities. According to the terms of the compact, I ought now to go to the victor, not to the vanquished Paris.— ἔχω, ‘I already have.’
σχετλίη, the first syllable is short, § 4.
μητίσομαι § 144, II), in construction corresponding with meqei/w (l. 414) and a)pexqh/rw (l. 415).
σὺ δέ κεν ... ὄληαι, future statement in an independent sentence, § 192.
οἶτον, cognate accusative.
κατασχομένη κτλ., similar in meaning to l. 141, a)rgennh=|si kaluyame/nh o)qo/nh|sin.
θεά, appositive to *)afrodi/th (l. 424).
πάλιν κλίνασα, ‘averting.’
ἠνίπαπε occurred B 245.
ὡς ὤφελες ... ὀλέσθαι § 203), ‘ah! you ought to have perished there!’
ἀνδρί, so-called dative of agent with passive damei/s (cf. a)/lloisi, l. 301); this construction is limited to what tenses in Attic Greek? GG. 524 b.
Μενελάου, genitive of comparison with fe/rteros (l. 431).
προκάλεσσαι, where found? GG. 284. Where might a different form. prokale/ssai (note accent), be found? GG. 285. The advice in this line and the next is ironical.
ἀλλά ς’ ἐγώ γε ... κέλομαι, ‘no, I for my part urge you.’
δαμήῃς, § 149 (a).
με ... θυμόν, § 180.
Paris is not candid enough to add that he himself escaped death by the timely intervention of Aphrodite only.
ἐγώ, supply nikh/sw.
πάρα, adverbial, as l. 135, A 611, B 279.
τραπείομεν (te/rpw), second aorist passive subjunctive, § 149 (a).
ἀμφεκάλυψεν, ‘encompassed,’ or ‘enmeshed’ like a net (scholium). Many modern commentators prefer ‘enwrapt’ like a cloud.
σε, object of a(rpa/cas (l. 444).

τρητοῖσι, ‘perforated’ with holes, applied to bedsteads. There are various explanations: one, that through these holes passed the leather thongs (i(ma/ntes) which formed a network to support the bed-clothes; another, that the holes were bored in the process of fitting together the parts of the frame.
ὅμιλον, of Trojans.
εἰ ... ἐσαθρήσειεν, § 198.1.
φιλότητι, § 178.

εἴ τις ἴδοιτο is probably to be translated as the protasis of a past contrary to fact condition; the construction is extraordinary, but comparison may be made with I 515-517, X 20. For ei) tis i)/doito, ei) ei)/donto has been proposed, which conforms to the regular Attic construction, found in Homer also (e. g. l. 374). The line reads in the MSS.:
ou) me\n ga\r filo/thti/ g' e)keu/qanon, ei)/ tis i)/doito.

φαίνετ’ (αι) ... *menela/ou, ‘seems to belong to Menelaus.’ Menelaus has not fulfilled the terms prescribed by Agamemnon (l. 284), for he has not slain Paris; but he has satisfied Hector's statement of the terms (l. 92), for Paris by deserting the lists has left him the victory. Compare note on l. 315. Menelaus did not notice Aphrodite's interference, and is of course, like the others, puzzled by Paris's disappearance.
ἀποτινέμεν, § 213. Cf. notes on ll. 286, 287.
οἳ μέν, Diomedes and his charioteer, Sthenelus.
τὼ δέ, Aeneas and Pandarus. The combination of dual subject, dual participle, and plural verb is not inconsistent with epic diction.
τόν, Diomedes, as shown by *tude/os ui(e/ (l. 277).

ὀιστός, in apposition to be/los. The reference is to ll. 95-106 of this Book, where it is told how Pandarus shot an arrow at Diomedes, slightly wounding his shoulder:
to\n d' ou) be/los w)ku\ da/massen (l. 106).
νῦν αὖτ’(ε), ‘once more now.’
πταμένη, πέτομαι.
αἰχμή is the ‘point’ of the spear.
τῷ δ’ ἔπι, ‘and over him.’
ἔπι is thus accented by Cauer § 166), in spite of the fact that d'(e/) intervenes.
μακρόν, cognate accusative.
βέβληαι, § 142.2, a.
κενεῶνα, accusative of specification.— διαμπερές, adverb, really neuter of diamperh/s, ‘quite through’ (dia/ + a)n(a/) + root per of pei/rw, ‘pierce’).
οὐ ταρβήσας, ‘undismayed’; the time is coincident with that of prose/fh § 186).
ἤμβροτες = Attic h(/martes.
μέν, ‘surely,’ = Attic mh/n.
πρὶν ... πρὶν ἤ = Attic pro/sqen ... pri/n (without h)/), Latin priusquam.
ἕτερον, ‘one of you twain.’
αἵματος, ‘with blood,’ partitive genitive.
ταλαύρινον § 63.2), ‘enduring the oxhide shield,’ i. e. ‘stout in battle.’
ῥῖνα (nominative r(i/s), § 179.—The subject of ἐπέρησεν is be/los understood.
ἀπό, with τάμε, § 163: ‘the unyielding bronze cut his tongue off at the root.’

ἐξεσύθη: this aorist (cf. e)k-seu/w) does not occur elsewhere in Homer; it has the support of the Alexandrian scholar Zenodotus; Aristarchus, on the other hand, favored e)celu/qh, the reading of some MSS. The latter form, difficult in itself, has been ingeniously interpreted as an ancient mistake for e)c-e/luqe or (with n movable) e)c-e/luqen, the unaugmented form of e)c-h/luqen, Attic e)c-h=lqen, which gives excellent sense.
νείατον, ‘lowest part of.’
παμφανάοντα, see note on B 458.
ψυχή τε μένος τε, ‘both breath of life and strength.’

As Diomedes, when he hurled his javelin, was afoot, and Pandarus was in his chariot, it has long been discussed how the spear could have inflicted a vertical wound from above. If one is not satisfied with the explanation that Athene guided the weapon (l. 290), he may suppose that Pandarus was bending forward to dodge the missile when caught by the spear-point (scholium).
ἀπόρουσε, understand ‘from his chariot.’
ἀμφὶ ... βαῖνε, compare the metaphorical use of the same words in A 37.—For accent of ὥς, § 123.5.
ἀλκί, metaplastic dative from nominative a)lkh/.
οἱ, dative of advantage.
τοῦ refers to the slain Pandarus; in construction like patro/s, A 534.

σμερδαλέα, note long ultima; § § 38; 61, 5. Vergil evidently had in mind this passage, with M 445 ff. and 21.403 ff., when he wrote Aen. XII, 896-901 (Turnus is the subject):
Nec plura effatus saxum circumspicit ingens,
saxum antiquum ingens, campo quod forte iacebat,
limes agro positus, litem ut discerneret arvis.
Vix illud lecti his sex cervice subirent,
qualia nunc hominum producit corpora tellus:
ille manu raptum trepida torquebat in hostem, etc.

Dryden's translation is:
Then, as he roll'd his troubled eyes around,
An antique stone he saw; the common bound
Of neighbouring fields, and barrier of the ground:
So vast, that tweleve strong men of modern days
Th' enormous weight from earth could hardly raise.
He heav'd it at a lift; and, poised on high.
Ran, staggering on, against his enemy.
ῥέα, short form of r(ei=a § 29), Attic r(a|di/ws.
τῷ, ‘with this’; like the Attic idiom, ba/llein li/qois, ‘to throw stones.’ ‘This he threw at Aeneas's hip, where the thigh plays in the hipjoint—“the cup” men call it.’ For te of l. 305 see § 123.3.
τε marks the general statement.
πρὸς δ’ (έ), ‘and besides.’
ὦσε δ’ ἄπο = Attic a)pw=se (a)p-wqe/w) de/.
ῥινόν, ‘skin.’ Distinguish from r(i=na (l. 291).
ἔστη, ‘he held himself upright,’ although he fell on his knee; he did not faint.
γαίης, ‘on the earth,’ genitive of place.
κεν ... ἀπόλοιτο = Attic a)pw/leto a)/n. see § 207.
‘And she spread the fold of her shining white robe in front, for his protection.’
οἱ is dative of advantage.
υἱὸς Καπανῆος, Sthenelus.
τάων, ‘those’ commands, § 115.
ἠρύκακε, § 129.
μώνυχας, ‘solid-footed,’ in contradistinction to the cloven hoofs of oxen, etc.
ἐξ ἄντυγος ἡνία τείνας, ‘tying the reins to the chariot-rim.’
Αἰνείαο limits i(/ppous.
ὁμηλικίης, syntax, § 175; cf. A 287. ‘Companionship’ here as in 3.175 means ‘companions.’
οἱ refers to Sthenelus.
ἄρτια ᾔδει, ‘knew things that suited’ him, ‘was congenial’ to him. Compare 16.73, h)/pia ei)dei/h, ‘have a gentle heart’; Od. 9.189, a)qemi/stia h)/|dei, ‘had a lawless heart.’
ὧν ἵππων ἐπιβάς, ‘mounting his chariot.’
ἡνία σιγαλόεντα, ‘gleaming reins’; probably the reins were decorated with little pieces of ivory, sewed on: such reins are mentioned, E 583: h(ni/a leu/k' e)le/fanti, ‘reins white with ivory.’
Τυδεΐδην is to be taken with meta/ of me/qepe, while i(/ppous is direct object of the verb.
νηλέι, § 161.
ἀνδρῶν, with po/lemon.

Ἐνυώ, a murderous, city-destroying goddess of war, usually accompanying Ares. Later poets say that she was the mother (or daughter or nurse) of Ares; and from this source came his name *)enua/lios. Cf. Xen. Anab. I, 8, 18.
ῥ’(α), perhaps a substitute for a lost v)(e), that is, e(, ‘her.’— ὀπάζων = diw/kwn.
ἄκρην χεῖρα, ‘the extremity of the hand’; the part near the wrist is meant, as is shown by l. 339.—On οὔτασε see note, O 745.
ἀβληχρήν: if possible, preserve the Homeric order, ‘her hand—her soft hand.’
πρυμνόν is a substantive.
δόρυ χροὸς (partitive genitive) ἀντετόρησεν (l. 337) ... prumno\n u(/per qe/naros, ‘the spear bored through the skin above the base of the palm,’ i. e. through the “heel” of the hand.
For the long ultima of μέγα see note on l. 302.—The final vowel of ἀπό has the ictus before e(/o, which originally began with sv § 61.6).
κάββαλεν (=kate/balen), ‘let fall,’ § 47.
πολέμου, genitive of separation.
ἢ οὐχ, to be read with synizesis, § 43.
χ̓ = ke.
ἑτέρωθι, literally ‘on the other side’; here ‘elsewhere’ or ‘from a distance.’
γιγνώσκων, with concessive force.
ὑπείρεχε, for u(pe/r-sexe. Cf. B 426.
δεινὰ δ’ ὁμοκλήσας, ‘breaking forth with a grim cry.’ For the force of the aorist cf. note on A 85.
The sense is, the race of gods is not like to that of men: it is superior.
τε follows ἐρχομένων rather than xamai/, because xamai\ e)rxome/nwn is regarded as a single expression: “men creeping here below” (Chapman).
ἀλευάμενος, for the tense, § 186.
Περγάμῳ, the citadel of Troy.
εἰν ἱερῇ, § 35, end. The temple here mentioned seems to have been a family seat of Apollo, his mother, and his sister.

Hector, fulfilling the bidding of his brother Helenus, returns to the city to urge a public supplication of Athene and the other gods. The ‘oak’ seems to have been a conspicuous landmark on the plain, outside the Scaean gate; elsewhere (e. g. E 693) it is mentioned as sacred to Zeus.
εἰρόμεναι παῖδας κτλ., ‘asking about their sons’ etc.
ἔτας, ‘relatives,’ more distant.
ξεστῇς αἰθούσῃσι, porticoes built about the courtyard with blocks of smoothly hewn stone.
δεδμημένοι, δέμω.
‘And for his daughters, on the opposite side, facing these [chambers of his sons] within the courtyard, were twelve chambers.’
κουράων limits qa/lamoi (l. 248).
ἔνθα indicates the courtyard with its chambers, to which Hecabe was coming from the me/garon.

Λαοδίκην ἐσάγουσα probably means ‘while she was leading [or ‘accompanying’] Laodice to her apartment’; the old interpretation, ‘while proceeding to Laodice's apartment,’ suits the sense well enough; the objection to it is that it makes e)sa/gousa intransitive. The verse offers an explanation of Hecabe's presence in the courtyard.
Arrange for translation: οἷ (dative of interest) ἐνέφυ χειρί, ‘she grasped [literally ‘grew to’] his hand.’
μαρναμένους, agreeing with *trw=as or some equivalent word understood, object of tei/rousi (l. 255).
ἐνθάδε, to be translated with e)lqo/nta (l. 257).—ἀνῆκεν, ἀν-ίημι.
ἐξ ἄκρης πόλιος, with xei=ras a)nasxei=n. The temples of the gods were in the citadel; cf. E 446, Z 297.—On the form πόλιος, § 103.
ὄφρα, ‘until.’
ἐνείκω, φέρω.
The sentence beginning ἔπειτα δέ is independent of the preceding construction.
καὐτός § 44), ‘yourself too.’
ὀνήσεαι is future indicative.
πίῃσθα, § 136.3.
δέ, ‘for.’
μένος μέγα οἶνος ἀέξει, ‘wine makes the strength wax mighty.’
τύνη, § 110.
ἔτῃσιν, ‘compatriots,’ ‘fellows.’
ἄειρε, ‘offer.’
οὐδέ πῃ ἔστι, ‘for it is not at all possible,’ i. e. ‘permissible.’
πεπαλαγμένον, agreeing with tina/ (‘anybody’) understood.

On the sentiment cf. Verg. Aen. II, 717-720:
Tu, genitor, cape sacra manu patriosque Penates;
me, bello e tanto digressum et caede recenti,
attrectare nefas, donec me flumine vivo abluero.

‘Do you, father, take in your hand the sacred emblems and the household Penates; for me, freshly come out of the great battle and carnage, it is impious to handle them until I shall have washed in running water.’
ἐνί, with lengthened ultima, § 38.
τοι ... αὐτῇ, § 112.
ὑποσχέσθαι, infinitive for imperative.
ἤνις, ‘yearlings,’ § 81.
αἴ κ’ ἐλεήσῃ, § 198.
φόβοιο, almost always ‘flight’ in Homer, not ‘fear.’ So fobe/omai means ‘flee,’ not as in later Greek, ‘fear.’
‘In the hope that he will listen to me as I speak.’ On the time denoted by εἰπόντος, § 186.
χάνοι, optative of wish, introduced by w(/s ke. ke is very unusual with the optative of wish; some editors therefore change it to de/, but without MS. authority.
μέγα, with ph=ma: ‘the Olympian raised him to be a great burden.’
κατελθόντ’(α), like ei)po/ntos (l. 281), refers to a single act, and denotes time coincident with that of i)/doimi.
Ἄιδος εἴσω = do/mon *)/aidos ei)/sw (3.322).

‘I should think I had quite forgotten joyless woe in my heart,’ i. e. ‘I should think my heart quite free from joyless woe.’ φρένα is to be regarded as accusative of specification. An easier reading is that of Zenodotus, which has fi/lon h)=tor instead of fre/n' a)te/rpou.
ποτί has ultima long, § 38.
κατεβήσετο, tense, § 153.
οἱ, dative of possession.
τάς, the antecedent is gunaikw=n (l. 289).
ἐπιπλώς, second aorist participle of which indicative forms -e/plws, -e/plw exist; the Attic is e)pipleu/sas (first aorist).
εὐρέα, Attic eu)ru/n.
τὴν ὁδόν, accusative with h)/gage (l. 291); cf. A 496. The allusion to Sidon indicates that the poet was familiar with the story that Paris brought Helen to Troy by a roundabout way.

Herodotus (II, 113-116), who says he heard the story from Egyptian priests, narrates that Paris with Helen touched at Egypt too, to which land they were driven by adverse winds. Herodotus tells at length of their experience in Egypt: King Proteus on learning the story of Paris's wickedness decided to keep Helen and the treasures stolen from Sparta until Menelaus should call for them; he ordered Paris and his other companions to leave Egypt within three days. While Homer did not find this story suited to his purposes, he yet knew it, Herodotus thinks, as the reference to Sidon shows.

Herodotus adds (ib. 117) that according to another account (the Cypria) Alexander and Helen came from Sparta to Troy in three days (“on the third day”), with a fair wind and smooth sea. As this is evidently contradictory to the allusion in ll. 290-292, he argues that Homer could not have written the Cypria.
ποικίλμασιν, ‘gay-colored patterns.’
ἄλλων, ablatival genitive after the comparative idea involved in nei/atos: ‘undermost of all.’ Compare the similar construction of a)/llwn, A 505.
ὤιξε, οἴγνυμι.
The final syllables of both *kisshi/s and a)/loxos, although naturally short, receive the ictus. § 32, § 33.
ἔθηκαν = e)poi/hsan, as often in Homer.

ἆξον, ἄγνυμι. Cf. Verg. Aen. XI, 484 f.:
frange manu telum Phrygii praedonis, et ipsum
pronum sterne solo, portisque effunde sub altis.
The Latin matrons pray to Athene for defense against Aeneas:
‘Break with thy arm the spear of the Phrygian pirate, lay him headlong on the ground, and under the high gates overwhelm him.’
ἀνένευε, ‘nodded upward,’ in token of dissent, as the Greeks do to-day.
Unlike the other children of Priam, Paris and Hector (ll. 305, 370) had houses of their own.

θάλαμον καὶ δῶμα καὶ αὐλήν indicate the complete Homeric house: (1) the interior and sleeping room, in particular the women's apartment; (2) the general reception hall (me/garon); (3) the courtyard. For description in detail and plan see Jebb's Homer: An Introduction to the Iliad and the Odyssey (Boston, 1894), pp. 57-62.
πάροιθε δουρός, ‘at the end of the spear.’
χρύσεος, on quantity of antepenult, § 30.
πόρκης, ‘ring,’ ‘ferrule.’ The metal head of the spear was set in the wooden shaft; then a ferrule was bound around the juncture.
ἕποντα, ‘busy.’
ἀσπίδα καὶ θώρηκα, in apposition to teu/xe)(a), l. 321.
δαιμόνι’(ε), ‘brother, you are acting strangely’; cf. A 561.—οὐ μὲν καλὰ κτλ., ‘you have not done right to cherish this wrath.’ καλά is an adverb.

ἔνθεο, second aorist indicative of e)n-ti/qemai. The ‘wrath’ is probably that which Hector supposes Paris to feel against his fellow Trojans; they hated him (3.454) and were quite indifferent to his fate in the duel with Menelaus (3.320-323); and Paris doubtless returned their feelings. Of course, one may understand that the Trojans' wrath toward Paris is meant, an interpretation old as the scholia.
327, 328. The underlying thought, which Hector does not express in words, is: “Yet you sit here, careless and indifferent.”
σὺ δ’ ἂν μαχέσαιο κτλ., ‘and you would quarrel with any other man, too, whomsoever you should see forbear from hateful war.’
ἄνα, adverb meaning ‘up!’
πυρός, see note on B 415.
δηίοιο, scansion, § 28.
θέρηται, ‘be burned.’
νεμέσσι, remarkable form from ne/mesis, equivalent to Attic )/eme/sei.
ἄχεϊ προτραπέσθαι, ‘to give way to anguish.’
παρειποῦς’(α) has its first syllable long because originally sounded parveipou=sa § 61.16). But the digamma is neglected, A 555.
νίκη δ’ ἐπαμείβεται ἄνδρας, ‘victory comes to men by turns.’ For a similar sentiment of Paris see 3.439 f.
δύω, aorist subjunctive, § 193.
κυνός, appositive to e)mei=o. For signification cf. A 225, 3.180.— κακομηχάνοο, § 74.
κρυοέσσης, causing chilly fear, ‘horrid.’

ὥς μ’(ε) ὄφελ’(ε), a past impossible wish, § 203. The subject of ὄφελε (= Attic w)/fele) is qu/ella (l. 346). μ̓ (l. 345) is object of profe/rousa (l. 346). οἴχεσθαι (l. 346) although present in form is past in meaning. Translate: ‘would that a dreadful blast of wind had borne me onward’ (literally ‘had gone bearing me’). Compare Helen's previous wish, not unlike this, 3.173, and Tennyson's reminiscence of the lines:
I would the white cold heavy-plunging foam,
Whirl'd by the wind, had roll'd me deep below,
Then when I left my home. A Dream of Fair Women.

ἀπόερσε: elision of o was prevented by the consonant sound that originally intervened between o and e; a digamma is inferred. Compare e)pieime/ne, A 149.—In construction, ἔνθα ... ἀπόερσε is the protasis of a past contrary to fact condition: ‘where the billow would have swept me away.’ The conditional force may be clearly seen if the idea be phrased thus: ‘I wish a whirlwind had carried me seaward, if the billows could have swept me away there before these deeds were done.’
A present impossible wish, § 203; GG. 470 b.

‘Who were sensitive to the censure and repeated reproaches of men.’ The clause ὃς ᾔδει is equivalent, in construction, to the protasis of a present contrary to fact condition. Compare e)/nqa ... a)po/erse (l. 348).— Why is ὅς long? § 61.23.
τούτῳ, § 121.
ἐπαυρήσεσθαι, ‘will reap the fruits’; cf. A 410. Supply ‘of his witlessness’ after the infinitive.
σὲ ... φρένας, § 180.
ἐπὶ ... θῆκε, tmesis.
ἐπέσσυται, ὄφρ’(α) ktl., a solitary instance of this construction; usually e)pe/ssutai is followed by the infinitive.
οἰκῆας, the ultima receives the ictus § 32). The word is best understood as = oi)ke/tas.
γάρ is a long syllable before voi=da § 61.23); ἤ is short § 25.1).
δαμάουσιν, § 151.
ἐὺ ναιετάοντας, ‘well-situated’ or ‘comfortable.’
πύργῳ, the great tower over the Scaean gate, mentioned 3.153.
ἔνδον, within the me/gaoon.
οὐδόν, the threshold of the qa/lamos, in the rear of the me/garon. Cf. l. 316.
εἰ δ’ ἄγε. See note on A 302.
For the omission of the noun with the genitives γαλόων, etc., cf. *)/ai+dos ei)/sw, l. 284.
ἐπειγομένη, ‘with haste.’
μαινομένῃ ἐικυῖα, ‘like one distraught.’

τὴν αὐτὴν ὁδόν (for construction cf. A 496), ‘the same road’ as the one by which he had come to the palace. The article as used here, while possibly demonstrative, resembles the Attic; elsewhere (Od. 8.107, Od. 10.263, Od. 16.138) au)th\n o(do/n occurs, without the article, meaning ‘the same road.’
τῇ, relative adverb.
Andromache seems to have left the tower (cf. l. 386 ff.) whence she had looked in vain over the field of battle for her husband; and as she turns homeward she meets him.
πολύδωρος, ‘much giving.’ ‘bounteous’ (cf. h)pio/dwros, l. 251), which easily passes into ‘richly dowered.’ Cf. note on X 472.
Ἠετίων, nominative for genitive, attracted to the case of its following relative o(/s—a singular construction.
Ἕκτορι, equivalent to u(po\ *(/ektoros. See note on 3.301, a)/lloisi.
νήπιον αὔτως, ‘a mere infant.’

402, 403. Hector named his boy after the Trojan river *ska/mandros. but the people, out of gratitude to their great defender, called his child Ἀστυάναξ, ‘city-lord,’ a name appropriate to the father. The name *(/ektwr itself may be from e)/xw and mean ‘upholder,’ ‘defender.’ In allusion to this signification Andromache says in her lamentation (24.730): e)/xes d' a)lo/xous kedna\s kai\ nh/pia te/kna, ‘thou didst defend honored wives and young children.’—On the quantity of the syllable before Σκαμάνδριον see note on B 465.
δαιμόνιε, ‘my husband, I like not your daring.’ Cf. l. 326 and A 561.
τὸ σὸν μένος, ‘this might of yours’; cf. A 207.
θαλπωρή, ‘comfort’ (from qa/lpw, ‘warm’); on formation see § 156.2.—ἐπί-σπῃς, ἐφ-έπω.

This line and one below (429) suggested to Sophocles the words which he put into the mouth of Tecmessa (as noted in the scholium ad locum) when she addressed Ajax:
e)moi\ ga\r ou)ke/t' e)/stin ei)s o(/ ti ble/pw
plh\n sou=: su\ ga/r moi patri/d' h)/|stwsas dori/,
kai\ mhte/r' a)/llh moi=ra to\n fu/santa/ te
kaqei=len *(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras.
ti)s dh=t' e)moi\ ge/noit' a)\n a)nti\ sou= patri/s;
ti/s plou=tos; e)n soi\ pa=s' e)/gwge sw/|zomai. Ajax, 514-519. “I have nothing left whereunto I can look, save thee. Thou didst ravage my country with the spear, and another doom hath laid low my mother and my sire, that they should dwell with Hades in their death. What home, then, could I find, if I lost thee? What wealth? On thee hangs all my welfare.”—Translation of Sir Richard Jebb.
κατέκηε, κατακαίω.
ἔπι, adverb, ‘thereon.’
ἔχεεν (xe/w), ‘heaped up.’
οἵ, relative; the antecedent is the demonstrative oi(/ of the following line.
Ἄιδος εἴσω, cf. l. 284.
κατέπεφνε, tense, § 128.
ἔπ’(ι), ‘with,’ i. e. ‘in charge of,’ ‘while tending.’
τήν repeats the object mhte/ra (l. 425).
Apollo is said to slay men, and Artemis women, that die by sudden —but not violent—death.
θαλερός, ‘blooming.’ ‘stalwart.’
μὴ ... θήῃς § 149 (2)], ‘lest you make.’
Lines 433-439 are a weak ending of the splendid âppeal. Military directions sound strange indeed on the lips of Andromache.

The statements that one portion of the wall is scalable and that perhaps the Greeks have been directed to this part by an oracle (l. 438) allude to a story not found in Homer, but repeated in Pindar's eighth Olympian ode, ll. 40-57. Its substance is this: Apollo and Poseidon, when about to build a rampart around Troy, called a mortal, Aeacus, to their aid. After the wall was built, three dragons tried to scale it; two died in the attempt, but one succeeded, in the part where the hands of Aeacus had wrought. Then Apollo interpreted the portent to mean that Troy was destined to be taken at the place where the mortal had labored.
τρὶς ... ἐπειρήσανθ’ (i. e. e)peirh/santo): there is no other allusion in Homer to these three attacks; and in fact the battle at present is not near the city wall.
ἔνισπε, i. e. e)/ni-spe, second aorist from e)nne/pw (e)n-se/pw). ἐὺ εἰδώς, with genitive, § 174 (4).
οὐδέ με θυμὸς ἄνωγεν, supply mi/mnein e)pi\ pu/rgw| (cf. l. 431).
ἀρνύμενος, ‘seeking to guard.’
αὐτοῦ agrees with an e)mou= implied in e)mo\n (kle/os).

447-449. This terrible foreboding of Hector is an indication of his present state of mind and possibly has no further significance. At any rate he seems to forget it later when he prays for his boy (ll. 476-481).
ἐυμμελίω, § 69.

‘But no sorrow for Trojans hereafter wounds my heart so deeply nor for Hecabe herself nor for lord Priam nor for my brothers, who though many and brave will fall in the dust beneath their foes, as grief for you’ (supply e)moi\ me/lei).—The genitives Τρώων, etc., including σεῦ (l. 454), are objective after a)/lgos.
κεν (l. 452) ... pe/soien, § 206.
σεῦ, the MSS. have sei=) (or sei=o) here, which might be retained; but seu= is preferred by some editors to avoid elision before the following pause.
ἀπούρας, § 63.3.
Ἄργει seems to mean here ‘Greece,’ in a general sense.
πρὸς ἄλλης = u(po\ a)/llhs keleuome/nh.
Μεσσηίδος, if understood of the spring in Laconia, suggests the realm of Menelaus; while ̔γπερείης suggests the home of Achilles, in southern Thessaly. These two genitives are ablatival.
κατὰ ... χέουσαν, tmesis.
ἀριστεύεσκε, followed by infinitive, is equivalent to a)/ristos h)=n.
χήτεϊ, dative of cause.
ἀμύνειν depends on toiou=d'(e), or rather on a oi(/ou which it implies; translate ‘such as,’ ‘able.’
κατὰ ... καλύπτοι, a wish.
ἔτι, ‘besides,’ i. e. in addition to your other distresses. Many editors prefer ge/ ti for g' e)/ti. Both readings are found in MSS.
With βοῆς, πυθέσθαι means ‘hear’; with ἑλκηθμοῖο, ‘hear of.’ For the latter genitive cf. § 174 (1).
‘Seeing it nodding dreadfully from the peak of the helmet.’— δεινόν is cognate accusative with neu/onta, which agrees with lo/fon understood.
κρατός, § 100.
ku/se, kune/w.—ph=le, pa/llw.

In this prayer (ll. 476 ff.) the Sophoclean scholia note a resemblance to the following lines which Ajax addresses to his child:
w)= pai=, ge/noio patro\s eu)tuxe/steros,
ta\ d' a)/ll' o(/moios: kai\ ge/noi' a)\n ou) kako/s. Ajax, 550 f.
‘My boy, I pray that you may be more fortunate than your father, but in all other respects like him; and you will not be base.’
παῖδ’ ἐμόν, appositive to to/nde (l. 476), while a)riprepe/a is a predicate adjective in agreement, after gene/sqai
Τρώεσσιν, ‘among the Trojans’; cf. 2.483, h(rw/essin.
Instead of ἀνάσσειν an adjective or participle might be expected, corresponding with a)gaqo/n. As the construction stands, a)na/ssein depends on do/te (l. 476).
τις, ‘men’ in general.
εἵποι, a prayer § 201).
ἀνιόντα agrees with min, or a similar word, understood, object of ei)/poi: ‘may men say of him, as he returns from war.’
χερσίν, ‘arms,’ as 1.441.
δακρυόεν, cognate accusative with gela/sasa.
ἐλέησε, ‘was moved to pity.’
δαιμονίη, ‘dear wife, I do not understand you.’
ὑπὲρ αἶσαν, ‘beyond my doom,’ ‘before my time.’
πεφυγμένον ἔμμεναι = Attic pefeuge/nai.
κακὸν ... ἐσθλόν, in sense of ‘the coward’ and ‘the brave man.’
ἐπὴν τὰ πρῶτα γένηται, ‘when once he is born.’
ς’ is for σά.
αὐτῆς agrees with the implied genitive. Compare l. 446, au\tou=.
γόον, a noun.
γόον, a verb, commonly called second aorist of goa/w (l. 373).
μιν, although short, receives the ictus.
Paris was evidently stung by Hector's reproof (ll. 326-331), and wished to make amends by his readiness to enter the battle again.

‘And as happens when’ etc., the protasis of a present general condition, § 197. The simile (ll. 506-511) is imitated by Vergil, who applies the comparison to Turnus:
qualis ubi abruptis fugit praesepia vinclis
tandem liber equus, campoque potitus aperto
aut ille in pastus armentaque tendit equarum,
aut assuetus aquae perfundi flumine noto
emicat, arrectisque fremit cervicibus alte
luxurians, luduntque iubae per colla, per armos. Aen. XI, 492-497.

As when, his halter snapped, the steed Darts forth, rejoicing to be freed, And ranges o'er the open mead, Keen life in every limb: Now hies he to the pastured mares, Now to the well-known river fares, Where oft he wont to swim: He tosses high his head, and neighs: His mane o'er neck and shoulder plays.—Conington.
So luxurious Paris, proud of his fair looks and waving hair, prances off heedlessly to battle.
θείῃ, Attic qe/h|, § 150.
πεδίοιο, § 171.
εἰωθώς, ἔθων.
ἐυρρεῖος, contracted genitive from e)urree/os. The nominative is e)urreh/s, and the word is declined like a)lhqh/s.
ποταμοῖο, a kind of partitive genitive, in construction like pedi/oio (l. 507); or it may be compared with puro/s, B 415.
ἀγλαΐηφι, equivalent to dative § 155.1). The nominative ὃ δ’ (έ) has no predicate; ἑ (l. 511), which repeats o(\ d'(e/), is object of fe/rei, while γοῦνα is subject.
Note the galloping effect of the abundant dactyls.
ἀδελφεόν, Attic a)delfo/n.
ἔμελλεν, ‘he was about,’ followed by future infinitive, as in Attic.
ἠθεῖ’(ε), ‘my dear [brother].’
ἐναίσιμον, ‘in good time.’
ὃς ἐναίσιμος εἴη, either the protasis of a less vivid future condition, or ei)/h is assimilated from the indicative to the mood of a)timh/seie (l. 522).
ἀλλὰ ἑκὼν κτλ., ‘but you are willingly remiss and irresolute.’— μεθιεῖς, on form, § 132; for meaning cf. meqh/mwn, B 241.
οὐκ ἐθέλεις, literally ‘you have not the will to do.’
τό, ‘therefore,’ is probably a cognate object of a)/xnutai. Cf. 3.176.
ὅθ’=o(/te.
ὑπέρ, used in sense of peri/, ‘about.’
ἀκούω is subjunctive, § 197.
πρὸς Τρώων, ‘on the part of’ or ‘from the Trojans.’
τὰ δ’ ὄπισθεν ἀρεσσόμεθ’(α), ‘we will adjust these things hereafter.’
κρητῆρα ... ἐλεύθερον, ‘a mixing-bowl in honor of freedom.’

ἐλάσαντας agrees with h(ma=s, the understood subject of sth/sasqai (l. 528). Translate the whole: ‘if ever Zeus shall allow us, in honor of the heavenly gods that live for ever, to set forth a mixing-bowl in the name of freedom in our halls, when we have driven from Troy the well-greaved Achaeans.’
φύζα, regulariy flight accompanied by fear; but the latter idea predominates in the present context: ‘panic.’
φόβου, as commonly in Homer, ‘flight.’
βεβολήατο, § 142.4, a.
ὀρίνετον, aorist subjunctive or present indicative? Cf. § § 143; 144. II; 145; 197.
ιχθυόεντα, § 159.
The northwest wind is meant.
ἔχευεν, gnomic aorist § 184).
Like a wild storm at sea was the spirit of the Achaeans, rent alike by fear and grief.
φοίτα, the tense expresses repeated action.
εἰν ἀγορῇ, § 35.
18-25. See notes on parallel passage, B 111-118.
τότε refers to the occasion of the deceptive dream which Zeus sent to Agamemnon before the dawn a few days previous (B 8 ff.).
26-28. Agamemnon made this same proposal before the first day of battle, B 139-141. Then he spoke the words insincerely, to test his men's bravery; but now he speaks in good earnest.
ἥ agrees with the predicate noun qe/mis. In the assembly (a)gorh=|) there is equality of speech, for the heroes at least.

This disparagement of Diomedes's courage occurs in a speech of Agamemnon, in the course of the first day of battle (4.370-400). It begins
w)/ moi, *tude/os ui(e\ dai+/fronos i(ppoda/moio, ti/ ptw/sseis;
‘Ah me, son of the valiant knight Tydeus, why do you cower?’ But Agamemnon does not, in the passage referred to, actually use the words a)pto/lemon kai\ a)na/lkida (l. 35).

διάνδιχα, with one of two gifts, ‘by halves.’ Diomedes's taunt seems unjustifiable, for according to Helen's testimony (3.179) Agamemnon was a)mfo/teron, basileu/s t' a)gaqo\s kratero/s t' ai)xmhth/s, ‘both a good king and a brave fighter.’
ὅ τε, agreeing with predicate noun kra/tos.
δαιμόνι’(ε), cf. A 561.
ὥς τε (=Attic w(/ste) νέεσθαι, is set ‘on returning.’
πάρ, § 46. Supply e/sti/.
διαπέρσομεν, § § 143; 144, II.
With ei) de\ kai\ au)toi/ supply e)qe/lousi fugei=n.
φευγόντων, imperative. Compare Agamemnon's proposal, l. 27.
πέρι, adverb, ‘exceedingly.’
μετά, a rather remarkable use with the accusative. In Attic the genitive would follow.
ὅσσοι, supply ei)si/: ‘of all the Achaeans.’
πάλιν ἐρέει, ‘will gainsay.’

ἀτὰρ οὐ τέλος ἵκεο μύθων, ‘but you did not come to the completion of your speech’; you did not touch the really vital point, namely the quarrel between Achilles and Agamemnon, which has led to the present disasters. “And yet thou hast not gone so far, but we must further go” (Chapman).
κε ... εἴης, ‘you might be.’

The verse is bracketed, as not a part of the original poem, because the construction of two accusatives after ba/zeis is unusual (m' , *p 207, may stand for moi), and because the latter part of the line contains a weak repetition of l. 58.
ἐξείπω, § 191. Nestor promises that he will complete the unfinished speech of Diomedes.
ἀτιμήσει, with ke (l. 61), § 190.

οὐδὲ κρείων Ἀγαμέμνων, ‘not even lord Agamemnon.’ By these words Nestor makes it clear that what he has to add will be likely to irritate the king of Mycenae. He is hinting at the real cause of the recent calamities, the quarrel with Achilles. What he has to propose is a reconciliation between the two chiefs.
