Yet he will not humiliate Agamemnon by speaking out before the whole assembly, both chiefs and common soldiers. He proposes that Agamemnon give a dinner to the elders (l. 70), the preliminary of a council. Then, before this select body, he apportions the blame firmly (beginning with l. 96) and proposes the remedy. His tact and his years win Agamemnon's respect; and the king finally yields every point.

63, 64. These lines are bracketed, because probably not a part of the original poem. They seem like the interpolation of a later gnomic poet. In the present context, πολέμου ἐπιδημίοο (‘civil war’) must refer to the quarrel between Agamemnon and Achilles, and ἐκεῖνος, if applied to this concrete case, indicates Agamemnon.
ἐπιδημίοο, § 74.
λεξάσθων, from root lex, ‘lie’; ‘let them take their post.’
δαίνυ δαῖτα, ‘give a feast’ (cognate accusative).
εὐρέα, Attic eu)ru/n.
πολέσιν, § 106.
χρεώ, subject of a verb of motion like i(/kei understood.
Ἀχαιούς is a limit of motion.
ἐσθλῆς, supply boulh=s.
τίθεντο, ‘made ready for themselves.’
ἑτοῖμα, predicate adjective after προκείμενα, ‘lying ready before (them).

ἐν σοὶ μὲν λήξω, σέο δ’ ἄρξομαι. Compare Theocritus, Idyls, XVII, 1:
*)ek *dio\s a)rxw/mesqa kai\ e)s *di/a lh/gete, *moi=sai From Zeus let us begin, and with Zeus end, ye Muses.
θέμιστας, cf. A 238.
σφίσι, dative of advantage.
πέρι, ‘beyond others,’ ‘most of all.’
κρηῆναι δὲ καὶ ἄλλῳ κτλ., ‘and to falfil the words for another as well whenever the spirit bids anyone speak out for the common good.’ Supply ἔπος as object of krhh=nai.

σέο δ’ ἕξεται, ὅττι κεν ἄρχῃ, ‘whatever he proposes [or ‘initiates’] will depend upon you.’ Whatever any one else suggests will depend for its final execution on your will; and so the credit of it will redound to you.
ἐξ ἔτι τοῦ ὅτε, ‘even from the time when.’
Ἀχιλῆος depends on klisi/hqen.
‘Not at all with our approval.’ Recall Nestor's words, A 275, 276, and 282-284.
μάλα (l. 108) ... po/ll) (=polla/), ‘very earnestly.’
ψεῦδος, adverbial accusative, equivalent to yeudw=s, ‘falsely.’
ἀντί νυ πολλῶν ἀνδρῶν, ‘equal to many men,’ ‘a match for many men.’
φιλήσῃ, § 197.
ὀνομήνω, § 191.

ἀπύρους, ‘that fire has not yet touched,’ as is proved by 23.268.— A Homeric τάλαντον of gold was a weight much less in value than the Attic talent of silver; the latter was equivalent to about $1,080 in our money. The value of the Homeric talent, however, although it must have been vastly less than this, is unknown. Two talents of gold are mentioned as a fourth prize in connection with the chariot race, 23.269, while the third is a caldron untouched by fire, and the fifth an urn. What may be a similar caldron is mentioned, 23.885, as equivalent in value to an ox.
ἄροντο, ἄρνυμαι.
γένοιτο, protasis of the less vivid future condition.
τόσσα of this line is correlative with o(/ssa, l. 127.—Line 126, which awkwardly interrupts the construction, is rejected by some editors.
ἠνείκαντο, φέρω. Cf. e)nei/kw, Z 258.
αὐτός, Achilles.
ἐνίκων φῦλα γυναικῶν, ‘surpassed womankind,’ at the time of the division.

μέτα, ‘among them,’ counting as eighth, however, and not included in the seven, as is proved by T 246; further, the seven were Lesbians, while Briseis was from Lyrnessus, a town of Mysia (B 689, 690).
ἀπηύρων, § 63.4.
ἔπι, ‘besides.’
τῆς, equivalent to Attic au)th=s, ‘her,’ possessive genitive.

εἰσελθὼν κτλ.: as our text is punctuated, this may be taken to mean ‘entering into the council of chiefs, when we Achaeans apportion the booty.’ If a comma were placed after ei)selqw/n (the common punctuation), and that after nhhsa/sqw were removed, the participle might be taken with the preceding verb thus: ‘entering into the city, let him load his ship’ etc.
εἴ κεν followed by optative, of a remote future supposition, has been observed A 60 also; cf. § 208
Ἄργος ... Ἀχαιικόν, the Peloponnesus; see note on A 79.
οὖθαρ ἀρούρης, imitated in Vergil's “ubere glaebae,” Aen. I, 531, and III, 164; “divitis uber agri,” VII, 262.
τάων, genitive plural of h(/, § 115.

ἔπι, ‘besides.’ Not only may Achilles neglect the custom of making presents to the bride's father and so possess his bride free (a)na/ednon, l. 146), but Agamemnon will of his own accord give rich presents along with her as peace-offerings (mei/lia). See note on X 472.
νέαται (= Attic e)/sxatai) Πύλου, ‘on the borders of Pylos.’
τιμήσουσιν with κε, § 190.

τελέουσι, future indicative, § 151. The people will honor him, like a god, with offerings (dwti/nh|si, l. 155) of first-fruits, and they will pay rich taxes (lipara\s qe/mistas) imposed on them by royal command.
μεταλλήξαντι, i. e. meta/ + lh/canti, § 39.

δμηθήτω, δαμνάω or da/mnhmi. A scholiast calls attention to a similar passage from Aeschylus:
mo/nos qew=n ga\r *qa/natos ou) dw/rwn e)ra=|:
ou)d' a)/n ti qu/wn ou)d' e)pispe/ndwn a)/nois,
ou)d' e)/sti bwmo\s ou)de\ paiani/zetai:
mo/nou de\ *peiqw\ daimo/nwn a)postatei=. Fragment 161 (Wecklein)

‘For Death alone of the gods loves not offerings; nor by sacrifice nor by libation may you accomplish aught, nor has he altar nor is he hymned; and from him alone of divinities Persuasion holds aloof.’
Γερήνιος, see note on B 336.
διδοῖς § 132), ‘you offer.’
ὀτρύνομεν, aorist subjunctive § 144, II).
ἔλθως’(ι) with οἵ κε (l. 165) is a relative clause of purpose. The Attic equivalent is the relative with future indicative.
ἂν ... ἐπιόψομαι, § 190.

Φοῖνιξ, the old tutor of Achilles, who also commanded one of the five divisions of the Myrmidons (16.196). When Achilles refused to take further part in battle, his men shared his inactivity, however restive they may have been. Phoenix, though holding aloof from fighting, was doubtless keen to observe the progress of the battle; and for this purpose absenting himself from the quarters of the Myrmidons and the company of Achilles, he seems to have associated with the active chiefs, in council at least. So he was present at the feast of the elders. Whereupon Agamemnon availed himself of Phoenix's presence—whether this was accidental or not—to help the two envoys, Ajax and Odysseus. But Phoenix was distinctly not an envoy; he simply accompanied the envoys, as did the two heralds, Odius and Eurybates. The envoys are regularly spoken of as two (ll. 182, 185, 192, 196, 197). Achilles disregarded Phoenix's presence in his formal welcome to the two envoys (l. 197). The old man took a part in the interview, however (ll. 434 ff.), because he was a privileged person.
Many critics believe that the seeming inconsistencies show that the lines relating to Phoenix are interpolations of later times.
ἡγησάσθω, ‘lead the way.’

Odius, the herald, is not elsewhere mentioned. Of Eurybates it can hardly be believed that he is the same as the herald of Agamemnon who (A 320) was sent to take away Briseis and so would be particularly hateful to Achilles. The name is suggested by the herald's occupation and may well have been borne by different men. Odysseus had a herald named Eurybates also (B 184), who is very likely meant in this context.
φέρτε, § 131.
ἔπιον, πίνω.
Ὀδυσσῆι, with ἐπέτελλε (l. 179), on which πειρᾶν (l. 181) also depends: ‘enjoined earnestly [po/ll)] on them ... to try.’
παρὰ θῖνα, ‘along the strand’; cf. A 327.
γαιηόχῳ, ‘earth-holder,’ Poseidon is called—by identification with the sea, which seems to mariners to embrace the lands.
πόλιν Ἠετίωνος, cf. A 366.
κλέα, for kle/ea, which some editors write kle/e). Cf. duskle/a, l. 22.
ὁπότε, ‘until.’
ἡγεῖτο, Odysseus preceded Ajax.
αὐτῇ σὺν φόρμιγγι, ‘lyre and all.’

ἦ φίλοι κτλ., ‘right welcome men are you that have come—some great need surely must urge you—who of [all] the Achaeans are dearest to me, despite my wrath.’—With χρεώ (l. 197) supply i(ka/nei u(ma=s. A different interpretation is: ‘surely I have great need’ (of friends); the words supplied are then i(ka/nei me.
καθίστα, present imperative, Attic kaqi/sth.
ὑπέασι, Attic u(/peisi, from u(/peimi (ei)mi/).
κάββαλεν, ‘set down’; for the spelling cf. E 343.
ἐν πυρὸς αὐγῇ, ‘in the bright light of the fire.’ It will be recalled that the embassy occurs in the evening; and perhaps all the light in the hut is furnished by this fire.
τῷ, ‘for him,’ Achilles.
μέγα, ‘to a large flame.’
κατὰ ... ἐκάη, tmesis.
213, 214. ‘He spread out the glowing embers and extended the spits over them; and he sprinkled all with holy salt, resting the spits on the supporting stones.’
ἁλός, genitive of material. The salt is said to be called ‘holy’ because of its preservative power.
τοίχου τοῦ ἑτάροιο, ‘by the opposite wall,’ a genitive of place.
The envoys had just feasted with Agamemnon (l. 177); so it may be inferred that these formulary lines mean that they ate only so much now as courtesy demanded.
δείδεκτ’(ο) (for de/dvekto?) from deidi/skomai (dedvi/skomai?), ‘pledged.’
χαῖρ’ Ἀχιλεῦ, ‘your health, Achilles!’
ἐπιδευεῖς, predicate adjective after e)sme/n understood.
Odysseus purposely mentions the name of Achilles's great enemy at the outset: he hints that they were sent by him, although, for fear of a rebuff, he does not openly say so.
ἠμὲν ... ἠδέ (l. 227)=kai\ ... kai/.
πάρα γὰρ κτλ., ‘for there are set forth many satisfying viands to feast upon.’
δαίνυσθ’(αι), infinitive of purpose.
μέμηλεν, supply h(mi=n.
μέγα πῆμα ... εἰσοράοντες, ‘looking on the great distress.’
δείδιμεν=de/dvimen, § 62.1.
ἐν δοιῇ, supply e)sti/: ‘it is uncertain whether the ships be safe or perish.’
Achilles may well feel that his prayer (A 408, 409) is being realized.
αὖλιν, perhaps originally au)/lid'(a), but made to conform to ordinary Attic usage § 80). Classical Greek had a verb from this word, au)li/zomai, familiar in Xenophon's Anabasis.

οὐδ’ ἔτι φασὶν σχήσεσθ’(αι), ‘and they say they will no longer be restrained’; in the Greek idiom the negative precedes fhmi/. Cf. Xen. Anab. I, 3, 1: oi( ga\r stratiw=tai ou)k e)/fasan i)e/nai tou= pro/sw.
236, 237. The lightnings of Zeus, propitious to the Trojans, and the confidence of Hector are told of in the preceding book (8.75, 133, 141, 170, 175).
πυρός, cf. B 415.
ὀρινομένους, ‘stirred out’ like wasps, says a scholiast.
δείδοικα=de/dvoika. Cf. dei/dimen, l. 230.
ἤῃ, present subjunctive, third singular, of ei)mi/, a conjectural form for the MS. ei)/h.
ἄνα, cf. Z 331.
καὶ ὀψέ περ, ‘late as it is.’ It will be recalled that there have been but two days of battle included in the time since Achilles withdrew.

ἐρύεσθαι: if a nice distinction be drawn between e)ru^/w, ‘drag,’ and r(u_/omai, ‘preserve,’ ‘save,’ the spelling here should be r(u_/esqai, which some editors introduce. Compare r(u_si/ptoli (or e)rusi/ptoli), Z 305.—u(po/= ‘from under.’
οὐ δέ τι μῆχος κτλ., ‘and there is no means to find a cure for mischief once done.’
ἔστ’ may represent e)/sti or e)/stai.
ὦ πέπον, ‘dear friend.’ Cf. the different sense, B 235.
Nestor and Odysseus went to Phthia to persuade Peleus to allow Achilles to go to the Trojan war (cf. H 127, 11.765-784). On that occasion Peleus is supposed to have spoken the words quoted here.
ἔριδος, ‘strife,’ but not, of course, with reference to any particular occasion. Achilles's high-strung temperament was known to his father.
παύἐ (pau/eo): this MS. reading is significant. For consistency's sake, fra/zeu in l. 251 should read fra/ze), since the formation of the two words is identical. The principle has wide application.
δίδωσι, ‘offers’; cf. l. 164, didoi=s.
εἰ δέ, interjectional, like a)/ge dh/. A probable emendation is ei)=a. Cf. A 302.
καταλέξω, with ke, aorist subjunctive, § 192.
κλισίῃσιν, the plural indicates that Agamemnon's lodge contained more than one room.
264-299. Repeated with necessary changes of person from ll. 122-157.
ἀπηύρα, § 63.4.
νηήσασθαι, § 213.
ἄγεσθαι, § 213.
‘And if the son of Atreus has become too hateful to you, in your heart—himself and his gifts—yet do you have pity for the rest of the Achaeans, at least.’
μᾶλλον with ἀπήχθετο signifies ‘too hateful’ for you to forgive and forget.
κηρόθι, § 155.3.

δ’=de/: such a clause as the present is commonly considered a relic of the old paratactic construction; but it is probably better to regard de/ as equivalent in force to a weakened dh/, not as a conjunction. Cf. A 58, 137.
Παναχαιούς, cf. modern “Pan-American.”
σφι=para\ (or e)k) pa/ntwn, ‘in the esteem of all.’

A summary of the points made by Odysseus: (1) The danger of the ships is emphasized (ll. 231, 232, 235, 241); (2) Achilles is reminded of the parting words of his father Peleus and urged to be reasonable and gentle (ll. 252, 255, 256, 260); (3) Agamemnon's offer of gifts to effect a reconciliation is dwelt on at length (ll. 263-299), although it is not stated that Agamemnon is in any way sorry for the injury done to Achilles; (4) a plea for pity of the Greeks follows (l. 300), in close connection with which is (5) a suggestion how Achilles may win great glory (l. 303); and (6) an attempt is made to arouse his jealousy of Hector's success (ll. 304306).
‘I must speak out my will unreservedly.’ In these words Achilles foreshadows his own unfavorable reply.
ἄλλοθεν ἄλλος, Latin aliunde alius.

‘As hateful as the gates of Hades’ expressed to Achilles hatefulness in the superlative degree. Hades was most hateful of all the gods to mortals (l. 159), because through his gates the dead must pass. ‘Hateful as black death’ is the expression in 3.454.
ὅς χ’ ἕτερον μὲν κεύθῃ ... ἄλλο δὲ εἴπῃ, ‘who hides one thing [i. e. the true feeling] ... and says another.’

p.lemma: ἐπεὶ οὐκ ἄρα τις χάρις ἦεν

p.l: μάρνασθαι, ‘since, as now appears [a)/ra], there is no gratitude for fighting.’ See note on 3.183.

div2.p: 318-320. ‘An equal share [of booty] falls to him who stays behind and to him who may battle ever so hard, and in equal honor are held both the coward and the brave man too. The man of no deeds and the man of many deeds die alike.’—By μένοντι (l. 318) and κακός (l. 319) Achilles alludes to Agamemnon, who he distinctly says (l. 332) stays behind.— Instead of εἰ μάλα τις πολεμίζοι (l. 318), ma/la polemi/zonti would form a natural antithesis to me/nonti.—For ἰῇ see § 108.1.
This line looks like the interpolation of a gnomic poet. Compare ll. 63 and 64.
οὐδέ τί μοι περίκειται, ‘nor is aught more [peri/] gained for me,’ ‘it profits me nothing.’
πολεμίζειν, infinitive of purpose.
προφέρῃσιν, § 197.
μάστακ̓, generally understood as ma/staka, accusative singular, in a meaning (peculiar to this place) of ‘food.’
κακῶς δέ τέ οἱ πέλει αὐτῇ, ‘although it fares ill with her herself’ (oi( au)th=|).
ἴαυον, ‘passed’ sleepless nights.

πολεμίζων κτλ., ‘warring against men that fought in defense of their wives.’ The dative (as here, a)ndra/si, l. 327) after verbs of fighting denotes the enemy. Homeric men who defended their cities against invaders knew that if defeated they should be slain, while their wives and children would be enslaved.
μαρναμένοις, an emendation of the MS. marna/menos.
πεζός, ‘on land.’
δόσκον, § 154.
ὃ δ’ ὄπισθε μένων, an imputation of cowardice.
διὰ ... δασάσκετο, tmesis.
γέρα^, neuter plural; observe the short ultima; it occars also B 237.
εἵλετ’(ο), supply as object ‘my prize,’ i. e. Briseis.—‘But he has a wife,’ already, adds Achilles, alluding to Clytaemnestra, whom Agamemnon, when sailing to Troy, left behind in Mycenae.
ἄλοχος appears always to be used by Homer of a wedded wife: so it fits Clytaemnestra, but does not apply to Briseis, unless its use in this instance be extraordinary.

ἀνήγαγεν, ‘led up,’ said of the journey from Greece ‘up’ to Troy. Agamemnon is greatly in the wrong: although waging this war on account of Helen, stolen away by Paris, he himself has committed as grievous an offense as Paris. Does he think Paris's act a crime, and his own insignificant? Or does he think that Atreus's sons alone of mortal men hold their wives of value?
ὅς τις, supply e)sti/.
τὴν αὐτοῦ, ‘his own wife.’
καὶ ἄλλοισιν βασιλεῦσιν may be a bitter allusion to Agamemnon's own words, A 174.
φραζέσθω, ‘let him consider how,’ with infinitive.
νήεσσι, dative of interest (advantage).
δήιον, scansion, § 28.
ἤλασε τάφρον, ‘ran a ditch.’ Cf. note on A 575.

μετ’ Ἀχαιοῖσιν, ‘amid the Achaeans.’ Achilles was indeed a ‘great bulwark’ for the Achaeans, when he was fighting, as Nestor truly said (A 284). He was greater than the wall and moat which unsuccessfully served as a defense in his absence.
ἀπὸ τείχεος, ‘away from the city wall.’
ὅσον, ‘only so far as.’
φηγόν, see note on Z 237.
As object of ἔμιμνε supply me, with which οἶον agrees.

εὖ, cf. a(/lis, l. 279, to which it is similar in meaning.—After προερύσσω, Achilles would regularly continue with an expression like pleu/somai, ‘I shall sail,’ with the subject of which the participles r(e/cas (l. 357) and nhh/sas (l. 358) would agree. Instead, the construction abruptly changes.
ἔπ’(ι), ‘over’ the Hellespont.

ἤματι ... τριτάτῳ, compare the account in the Cypria (note on Z 292), which gave the voyage from Sparta to Troy as three days long, in fair weather. Diomedes voyages from Troy to Argos in four days (Od. 3.180). Cf. also Xen. Hellenica, II, 1, 30.
ἐνθάδε ἔρρων, ‘on my sorry voyage hither.’ The verb implies that the journey was attended with misfortune.
365 ἄλλον, ‘besides.’
367-369. ‘But my prize even he who gave took from me again with in sult—lord Agamemnon Atrides. To him tell § 213] all.’
αἰὲν ἀναιδείην ἐπιειμένος, cf. A 149.—οὐ δ’ ἂν ἐμοί γε κτλ., but though he be ever so shameless, he would not dare to look me [emphatic, as ge shows] in the face.’
ἐκ (‘utterly’) ... ἀπάτησε, tmesis.

μ’(ε) is to be taken with h)/liten as well as with a)pa/thse. Agamemnon deceived Achilles by proving false in friendship.—The ancient commentators call attention to the short sentences and broken lines, 375-378, which mark Achilles's intense nature.
ἅλις δέ οἱ, supply e)sti/: ‘)tis enough for him [to have tricked me thus far].’
ἕκηλος ἐρρέτω, ‘let him go to his ruin undisturbed.’ Cf. l. 364.
τε καί ‘or even.’
ὅσσα τε, § 123.3.
καὶ εἴ ποθεν ἄλλα γένοιτο, ‘and if from some source he should get wealth besides.’

οὐδ’ ὅσα, ‘not even if he should offer me as much wealth as’: between ou)d' and o(/sa there must be understood ei) to/sa doi/h from l. 379. The wealth is thought of as tribute from subject lands. Orchomenus was the rich city of the Minyans in Boeotia—seat of the Graces, as Pindar sings.
Αἰγυπτίας, in scansion either the antepenult must be treated as short, or -ias must be pronounced as one syllable (yas) by synizesis.
ἑκατόμπυλοι, a “round” number, not necessarily exact.
ἑκάστας, with pu/las understood from the preceding adjective. A city “gate” is regularly plural in Homer, consisting, as it did, of two folding leaves. Cf. *skaia\s pu/las, l. 354.

πρίν γ’ ἀπὸ ... δόμεναι, ‘before he atones for.’ Achilles plainly did not want gifts from Agamemnon; the only real satisfaction that he could have was the utter humiliation of the king. This is why he asked his mother Thetis to persuade Zeus (in A) to send victory to the Trojans and defeat to the Achaeans; this is what he accomplished when (in O) the very ships of the Achaeans were threatened with fire.
γαμέω, future, § 151.

Aristarchus's reading gunai=ka/ ge ma/ssetai, ‘shall seek out a wife,’ instead of the vulgate γυναῖκα γαμέσσεται, ‘shall marry a wife to me,’ has the advantage of avoiding the infrequent feminine caesura of the fourth foot § 21).
398-400. ‘And there my manly heart was right well inclined to marry a wedded wife, a fitting mate, and to enjoy the possessions that aged Peleus had amassed.’
γήμαντι agrees with μοι (l. 398). The time referred to in e)pe/ssnto is prior to the Trojan war.
ἀντάξιον, predicate adjective with e)sti/ understood; the plural adjective might be expected, agreeing with to/sa understood (antecedent of o(/sa. ll. 401 and 404).

ἐκτῆσθαι, ‘used to possess,’ represents e)/kthto of direct discourse. The great wealth of Troy ‘in time of peace’ (e)p' ei)rh/nhs) is elsewhere (18.288, 289, 24.543) referred to; but the treasures became greatly depleted in purchase of provisions from abroad during the long siege (18.292).
πρι^̀ν ... πρι_́ν, § 30.
ἐέργει, ‘encloses.’
Πυθοῖ, later Delphi, famous for rich offerings. In later days Herodotus tells how Croesus, for example (Herod. I, 50, 51), made magnificent presents to Delphi, as to the only true oracle.
ληιστοί, supply ei)si/.
409. A literal translation: ‘but a man's spirit may be neither won as spoil nor caught, so as to return again, when [once] it has passed the barrier of the teeth.’
ἐλθέμεν, syntax, § 212.
λεϊστή is only another spelling of lhi+sth/, on which see § 28, § 29.
The spirit of life is thought to pass out through the mouth at death. Pope renders freely ll. 401-409:

Life is not to be bought with heaps of gold; Not all Apollo's Pythian treasures hold, Or Troy once held, in peace and pride of sway, Can bribe the poor possession of a day! Lost herds and treasures we by arms regain, And steeds unrivall'd on the dusty plain: But from our lips the vital spirit fled, Returns no more to wake the silent dead.
με is object of fere/men (l. 411).
ὤλετο, ‘is lost,’ emphatic conclusion of future condition.
For long syllable before dhro/n see § § 37; 62, 2.

This line, which is but a weak repetition, was omitted by Zenodotus and rejected by Aristarchus. The interpolator evidently did not feel the force of e)/stai (l. 413), which is understood also at the end of l. 415.
The meaning is: ‘since there is no longer hope that you will gain the goal [i. e. ‘the overthrow’] of lofty Troy.’
δήετε, cf. note on 16.852.
ἑθεν, § 110.
γέρας, ‘meed,’ ‘honorable service.’
σαῷ, subjunctive, contracted from sao/h|, like gnw=| (A 411) for gno/h|- The clause expresses purpose.
ἥδε [mh=tis], i. e. the attempt to persuade me to return to active warfare.
ἐμεῦ ἀπομηνίσαντος, ‘while I have given way to wrath, apart from my comrades’ (a)po-), or perhaps simply ‘during the outburst of my wrath.

From the long speech of Achilles (ll. 307-429) one gets much insight into his character. He is high-mettled, and can not endure to be called second to anybody; he is far from mercenary, putting honor far above riches; on the other hand, he is unforgiving, treasuring an insult to himself until his enemy shall have drained his cup of bitterness to the last drop. It was not the loss of Briseis, of course, that wounded him so much as the sting to his pride inflicted by Agamemnon's act.

The more impassioned the speech, the less it yields to so concise analysis as is possible in the case of Odysseus's (note on l. 306). While Achilles heeds most of Odysseus's arguments, he does not answer them quite in order. To the words of Odysseus about the danger of the ships, he retorts that Agamemnon may consult with Odysseus and the rest of the princes how best to ward off the hostile fire (ll. 346, 347). He does not notice at all the reference to his father's words that reminded him to be of gentle character. The gifts—a chief inducement in Odysseus's speech—he emphatically rejects (ll. 378-387), and with them the offer of Agamemnon's daughter in marriage (ll. 388-391). Already he has stated that he has gained enough (ll. 365-367); with this he will load his ships (l. 358). he says, in answer to Agamemnon's invitation to share in a future division of the spoil of Troy (ll. 277-282); in Phthia, his home, he will seek a wife (ll. 394-397), and there already Peleus has acquired property for him (l. 400). He nowhere shows signs of pity for the distress of the Greeks (cf. ll. 315, 316); he actually advises them to go home (ll. 417-420), alluding effectively to the words of Odysseus that Zeus manifestly favors the Trojans (ll. 236-238). As for winning great glory, great indeed is the cost (ll. 401-416), and in how unworthy a cause (ll. 337-343)! About the present success of Hector he cares just enough to remind the king that so long as he—Achilles—had a part in fighting, wall and moat were unnecessary (ll. 348-352) and Hector was far less venturesome (ll. 352-355).
εἰ μὲν δὴ κτλ., ‘if then you are really planning to return.’
λιποίμην, with passive sense, § 185.

σοὶ δέ μ’ ἔπεμπε, ‘bade me accompany you’: soi/ is a dative of advantage, ‘sent me along for you.’ So the words seem to have been understood by Cicero who instances (De Oratore, III, 15, 57) “ille apud Homerum Phoenix, qui se a Peleo patre Achilli iuveni comitem esse datum dicit ad bellum, ut efficeret oratorem verborum actoremque rerum” (‘the well-known Phoenix in Homer, who says he was given by father Peleus to the young Achilles for his companion in arms, to make him a speaker of words and a doer of deeds’).
νήπιον κτλ., ‘a young lad, not yet familiar with leveling war nor with discussions [a)gore/wn, l. 441] in the assembly.’
πολέμοιο, syntax, § 174 (4).
ἵνα, ‘where,’ relative adverb.
445, 446. The sense is: ‘not even if a god should promise to smooth away the wrinkles of my old age, and make me young, in manhood's bloom.’
Ἑλλάδα, see note on A 79.
ἄναχθ’=a)/nakta.
ὡς εἴ τε, ‘like as.’
πολλοῖσιν ἐπὶ κτεάτεσσιν, ‘guardian of his great possessions’: w(=n ... sunh/gagen ... fu/laka (scholium). On this use of e)pi/ cf. Z 424, 18.529.
καί σε τοσοῦτον ἔθηκα, ‘and I made you what you are.’
488, 489. ‘Until I seated you on my knees and fed you with dainty food, carving for you first, and pressing the wine to [your lips].’
ὄψου is partitive genitive.—The dainty food may have been such as Astyanax had (X 500, 501), ‘who, seated on his father's knees, ate only marrow and rich fat of sheep.’
οἴνου, in construction like u)/you, l. 489.
ὅ=ὅτι, § 123.7. The gods granted no offspring to Phoenix in consequence of his father's curses.
οὐδέ τί σε χρή, ‘it befits you not.’

502-512. The allegory of the Suppliant Prayers. In the *litai/ Phoenix covertly alludes to Agamemnon, who, he suggests, is now penitent. Agamemnon was misguided and sinned, as in fact he himself confessed (l. 119), though not to Achilles. Now he makes full atonement. If Achilles will accept the atonement, he will be benefited thereby; if he spurns it, he will put himself in the wrong, becoming subject to the same sin of arrogance which before seized Agamemnon. And in his turn he will pay the penalty. The Prayers are appropriately called ‘daughters of Zeus,’ since Zeus is the god and protector of suppliants (Od. 9.270).

As suggested by the scholia: the Prayers are called ‘lame’ because men come haltingly to ask forgiveness; ‘wrinkled,’ because the faces of the penitents express sorrow; ‘downcast in gaze,’ because they can not look straight at those whom they have wronged.
ἀλέγουσι κιοῦσαι, ‘anxiously go.’

Ἄτη is sinful arrogance, blindness of heart, described T 91-94:
pre/sba *dio\s quga/thr *)/ath, h)\ pa/ntas a)a=tai.
ou)lome/nh: th=| me/n q' a(paloi\ po/des: ou) ga\r e)p' ou)/dei
pi/lnatai, a)ll' a)/ra h(/ ge kat' a)ndrw=n kra/ata bai/nei
bla/ptous' a)nqrw/pous: kata\ d' ou)=n e(/tero/n ge pi/dhsen.

‘August daughter of Zeus is Ate, who deludes all men. Hurtful one! Soft indeed are her feet, for she moves not on the ground, but over men's heads she walks, blinding mankind; and of two one at least she takes in her toils.’ Cf. Proverbs xvi, 18: “Pride goeth before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.” An example was Uzziah (II Chronicles xxvi, 16): “But when he was strong, his heart was lifted up to his destruction.”
οὕνεκα, in sense of tou)/neka.—With πάσας supply *lita/s.
αἳ δ’ ἐξακέονται ὀπίσσω, “while Prayers, to heal her wrongs, move slow behind” (Pope).
δέ, cf. l. 301.
ὤνησαν, ἔκλυον, § 184.—510. ἀνήνηται, ἀναίνομαι.
They pray ‘that Ate may overtake him so that he may be blinded in mind and pay the penalty.’
πόρε, with timh\n e(/pesqai ktl. as object, ‘grant that respect attend.’
‘Pay such respect to the daughters of Zeus as bends the minds of other men, noble as they are,’ to yield to Prayers.
515-517. A present contrary to fact condition, expressed in terms of the less vivid future, § 207.1.
νῦν δ’(έ), ‘but as it is.’
διδοῖ, see note on l. 164.

τῶν μὴ σύ γε κτλ., ‘do you not throw reproach on their words or on their coming [po/das] hither. But your anger before this was no cause for blame at all.’ The latter implies a converse statement: to continue in anger now, after the supplication of Agamemnon, does deserve reproach.
μή τοι ταῦτα νόει, i. e. like Meleager.
ἐνταῦθα, i. e. to such an extremity of obstinacy as is seen in the story of Meleager.
φίλος, § 169.
ἐπὶ δώροις, ‘on condition of the gifts.’
τιμῇς, commonly explained as equivalent to timh/eis, ‘honored.’
χρεώ, supply i(ka/nei, or i(/kei, as l. 75.
Διὸς αἵσῃ, ‘by the award [or ‘allotment’] of Zeus,’ by the fortune that Zeus has meted to me.

Cf. Verg. Aen. IV, 360:
Desine meque tuis incendere teque querellis.
‘No more vex thee and me with thy complaints.’
καλόν [e)sti], ‘it is right.’
κηδέμεν, ‘to injure.’
λέξεο, § 153.
ἅμα δ’ ἠόι § 92) φαινομένηφιν § 155.1), ‘at daybreak.’
νόστοιο μεδοίατο, ‘might bethink themselves to go.’ This was a suggestion to Odysseus and Ajax that it was useless for them to tarry longer.
μύθοιο τελευτή, i. e. the object of our mission.
ἕαται, § 142.4, b.
θέτο, ‘has made.’
σχέτλιος, ‘implacable!’ § 170.—οὐδὲ μετατρέπεται κτλ., ‘nor does he even heed the love of his comrades—that love with which we honored him’ etc.
νηλής, ‘unpitying!’
κασιγνήτοιο φονῆος ποινήν, ‘pay from the murderer of a brother’: para\ fonh=os, in Attic. poinh/ of this sort is the Anglo-Saxon wergild.
ἢ [ποινὴν] οὗ παιδὸς ... τεθνηῶτος, ‘or pay for his own son slain.’

παιδός is objective genitive. This primitive custom of indemnity for manslaughter is alluded to also 18.497-500. If not allowed to make this atonement, the guilty man had to flee the land. See Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiquities, p. 407.
ἐδέξατο, § 184.
ὃ μέν, ‘the slayer.’
τοῦ δέ ... κραδίη, ‘while the heart of the other,’ i. e. the brother or father of the slain man.
Ajax, who before has been addressing Odysseus, now turns directly to Achilles, with soi\ d' a)/llhkto/n te ktl.
637, 638. Ajax either fails to understand or ignores the fact that Achilles is angry on account of his wounded honor, not on account of the loss of Briseis alone.
ἐπί, ‘in addition to.’
σὺ δ’ ἵλαον ἔνθεο θυμόν, ‘then do you make the spirit in your breast gracious.’ Ajax speaks to Achilles as to a god.
αἴδεσσαι δὲ μέλαθρον, ‘and respect the roof’ that shelters us. Cf. l. 204. We are your guests, Ajax means; then show us the respect that is our due, by yielding to us.
δέ (after u(pwro/fioi)=ga/r.
ὅσσοι, cf. l. 55.

The force of τι is very important: ‘to a certain extent you have seemed to speak everything in harmony with my own desire.’ But Achilles can not forgive Agamemnon, for all the pleading. And now the very thought of him calls forth another burst of anger. Attention is called, in the scholia, to Achilles's change of attitude in the course of this interview: to Odysseus he said that he should said for home the next morning (ll. 357-361); and this is what Odysseus later reported to Agamemnon (ll. 682, 683, 690-692); to Phoenix he said that he would take into consideration the matter of going or staying (ll. 618, 619); and to Ajax he intimates that he will fight against the Trojans when dire necessity forces him (ll. 650655).
646-648. ὁππότ’ ἐκείνων μνήσομαι κτλ., ‘whenever I recall those deeds, how Atreus's son did me outrage in the presence of the Argives, as if I were some honorless outlander.’
ἀσύφηλον, translated ‘outrage,’ is doubtful in respect to meaning.
μετανάστην = Attic me/toikon. The South African Uitlander (outlander) affords a suggestive modern instance of the prejudice against the intruding foreigner.
τῇ ἐμῇ κλισίῃ, ‘this lodge of mine.’
παρὰ νῆας, cf. A 327.

While Scyros is still understood by some, as it was in ancient times, to have been a city of Phrygia, it is also identified with the island of that name. Accepting it as the well-known island, a scholiast relates that Achilles captured Scyros when the army was mustering at Aulis, because Dolopians were there who had revolted from the rule of Peleus; and he distributed the spoil among his companions in arms. Here too he became the father of Neoptolemus. According to this account, Achilles visited Scyros first when a warrior in full armor; and the later story of his rearing there was unknown to Homer. Later in the poem Achilles refers to his son Neoptolemus growing up in Scyros (T 326-333). And Neoptolemus is mentioned in the Odyssey as well, when Odysseus says he brought him away from Scyros (Od. 11.509).
δειδέχατ’(ο), § 142.4, c; cf. note on l. 224.
μ̓=moi.
Cf. l. 347 for Achilles's own words.

ἂν ... παραμυθήσασθαι, indirect form of a)\n ... paramuqhsai/mhn, l. 417. This is the only example in Homer of a)/n with infinitive of indirect discourse.—For ll. 684-687, cf. ll. 417-420. It is noticeable that Odysseus reports from Achilles only what Achilles said directly to him, and passes over what was said to Phoenix and to Ajax; see note on l. 645.
εἰσί, ‘are here.’
εἰπέμεν § 212), ‘to tell,’ ‘to confirm.’
This verse was rejected by the Alexandrians; it is probably introduced from elsewhere (cf. 8.29), and in this context is inappropriate.
μηδ’ ὄφελες λίσσεσθαι, ‘would that you had not besought’; a wish impossible of fulfilment.
διδούς, ‘offering.’
καὶ ἄλλως, ‘even as it is.’

‘Now you have urged him far more to haughty thoughts.’ Chapman translates:
He's proud enough beside,
But this ambassage thou hast sent will make him burst with pride.
κεῖνον ... ἐάσομεν, ‘let us leave him alone’; but the verb may be future indicative.
ἤ ... ἤ, ‘whether ... or.’—On κε with subjunctive see § 192.
τεταρπόμενοι, τέρπω, § 128: ‘having got enjoyment,’ ‘satisfied.’
τὸ γὰρ κτλ., ‘for this [i. e. food and drink] is might’ etc.
ἐχέμεν § 213), ‘marshal.’
λείουσιν, Attic le/ousin, from le/wn.

p.l: Ἀργεΐων, ‘and charmed [“quenched,” Chapman] the spirit of the Argives.’

div2.p: τοὺς δ’ (έ), the Trojans.
Πριαμίδῃ, in apposition to *)/ektori (l. 596), and in emphatic position.
Θέτιδος δ’ ἐξαίσιον ἀρὴν κτλ., ‘and might fulfil the unjust [“merciless,” Voss] prayer of Thetis to the utmost’ (pa=san).
ἐξαίσιον= ‘exceeding proper measure.’ The point of view of the poet is characteristically Greek.
τὸ ... μένε, ‘was waiting for this.’ The next line is an appositive to to/.

παλίωξιν παρὰ νηῶν ... Τρώων, ‘a rout [‘pursuit back’] of the Trojans from the ships.’ This is the phrase seen in the title of the present book (occurring l. 69 also); yet it is not strictly correct, for the rout does not begin until the next book.
θησέμεναι, ‘to make, ‘to cause.’
βαθέης, Attic baqei/as.
ἀμφί, adverb, § 168.

Lines 610-614 have from ancient times been suspected as an interpolation. They match the present context badly, for Zeus is known to be on Mount Ida, while a)p' ai)qe/ros (l. 610) implies Olympus; the expression pleo/nessi ... mou=non e)o/nta (l. 611) is scarcely intelligible; further the cause here given for honoring Hector, minunqa/dios ... e)/ssesq' (ll. 612 f.), is at variance with the reasons already introduced (ll. 596-599).
ἐπώρνυε, a thematic formation for e)pw/rnu § 132): ‘let approach.’

ἴσχον γὰρ πυργηδὸν ἀρηρότες, ‘for they stood firm supporting one another [literally ‘fitted’] like a tower,’ i. e. in solid array. The simile beginning h)u/te pe/trh is imitated by Vergil (Aen. X, 693-696):
... velut rupes, vastum quae prodit in aequor,
obvia ventorum furiis expostaque ponto,
vim cunctam atque minas perfert caelique marisque,
ipsa immota manens.
‘Even as a rock that projects into the measureless sea, facing the raging winds and exposed to the deep, firmly meets all the violent menaces of heaven and sea, staying fast itself.’
μένει ... λαιψηρὰ κέλευθα, ‘firmly meets the swift assaults.’
λαμπόμενος πυρί, ‘gleaming with fire,’ in reference to the shining bronze armor.
δεινός must here be considered an adjective of two endings, one form serving for both masculine and feminine. The MSS. commonly read a)h/ths, masculine, however.
τυτθόν, ‘by a little,’ ‘narrowly.’
Neither ὅ γ’(ε) nor λέων has a finite verb. le/wn is taken up in o(\ de/ (l. 635); while o(/ g'(e) recurs as *(/ektori (l. 637). The translation should supply verbs where the English idiom demands.
‘And among them is a herdsman that does not yet clearly know how to cope with a wild beast about the slaying of a crumpled-horned cow’; i. e. to prevent the slaying.
ὃ μέν, the herdsman.
ὁμοῦ στιχάει, ‘walks with,’ or ‘along with.’
ὑπέτρεσαν, gnomic aorist.
ἐφόβηθεν, ‘fled,’ as regularly in Homer.
ἀγγελίην is cognate accusative after oi)/xneske.

βίῃ Ἡρακληείῃ is a periphrasis for ‘mighty Heracles.’ Translate, ‘used to go on the mission of lord Eurystheus to mighty Heracles.’ Eurystheus, fearing to meet Heracles personally, communicated with him through Copreus.

πατρὸς ... χείρονος is in apposition to tou=: literally ‘from him, a much worse father, he was born a better son.’ Pope paraphrases:
The son redeem'd the honours of the race,
A son as generous as the sire was base.
μάχεσθαι, infinitive of specification, equivalent to ma/xhn. Cf. A 258.
ἐτέτυκτο (teu/xw) = h)=n.

στρεφθεὶς ... μετόπισθεν, ‘as he turned back’ in flight to the ships. To understand how it was possible for Periphetes to trip on his shield, the great shield of the Mycenaean type must be called to mind; cf. Introduction, 23.
Periphetes was indeed a warrior “at mischief taken” (cf. Dryden's Palamon and Arcite, III. 516); but he was not therefore spared by Hector, for this was no tournament of jousting knights.
ἑταίρου, genitive of cause.
δείδισαν, for de/dvisan, § 62.1.

653-656. Three points in the flight of the Achaeans are pictured: driven before Hector they had turned their backs on the Trojans; (1) now ‘they had come to be face to face with their ships’ (l. 653); (2) now ‘the foremost ships, the first that were hauled up, compassed them about,’ and as they were streaming between them, ‘the Trojans poured in after them’ (l. 654); (3) now ‘they retreated from the foremost ships by necessity and grouped themselves near the huts’ (ll. 655, 656). It is generally understood that the ships were hauled up in several long rows, ranged one behind another.
ἔσχεθον, § 154.2.
τοὶ δ’(έ), the Trojans.
τῶν πρωτέων § 70) agrees with new=n, l. 655, genitive of separation The same ships are denoted as by a)/krai nh=es above (ll. 653 f.).
ὑπὲρ τοκέων, ‘in behalf of [i. e. ‘by’] his parents,’ with gounou/menos Compare toke/wn with tokh/wn (l. 663), the same word; § 29.
αἰδόα, declined like h)w/s, § 92.

ἐπί, ‘besides.’ The sentiment is imitated by Vergil (Aen. X, 280 282):
Nunc coniugis esto quisque suae tectique memor,
nunc magna referto facta, patrum laudes.
‘Now let every man remember his wife and his home, now let him recall the mighty deeds that gave his fathers glory.’
ὅτεῳ § 124) and ᾧ are datives of interest (advantage or disadvantage). The idea is, do all of you remember, ‘both the man whose parents yet live, and the man whose parents are dead.’
ὅττεῳ, two syllables, § 43.
τῶν ὕπερ κτλ., ‘I here beseech you by those that are not with us.’
ὦσεν, cf. A 220. No previous mention has been made of a cloud surrounding the Greeks.
πρός, ‘in the direction of.’
ἐφράσσαντο (from fra/zomai), ‘they saw.’
ἴκρι’(α), the Homeric ship had small decks fore and aft only.

ἀνήρ lacks a finite verb; so ὡς δ’ ὅτ’(ε), which literally would be rendered ‘and as [happens] when,’ must here be translated simply ‘like.’ —The idea is, like a skilful horseman Ajax leaped from deck to deck.
πολέων, § 106.
πίσυρας § 108.4), a relic of Aeolic influence.
συναείρεται, aorist subjunctive, ‘has hitched together.’
θηήσαντο, gnomic aorist § 184).

ὃ δ’ ἔμπεδον κτλ., ‘while he with steady poise [e)/mpedon] and sure feet [a)sfale/s] continually vaults [qrw/|skwn] from horse to horse in succession [a)mei/betai], as they course along.’ The horseman is imagined as standing all the time.
ὀρνίθων πετεηνῶν, with e)/qnos (l. 691).
‘So Hector rushed straight toward a dark-prowed ship, dashing against it.’
νεός is a variety of partitive genitive.
φαίης κ’(ε), ‘you would have thought’ § 207).

Τρωσὶν δ’ ἔλπετο θυμός means ‘the Trojans' spirit hoped’; then e(ka/stou, a possessive genitive with sth/qessin, is added, regardless of the preceding *trwsi/n. ‘Each man of the Trojans cherished in his breast the hope.’
Πρωτεσίλαον, the first of the Achaeans to land from his ship on Trojan soil (B 698, 702). He was slain by a Dardanian as soon as he set foot on the shore.
τόξων=toceuma/twn.
ἀικάς belongs to a)ko/ntwn as well as to to/cwn.
ἀμφίς, ‘at a distance from one another,’ in contrast with e)ggu/qen i(sta/menoi (l. 710).
711, 712. πέλεκυς, an axe or hatchet, often double-edged, commonly used for cutting and hewing wood (cf. 3.60 f., 16.483, 484).
ἀξίνη, ‘battleaxe.’
ξίφος (like fa/sganon, cf. l. 713), ‘sword.’
ἔγχος ἀμφίγυον, commonly explained as ‘double-headed spear,’ one end of which was used for thrusting, the other for fixing the spear in the ground (cf. 3.135) when it was not in use.

ἄλλα ... ἄλλα, ‘some’ ... ‘others,’ in apposition to fa/sgana (l. 713). Swords fell from hands, if the hands that held them were maimed or cut off; from shoulders, if the shoulders and the sword belts that they carried were slashed through. The sword belt probably passed over the right shoulder; and the sword, when not in use, dangled in its sheath at the left side.
πρυμνῆθεν, used for a partitive genitive, § 172.
οἴσετε, § 153.
πάντων ... ἄξιον ἦμαρ, ‘a day worth all our former toils.’
721-723. Achilles, on the other hand, assigned a quite different reason for Hector's reluctance to fight, I 352 f.
αὐτόν, with m)(e) (l. 722).
We are to understand that Ajax, who had previously been springing from deck to deck of one ship after another, now stood at bay on the vessel of Protesilaus.
θρῆνυν, explained in the scholia as a ‘thwart’ (kaqe/dran) for rowers or helmsman. There are various other conjectures about it, both ancient and modern.
ἄρειον, comparative of a)gaqo/n.
‘In which we may defend ourselves with citizens who would change the fortune of battle.’
ἑτεραλκέα means ‘bringing defensive strength to the other side’ that previously was getting the worse of the conflict.
ἀλλ’(ὰ) ... ga/r, ‘but [this is not to be considered] for.’
πόντῳ κεκλιμένοι, with “naught but seas behind” (Chapman).
‘Therefore delivery lies in might, not in flinching from battle.’
χάριν Ἕκτορος ὀτρύναντος, ‘to serve Hector who urged him’: χάριν, ‘for the sake of,’ is adverbial accusative.

745, 746. οὔτασκε and οὖτα: this verb (ou)ta/w, ou)ta/zw), like tu/ptw, nu/ssw, and plh/ssw, is regularly used of wounding by a thrust, the weapon not leaving the hand. Cf. E 336, 16.26. When the poet wishes to express the idea of hitting with a missile that is hurled from a distance he uses ba/llw.
τίπτε § 48) δεδάκρυσαι, ‘why pray are you in tears?’
εἱανοῦ, cf. e(anou=, *g 385.
Πάτροκλε, but *patro/klees (l. 7), § 102.
‘At the death of both of whom we should be exceedingly distressed.’
‘O knight Patroclus,’ the poet says with sympathy, directly addressing him.
25, 26. βέβληται and οὔτασται: see note on O 745.
Of Machaon, about whose wounding Patroclus had been sent to make inquiry of Nestor (11.608-615), he says not a word. Nor does Achilles question him about the errand.
ἀμήχανος, ‘unmanageable,’ ‘proof against entreaty,’ ‘unyielding.’
τί σευ ἄλλος κτλ., ‘what good shall another—even a late-born man —have of you?’ Neither your services nor your helpful example will make posterity grateful to you.
‘Pitiless! It seems then that your father is not the knight Peleus.’ Cf. note on 3.183.

Vergil imitates as follows (Aen. IV, 365-367):
Nec tibi diva parens, generis nec Dardanus auctor,
perfide, sed duris genuit te cautibus horrens
Caucasus Hyrcanaeque admorunt ubera tigres.
False as thou art, and more than false, forsworn; Not sprung from noble blood, nor goddess-born, But hewn from harden'd entrails of a rock; And rough Hyrcanian tigers gave thee suck.—Dryden.

Lines 36-45 are taken, with necessary changes, from 11.794-803; the former scene is the tent of Nestor whither Patroclus had been sent by Achilles to inquire after the wounded man (cf. p. 114). The lines are a part of Nestor's advice.
θεοπροπίην, cf. I 410-416.
‘And give me these arms of yours to gird on my shoulders.’

ὀλίγη δέ τ’(ε) ktl., the meaning is somewhat obscure, and capable of more than one interpretation: ‘for short is the time to recover the breath in war,’ or ‘for only a little time is yet a chance to recover the breath in war.’
τ’(ε) marks the gnomic character of the statement.
ἦ γὰρ ἔμελλεν ... λιτέσθαι, ‘for really he was fated to pray for evil death and doom for himself’; i. e. really what he was praying for was fated to be his own doom.
ὅ τε may be for o(/s te, with a)nh/r (l. 53) for its antecedent; or it may be for o(/ti te, ‘because.’
The city was Lyrnessus according to B 690.
μετανάστην conforms to the case of an understood me, one object of the verb of depriving (e(/leto, l. 58).
προτετύχθαι, προ-τεύχω.
ἐάσομεν may be aorist subjunctive. The sense is: ‘let us suffer these wrongs to be things of the past.’ Tennyson has the phrase in The Princess: “and let old bygones be.”
οὐδ’ ἄρα πως ἦν, ‘for, it seems [a)/ra], it is not possible in any way’; cf. l. 33.
ἦ τοι ἔφην γε, ‘yet I thought surely.’
ἀλλ’ ὁπότ’ ἄν, ‘until.’ For the thought cf. I 650-653.
Τρώων κτλ., ‘the whole city of the Trojans is come against us, full of confidence.’
θάρσυνος = teqarshkui=a.

71-73. τάχα κτλ., ‘quickly would they flee and fill the watercourses with their corpses, if lord Agamemnon were gentle-hearted toward me.’ These lines (with 52-61 and particularly 84-87) have given much trouble, and critics generally have regarded them as quite inconsistent with the embassy of Book IX. Cauer however observes that the attitude of Achilles here harmonizes with his own words at the conclusion of the embassy (I 615 and 646 ff.). “Achilles is in fact not satisfied with the reparation offered [in Book IX]; there is no reparation for him; he ignores the attempt to make one” (Cauer, Homerkritik, p. 280).
ἤπια εἰδείη, see note on E 326; and on the condition, § 207.1.
ἀμῦναι expresses purpose.
κεφαλῆς, ‘throat’ here.—With Ἕκτορος supply o)/y, subject of peria/gnutai.
ἀλαλητῷ, cf. B 149.
πυρός, for construction cf. B 415, I 242.
μύθου τέλος, my ‘chief injunction,’ with reference to l. 87. For a similar expression see I 56.
For ὡς ἄν with subjunctive, § 196.
πότι δ’(έ), ‘and besides.’ For the apparent ignorance of the embassy and the offerings described in Book IX, see the note on l. 71.

θήσεις, ‘you would make’ in our idiom. Achilles is not jealous of any success that may come to Patroclus, of course. But he is apprehensive that, should such success be pushed too far, the Greeks would forget their helplessness and be less inclined to make him due amends. His wounded pride is always uppermost in his mind.
ἐμβήῃ, formed like dw/h| (l. 88) and qh/h|s (l. 96), § 149 (1).
τοὺς δέ, the Trojans and the rest of the Greeks.

97-100. This unnatural prayer was regarded as an interpolation in ancient times also (by the Alexandrians Zenodotus and Aristarchus). The invocation of Apollo is very strange, for Apollo is a partizan of the Trojans (l. 94). νῶιν seems to be a blunder for nw=i. Cf. § 110. It must be translated as nominative, subject of ἐκδυῖμεν, which is an optative of wish.

κρήδεμνα λύωμεν, ‘unloose the head-dress,’ said metaphorically; the head-dress of Troy is the *pe/rgamos a)/krh, *z 512 (i(erh/, E 446), where are the seats of the gods and the *pria/moio me/laqron which Agamemnon (B 414) wishes to destroy (Studniczka)
At this point the poet returns to the battle being waged about the ship of Protesilaus, mentioned at the end of the preceding book
ἔχε, ‘was making,’ ‘gave out.’

κάπ, § 47. The shield of Ajax is thus described (H 219-223):
*ai)/as d' e)ggu/qen h)=lqe fe/rwn sa/kos h)u/te pu/rgon,
xa/lkeon e(ptabo/eion, o(/ oi( *tuxi/os ka/me teu/xwn,
skutoto/mwn o)/x' a)/ristos, *(/ulh| e)/ni oi)ki/a nai/wn:
o(/s oi( e)poi/hsen sa/kos ai)o/lon e(ptabo/eion
tau/rwn zatrefe/wn, e)/pi d' u)/gdoon h)/lase xalko/n.

‘Ajax came near with his tower-like shield, bronze-covered, of seven oxhides, which Tychius had wrought for him with pains—Tychius, who was far the best of the leather-workers and who dwelt in Hyle; he had made for him the shimmering shield of seven hides from well-fed bulls, and over all he forged an eighth layer of bronze.’
Supply sa/kos as object of πελεμίξαι.
ἔχετ’(ο), ‘was oppressed by,’ ‘suffered from.’
ἀμ-πνεῦσαι, for the prefix, § 47.—πάντῃ κτλ., ‘and on all sides evil was set upon evil.’ “Ill strengthen'd ill” (Chapman).
αἰχμῆς, with o)/pisqen.
παρὰ καυλόν, ‘by the end of the shaft.’
αὔτως, ‘in vain.’
μάχης ἐπὶ μήδεα κεῖρεν, ‘thwarted [literally ‘mowed over,’ ‘cut short’] his plans for battle.’
Join τῆς κάτ’(α).
Πατροκλῆα, § 102.
ὄρσεο, § 153. So too du/seo (l. 129).
πυρὸς ... ἰωήν, ‘the flare of fire.’
“May they not (as I fear they may) seize the ships and make it no longer possible to escape” (GMT. 261). For another example of this same subjunctive cf. B 195.
θᾶσσον, ‘the sooner the better,’ ‘with all haste.’
ἀγείρω, subjunctive.
135-139 = 3.334-338, with slight changes in last line.
ἄλκιμα, though plural, is used with dou=re. Patroclus apparently takes his own two spears.
ἔμμεναι denotes purpose.
μεῖναι ὁμοκλήν, ‘to await the word of command.’ While the warrior fought afoot, his charioteer held the chariot near by and waited intently for orders.
ἅρπυια, ‘the storm-wind,’ personified as female.

‘And in the side-traces he harnessed blameless Pedasus.’ Why the extra horse was taken, is a difficult question. Under ordinary circumstances it might be supposed that the trace-horse would take the place of one of the regular pair, in case either of the latter should be wounded; but here the regular pair were immortal. Yet, as an ancient commentator suggests, if Homer permitted the immortal gods to be wounded (as in Book V) why not immortal horses as well?
οἳ δέ, the verb of the predicate does not appear until l. 166, r(w/ont'(o), before which the subject is repeated in h(gh/tores ktl., l. 164.
τοῖσίν τε πέρι κτλ., ‘in whose hearts is exceeding great strength,’
πέρι is probably an adverb, ‘exceedingly.’
ἀπὸ κρήνης μελανύδρου is to be translated with la/yontes (l. 161).
ἄκρον, with me/lan u(/dwr (l. 161), ‘the dark water at its surface.’— φόνον αἵματος = ai(=ma fo/nou, ‘the blood of slaughter.’
περιστένεται δέ, ‘although’ etc.
κρίνας, ‘separating,’ ‘marshaling.’ Cf. B 446.
μοι, ‘I pray you.’
ὑπό, ‘during.’

χόλῳ, ‘on gall’ (Attic xolh=|), instead of milk, is the traditional interpretation; but xo/los has its usual meaning in l. 206, and possibly here too. T. L. Agar (Classical Review, vol. xiii, p. 43) says: “‘In wrath’ is all that xo/lw| need imply. The child is supposed to inherit the mood of the mother at the time she suckles it.”
μ̓ stands for moi (or perhaps me) which is to be translated with e)ba/zete. See note on I 59.
πέφανται, cf. note on B 122.
ἕης, solitary instance of this form, § 123.2.
ἔνθα, ‘therefore.’
τις, ‘every man,’ as often.
ἄρθεν (a)rari/skw), ‘were fitted together,’ ‘pressed close.’ The second aorist active of the same verb occurs as transitive in l. 212 (a)ra/rh|), but intransitive in l. 214 (a)/raron).
βίας ἀνέμων ἀλεείνων, ‘trying to escape the violent assaults of the winds.’
The idea is imitated by Vergil (Aen. X, 361): haeret pede pes densusque viro vir.
‘Foot presses on foot, and closely man on man.’
λαμπροῖσι φάλοισι, ‘with splendid horns.’ Cf. Introduction, 33.
νευόντων, ‘as the warriors nodded.’
οὔλων ταπήτων, ‘fleecy coverlets,’ for beds and chairs.
τετυγμένον, ‘well wrought.’
Hurried on by his quick imagination the poet does not trouble himself about strictly logical expression at this point.
ὅτι μή, ‘except.’
Quantity of τό, § 38.
The poet imagines the lodge of Achilles, like Homeric houses in general, opening on an enclosure which contained an altar of *zeu\s e(rkei=os.

Achilles prays to the great god of his own far distant land. The oracle of Zeus at Dodona is referred to in the Odyssey (Od. 14.327, Od. 19.296) as a place where his counsel is learned from a high-leafed oak; that is, from the sounds given by the rustling leaves. Its antiquity is mentioned by Herodotus (II, 52), who says that the oracle of Dodona was regarded as the oldest among the Greeks.
ἄνα, vocative of a)/nac.
Σελλοί (another reading is s' *(elloi/) probably has an etymological connection with *(/ellhnes.

ἀνιπτόποδες, χαμαιεῦναι. “The Selli at Dodona were xamaieu=nai, i. e. abstained from sleeping in a bed, probably for the reason that the bed would become too holy for anyone else to occupy afterwards. They were also a)nipto/podes, and the priest and priestess of Artemis Hymnia did not wash like other people [Pausanias, viii, 13, 1], doubtless because of the excessive sanctity of their persons, just as the Arabians of old might not wash or anoint the head.”—F. B. Jevons, Introduction to the History of Religion (London and New York, 1896), p. 63; from the chapter on Taboo: its Transmissibility.
εὐξαμένοιο agrees with the genitive (e)mou=) implied in e)mo/n.
νηῶν ἐν ἀγῶνι, ‘in the gathering place of the ships.’
ὄφρα, ‘in order that,’ followed by future indicative, ei)/setai (from oi=da), with essentially the same force as the subjunctive. GMT. 324.
ἤ ῥα καὶ οἶος κτλ., ‘whether our squire will be able [‘understand how’] to fight alone, or then only his hands rage invincible, when I myself go into the moil of war.’

Vergil imitates (Aen. XI, 794-798):
Audiit et voti Phoebus succedere partem
mente dedit, partem volucres dispersit in auras:
sterneret ut subita turbatam morte Camillam.
annuit oranti; reducem ut patria alta videret,
non dedit, inque notos vocem vertere procellae.

‘Apollo heard and silently granted half his prayer, the other half he scattered to the fleet winds: he assented to his entreaty that he might strike down the bewildered Camilla in unexpected death; he did not grant that the lofty home of his fathers should witness his return, but the blasts carried his words forth on the breezes.’
ἀπονέεσθαι, for long a_ cf. B 113, I 20.
δ’(έ) = ga/r.
ὄφρ’(α), ‘until.’
μέγα φρονέοντες, ‘in high spirits.’
ἔθοντες, ‘as their custom is.’

A probable interpolation, because, as the ancient commentators observed, the line is tautological: ai)ei/ is practically equivalent to e)/qontes, kertome/ontes to e)ridmai/nwsin, o(dw=| e)/pi to ei)nodi/ois. Besides, kertome/ontes, which elsewhere means to ‘vex by words,’ here has the special meaning of ‘torment by acts.’ Translate, ‘always tormenting wasps that have their nests by the road.’
‘They make a common pest for many men.’
τιθεῖσιν, for tiqe/-nsin. Cf. B 255, didou=sin, *g 152, i(ei=sin.
263, 264. παρά goes with kiw/n. ‘If a wayfaring man passes by and unwittingly disturbs them.’—For the omission of ke(n) before κινήσῃ see § 197.
The verbs πέτεται and ἀμύνει agree with the adjective pa=s (‘every one’), instead of the real subject. πᾶς itself is in partitive apposition to oi(/ (l. 264).
τῶν, ‘of these,’ i. e. the wasps.
τιμήσομεν, what mood and tense? § 145, § 196.
With θεράποντες supply a)/ristoi/ ei)sin, ‘and whose squires are best.’

The poet in his omniscience naturally says that it was Patroclus whom the Trojans saw; it is not necessary to understand, however, that the Trojans at once recognized the man in Achilles's armor as Patroclus; indeed, l. 281 implies that they thought he was Achilles. But as a matter of fact, the poet lays no further stress on the disguise, which was apparently of little effect.
ὀρίνθη, ‘was shaken,’ ‘was dismayed.’
ἐλπόμενοι, ‘believing’; the participle agrees with fa/lagges except in gender, in respect to which it follows the sense.
ὦμον, construction, § 180.
μιν ἀμφί, for a)mfi/ min. Cf. § 168.
φόβηθεν, ‘fled. See note on Z 278.
λιπετο, ‘was left,’ § 185.
ὅμαδος κτλ., ‘incessant din arose.’
The appropriateness of the simile is emphasized by the fact that the poet has already alluded to the Trojans as a ‘dark cloud’ (l. 66).
κινήσῃ, ‘drives,’ ‘banishes’ with the wind.
299, 300. ‘And there shine forth all the outlooks and jutting peaks and the dells, and from heaven the vast ether shows through the riven clouds’ (literally ‘breaks forth beneath’).

Tennyson renders the parallel passage (8.557, 558):
And every height comes out, and jutting peak
And valley, and the immeasurable heavens
Break open to their highest.
ἔφανεν (l. 299) and ὑπερράγη (l. 300) are gnomic aorists § 184)
ἐρωή, ‘respite,’ cessation.’ See note on B 179.
οὐ γάρ πώ τι, ‘for not yet in any degree.’
ὑπ’ Αχαιῶν, ‘driven by the Achaeans.’
αἰδώς, nominative used in exclamation, § 170.
θοοί, ‘quick’ for battle.
δαείω, ‘learn,’ § 149 (a); formed like damei/w.—Presumably Sarpedon knows that the man is not Achilles.
ὅς τις ὅδε, ‘who this man is that.’

κεκλήγοντες, a perfect participle (cf. kla/zw) inherited from the Aeolic songs. Such perfect participles, with the inflection of the present, were regular in the Aeolic dialect (Cauer, Homerkritik, pp. 38, 101).
κασιγνήτην ἄλοχόν τε, Vergil's Iovisque et soror et coniunx (Aen. I, 46 f.).
For ὤ μοι ἐγών Plato (Republic, III, 388 C) has ai)\ ai)\ e)gw/n, an expression useful as an interpretation: ‘woe, woe is me!’ i. e. to me.
μοι is a dative of the person interested; ἐγών is nominative in exclamation.
ὅ τε = ‘that.’
μοῖρ’(ά) (e)sti), ‘'tis fated.’ Even Zeus himself feels subject to the decrees of fate; his only query is whether he shall delay the fulfilment.
ἤδη ... δαμάσσω, ‘shall at once allow him to be slain.’
πάλαι πεπρωμένον αἴσῃ, ‘long since doomed to fate,’ i. e. to death.
ἄψ implies a reversal of the doom.
ἐπαινέομεν, future, § 151.
ζών = sa/on (a reading introduced by some editors).

φράζεο, μή τις ... ἐθέλησι καὶ ἄλλος, ‘see to it that no one else too shall desire.’ This negative object clause is equivalent to the familiar Attic o(/pws mh/ with the future indicative (GMT. 341,352). The latter (Attic construction) Homer never uses.
υἱέες, § 107.
ἐνήσεις (e)ni/hmi), ‘will arouse in.’ Such sons of immortals were lalmenus, son of Ares; Menesthius, son of Spercheius; Eudorus, son of Hermes; Achilles, son of Thetis; and Aeneas, son of Aphrodite.
‘Send [i. e. ‘command to go’] Death and sweet Sleep to carry him.’
Θάνατον and Ὕπνον are subjects of φέρειν, on which see § 211.
εἰς ὅ κε = Attic e(/ws a)/n.

In the pre-Homeric days of Greece it is probable that bodies were embalmed (Helbig, Hom. Epos^{2}, pp. 51-56). This is a natural inference from the remains found preserved at Myeenae, after three thousand years. And the following reminiscences of the custom appear in the Homeric poems: tarxu/w (ll. 456, 674; H 85) is undoubtedly another form of the later tarixeu/w, ‘embalm’ (cf. ta/rixos, ‘mummy’), used by Herodotus, for example, in his description of the Egyptian process of mummifying (Herod. II, 85 ff.); the body of Patroclus was preserved by a sort of em balming, T 38, 39; the body of dead Hector was not burned until twenty-two days after his death (24.31, 413, 664, 784), and Achilles's body was kept seventeen days (Od. 24.63); jars of honey were laid away with the ashes of the dead (23.170, Od. 24.68), the significance of which act lies in the fact that honey was anciently used as a preservative.—In Homeric times the dead were burned and their ashes, gathered in urns, were buried. So tarxu/ein came to mean simply ‘bury.’ Over the ashes a mound of earth (tu/mbos, l. 457) was raised, and surmounted by an upright gravestone (sth/lh, l. 457).— In historical times cremation seems to have given way largely, but by no means entirely, to ordinary interment.
τὸ γὰρ γέρας κτλ., Vergil's “qui solus honos Acheronte sub imo est” (Aen. XI, 23), ‘for this is the only boon in deepest Acheron.’
τόν repeats the object, *qrasu/mhlon.
δεύτερος ὁρμηθείς: Patroclus was first to attack, Sarpedon ‘second’ (deu/teros).
ὃ δέ continues the same subject, contrary to later usage. Cf. A 191.—Perhaps οὔτασεν is here used for e)/balen: if so, the usage is exceptional. See note on O 745.
μακών, μηκάομαι.
τὼ δὲ διαστήτην, ‘the two other horses [the immortal pair] sprang apart.’
σύγχυτ’(ο) (sugxe/w), ‘were entangled.’
παρήορος, the ‘tracehorse,’ Pedasus.
τοῖο κτλ., ‘for this [the disorder of horses and reins] Automedon found an end,’ i. e. ‘remedy.’
ἄορ is a synonym of ci/fos and fa/sganon. See notes on O 711 and 714.
παρὰ μηροῦ, ‘from the thigh,’ because the sheath of the sword hung by the thigh.
οὐδ’ ἐμάτησεν, ‘without delay.’ Others render, ‘nor did he labor in vain.’
‘The two horses were set straight [in line with the pole of the chariot] and were pulled up tight in the reins.’
συνίτην, σύνειμι (ei)=mi).
Presumably it is the second of his two spears that Sarpedon now uses, unless the first was recovered (l. 466). The Homeric warrior regularly carried two spears (3.18, 11.43, 16.139).
ὤρνυτο, cf. note on 3.349.
ἔρχαται (e)/rgw or e)e/rgw), § 142.4, c; literally ‘are confined.’ ‘He hit him just where the midriff is locked about the throbbing heart.’—On ἁδινόν see B 87.
The second ἤριπε(ν) is to be translated as present, § 184.
νήιον εἶναι, ‘to be a ship-timber.’
ἀγέληφι, dative here, § 155.1.
μενέαινε, ‘was filled with fury.’
πέπον, cf. I 252.
τοι ἐελδέσθω κτλ., ‘let your yearning be for grievous battle.’
Σαρπηδόνος, for e)mei=o, with emphasis.
ἀμφί, § 168; the genitive with a)mfi/ is found also 16.825, 18.20, etc.
ἔχεο κρατερῶς, ‘hold out stoutly.’
502, 503. μιν ... ὀφθαλμούς, § 180.
ἵππους, that had belonged to Sarpedon and Thrasymelus.
ἐπεὶ λίπεν ἅρματ’ ἀνάκτων: either ‘since the chariot of their masters had been abandoned’ or ‘since the chariot had been bereft of its masters,’ as suggested in the scholia.
λίπεν (=e)li/phsan) in sense of e)lei/fqhsan is a solitary and suspicious instance of this form.
ἅρματα seems to be plural used for singular, as illustrated in 3.29, o)xe/wn, and A 14, ste/mmat'(a).
οἳ δ’(έ), Patroclus and his companions.
εἰ δ’ ἄγε, cf. A 302.
κελαινεφὲς αἷμα to *sarphdo/na (l. 668), ‘cleanse the dark blood from Sarpedon, when you have gone out of the range of missiles.’
κάθηρον takes two accusatives, like a verb of depriving.
‘Send him to be [i. e. ‘let him be’] borne along with’ etc.
The conclusion of a past contrary to fact condition.
κῆρα ... θανάτοιο, ‘fate of death.’
689, 690. These gnomic lines are wanting in some MSS., including the best, Venetus A. They look like an interpolation from another passage (P 177. 178).
ὁτὲ δ’(έ), ‘and then again,’ ‘and at another time.’

Cf. Vergil (Aen. XI, 664, 665):
Quem telo primum, quem postremum, aspera virgo,
deicis? aut quot humi morientia corpora fundis?
Who foremost, and who last, heroic maid, On the cold earth were by thy courage laid?—Dryden.
ἐυδμήτου ἐπὶ πύργου, perhaps the famous tower over the Scaean gate (3.149).
δεινὰ δ’ ὁμοκλήσας, see note on E 439.
οὔ νύ τοι αἶσα, ‘not at all is it your portion,’ ‘it is not decreed.’
ἀλῆναι, εἴλω.
μιν, object of prose/fh.
οὐδέ τί σε χρή, ‘it becomes you not at all’ to withdraw; ‘it ill becomes you.’ Cf. I 496.
‘Oh that I were as much superior to you [in position and power] as I am your inferior!’ Attic Greek would require h)=n rather than ei)/hn, Cf. § 202.
τῷ, ‘then.’
στυγερῶς, ‘hatefully’; here, ‘to your hurt.’
ἔφεπε, ‘drive ... after,’ has i(/ppous as direct object and *patro/klw| dependent on the prefix.
Κεβριόνῃ, Hector's charioteer.
τόν οἱ περὶ χεὶρ ἐκάλυψεν = xeiroplhqh= (cf. Xen. Anab. III, 3, 17), ‘filling the hand,’ ‘as large as his hand could hold.’
ἧκε, ἵημι.
οὐδὲ δὴν χάζετο φωτός, a somewhat obscure parenthesis: ‘nor long did he hold back from his man’ (probably Hector), i. e. ‘no laggard was he in the attack.’
ἀγακλῆος, like *patroklh=os, § 102.
οὐδέ ... ἔσχεν ὀστέον, ‘nor did the bone hold,’ i. e. ‘stay fast.’
αὐτοῦ, ‘there.’
εὐεργέος, three syllables, § 43.
The speech of Patroclus is of course ironical.
ὡς, ‘how,’ introducing an exclamation.

Perhaps additional point is given to Patroclus's sarcasm by picturing Cebriones in the act of seeking what was to the Homeric Greeks an ignoble food. Homeric warriors eat beef and pork, but no shellfish; neither in the diet of the luxurious Phaeacians nor in that of the suitors of Penelope are shellfish included. The companions of Odysseus ate shellfish when half-starved only.
ἔβλητο, ‘is struck,’ ‘is wounded,’ gnomic aorist, with passive meaning, § 184, § 185.—ἑῄ τέ μιν κτλ., ‘and his own might is his undoing.’
κταμένης (ktei/nw), another aorist middle with passive meaning, § 185.
μέγα φρονέοντε, cf. l. 258.

ἵεντ’(ο) (vi/emai), ‘strove.’ This verb is to be kept distinct from the middle of i(/hmi, with which it has two tenses, present and imperfect, identical in inflection. The Homeric aorist is ei)sa/mhn or e)eisa/mhn.
κεφαλῆφιν, § 172.—The object of λάβεν, μεθίει, and ἔχεν (l. 763) is *kebrio/nhn understood.
σύναγον ... ὑσμίνην, Latin committebant proelium.
ἔβαλον, § 184.
πάταγος, supply gi/gnetai.—With ἀγνυμενάων understand the genitive plural of the trees mentioned in l. 767. Vergil imitates by “stridunt silvae” (Aen. II, 418).
οὐδ’ ἕτεροι, ‘and neither side.’
ἄμφ̓, with *kebrio/nhn. For accent see § 168.
λελασμένος ἱπποσυνάων, ‘forgetful of his horsemanship.’
ἀμφοτέρων limits be/le)(a).
δεινός, to be translated in the Homeric order.
ὃ μέν, Patroclus, τόν, Apollo.
ἀντεβόλησεν, Apollo is subject.
kanaxh\n e)/xe cf. 16.105.
αὐλῶπις and τρυφάλεια, see Introduction, 33.
πάρος γε μὲν οὐ θέμις ἦεν, ‘formerly however it was not natural’ or ‘usual’ (Cauer, Die Kunst des Übersetzens^{2}, pp. 25, 26).
οἱ, Patroclus.—ἄγη, ἄγνυμι.
κεκορυθμένον, ‘tipped with bronze’; cf. 3.18.
ἡλικίην, in meaning here equivalent to o(mhliki/hn, *g 175.—ἐκέκαστο, καίνυμαι.
ἀφ’ ἵππων, ‘from their chariots.’
διδασκόμενος πολέμοιο, § 174 (2).
ὃ μέν, Euphorbus.
ἐκ χροός, of Patroclus.
κατά, ‘down through.’
σῦν, ‘wild boar.’
πολλά, cognate accusative with a)sqmai/nonta.
τ’ may be a relic of an original v) (i. e. ἑ).
πεφνόντα agrees with ui(o/n, one of the two objects of a)phu/ra (a verb of depriving).
ἀπηύρα, § 63.4.
τάων, with reference to gunai=kas (l. 831); it is used with pro/sq'(e): ‘for the protection of these.’
ὀρωρέχαται, ὀρέγνυμι, § 142.4, c; in meaning equivalent to o(rmw=ntai or e)kte/tantai (e)ktei/nw).
ἦμαρ ἀναγκαῖον = dou/lion h)=mar, *z 463.
δείλ̓ (i. e. deile/), Latin miser.
πρὶν ... πρίν (l. 840): as usual, the former pri/n must be omitted in translation.
ἰέναι, § 213.
αἱματόεντα, for construction cf. r(wgale/on, note on B 416.
αὐτοί, ‘alone.’
τοιοῦτοι, ‘such as you are.’
Apollo overpowered Patroclus with the consent of Zeus and in accord with fate; so these three are regarded as a single cause. Euphorbus is the second agent.
This prophecy accords with the ancient belief that just before death a man has an insight into the future.
οὔ θην οὐδ’ αὐτός, the repetition of the negative gives emphasis: ‘surely [qhn] not even you yourself shall live for long.’
βέῃ, present with future meaning, like dh/ute, ‘you shall find,’ I 418, and kakkei/ontes, ‘to go to rest,’ A 606. Compare the common Attic examples, e)/domai, ‘I shall eat,’ pi/omai, ‘I shall drink.’
δαμέντ’(ι) agrees with toi (l. 852). damh=nai would give the sense more exactly.

Compare Verg. Aen. XI, 831 (=XII, 952):
vitaque cum gemitu fugit indignata sub umbras.

‘And the spirit with a sigh fled chafing to the shades below.’ Also Matthew Arnold's Sohrab and Rustum:
And from his limbs
Unwillingly the spirit fled away,
Regretting the warm mansion which it left,
And youth, and bloom, and this delightful world.
ἀνδροτῆτα must be scanned with the initial syllable short—apparently a metrical irregularity.
860, 861. τίς δ’ οἶδ’, εἴ κ’ Ἀχιλεὺς ... φθήῃ ... τυπείς, ‘who knows if haply Achilles shall first be smitten,’ or in our idiom, ‘who knows whether Achilles shall not first be smitten?’ GMT. 491.
ἀπὸ θυμὸν ὀλέσσαι, infinitive of result, ‘so as to lose his life.’
It was Poseidon (23.277 f.) who gave these horses to Peleus on the occasion of his marriage to Thetis (18.84 f.).
The allusion is to the fighting in Book XVII.
ὀρθοκραιράων, ‘with upright horns,’ applicable not only to cattle, but also to Homeric ships, which seem to have had up-reaching bows and sterns, horn-like and of equal height.
ἀτυζόμενοι πεδίοιο, ‘fleeing bewildered over the plain’; a similar genitive occurs 3.14, Z 507, etc.
μὴ δή μοι κτλ., “may the gods not bring to pass—as I fear they may—bitter woes for my soul.” GMT. 261. Cf. B 195, 16.128.
Achilles suspects the truth, as the poet said, l. 4.
σχέτλιος, ‘persistent, fellow!’ or ‘my reckless comrade!’ § 170.
ἦ τ’ ἐκέλευον, ‘and yet I bade him,’ 16.87 ff.
ἧος, Attic e(/ws.
ἣ μὴ ὤφελλε κτλ., a wish impossible of fulfilment.
ὃ δ’ ἔστενε, the only audible mark, thus far, of Achilles's intense grief. Note the swift change of subject.
δείδιε, Antilochus is again the subject; the form in this instance is commonly called a pluperfect with imperfect ending, and so translated by the past tense.—The subject of ἀπαμήσειε is Achilles.

σιδήρῳ, ‘with his iron’ (sword). The use of bronze was of course older than that of iron. Weapons and instruments of bronze were characteristic of the Mycenaean age. They belonged also to the early Homeric age—at least to that part during which the epic style was developing. So the poets sang on about weapons of bronze even after the use of iron became common. The knowledge of iron must have been widespread, however, when the Iliad was completed. The allusion in this line is a bit of evidence in the matter. —Cauer, Homerkritik, pp. 179-187. Professor Ridgeway (The Early Age of Greece, vol. i, pp. 294-296) also calls attention to the general use of iron in the Homeric age “for all kinds of cutting instruments, and for agricultural purposes.” This prevalence of iron is in fact one of the chief differences between the Homeric and the Mycenaean civilizations.
ᾤμωξεν, Achilles is subject.
Thetis, it seems, had returned to the home of her father. This was in the deep sea
messhgu\s de\ *sa/mou te kai\ *)/imbrou paipaloe/sshs (24.78).

39-49. These “Hesiodic” lines are probably a late addition to the poem. Vergil introduces some of the names, Aen. V, 825, 826:
laeva tenent Thetis et Melite Panopeaque virgo,
Nesace Spioque Thaliaque Cymodoceque.
‘And the shining-white cave, too, was filled with them.’
εἴδετ’(ε) (oi)=da), Attic ei)dh=te.
ὃ δ’ ἀνέδραμεν κτλ., parenthetical. The conclusion to l. 55 begins with l. 57; e)piproe/hka (l. 58) is subordinate in importance, however, to u(pode/comai (l. 59).
φυτὸν ὣς γουνῷ ἀλωῆς, ‘like a tree on the orchard-slope.’
μοι, dative of interest, ‘before me,’ ‘in the world with me.’
For Achilles's prayer see A 409; Thetis carries it to Zeus, A 509, 510; Achilles mentions its fulfilment. 16.236, 237.
ἶσον ἐμῇ κεφαλῇ, ‘equally with my own life.’ A scholiast quotes the Pythagorean dictum: “ti/ e)sti fi/los; a)/llos e)gw/.”
θαῦμα ἰδέσθαι, ‘a marvel to see.’

βροτοῦ ἀνέρος ἔμβαλον εὐνῇ, ‘forced you to share a mortal's couch.’ The fact is alluded to again in this book, ll. 432-434. The story is (scholium, Venetus A, on A 519): Zeus became enamored of Thetis, daughter of Nereus, and passionately pursued her. But in the region of Caucasus he was restrained by Prometheus, who warned him that the son born of Thetis would be mightier than his own father; Zeus, fearing that his rule might be overthrown, heeded the warning; and he wedded Thetis to a mortal instead, Peleus, son of Aeacus. From this union sprang Achilles, who was in fact mightier than his father Peleus, as well as all the other warriors of his time.
ἁλίῃσιν, here a substantive, ‘goddesses of the sea.’
There is an ellipsis after nu=n d'(e/) of a thought like ‘the gods forced you to wed a mortal’; the verb of the implied thought is in a secondary tense, and so permits the optative ei)/h after i(/na.
καὶ σοί, ‘you too.’
παιδός, objective genitive after pe/nqos.
ἕλωρα, the ‘plundering,’ i. e. ‘despoiling.’
‘Short-lived, then, you will be, my son, to judge by your words.’
οἷ’ ἀγορεύεις = ‘because you speak such words.’
Thetis's words of remonstrance, with the warning of death, serve but to inflame Achilles the more.
ἐπεὶ οὐκ ἄρ’ ἔμελλον, ‘since I was not destined, it seems.’
ἐμεῦ δὲ δέησεν κτλ., ‘and he needed me to keep from him calamity.’
ἀρῆς ἀλκτῆρα, literally ‘a warder against calamity.’
The conclusion is found in l. 114, as the punctuation indicates. Achilles's mood is seen in the passionate, disconnected utterance.
Ἕκτορι, in Attic prose, u(f' *(/ektoros.
οἷος, for quantity of penult see § 28.
δέ, ‘although.’
ὡς, in force like ei)/qe, with a)po/loito, optative of wish.
ἐφέηκε, § 184.
καταλειβομένοιο, ‘trickling’ into the throat, or perhaps ‘dripping’ from the rocks or trees where wild bees have their hives.
ἠύτε καπνός, i. e. as smoke from a little fire increases to an immense volume. Cf. “Behold, how great a matter a little fire kindleth!” St. James iii. 5.
θυμόν, ‘anger.’
κεφαλῆς, ‘soul,’ ‘comrade.’
οὐδὲ ... οὐδέ, ‘no, not even.’
βίη Ἡρακλῆος, cf. O 640. Zeus could not keep his own son Heracles alive, says Achilles; how then may you hope to save me?
εἰ δή, ‘since in fact.’
122-124. ‘And may I bring many a deep-bosomed Trojan and Darda nian woman to wipe the tears from her tender cheeks with her two hands and to sob bitterly.’
ἁδινόν, cf. note on B 87.
γνοῖεν, also optative of wish; its final force is so strongly felt, however, that the scholiasts interpreted it as i(/na gnoi=en.
δηρόν, the sixteen days (as reckoned by Faesi) that have elapsed since Achilles retired from active warfare seem a long time, indeed, to the warrior.
μετὰ Τρώεσσιν in prose would be expressed with slightly changed point of view, u(po\ *trw/wn.
μή πω καταδύσεο § 153), mh/ with the aorist imperative iss a very rare and poetic construction (GMT. 260).

πρίν ... ἴδηαι, note omission of ke or a)/n, as always after pri/n with subjunctive in Homer. This relic of the original paratactic construction is illustrated by translating, ‘sooner than this you shall see’ etc.— GMT. 639. It is not suggested that this translation be retained here, however.
ἐν, ‘before.’
νεῦμαι, νέομαι § 42).
πάλιν τράπεθ’ υἷος ἐῆος, ‘turned away from her noble son.’
ἁλίῃσι, an adjective.

ἐνείκαι, φέρω. It is a common story that Thetis made Achilles invulnerable except in the heel by dipping him in the Styx (cf. Servius on Verg. Aen. VI, 57, and Statius, Achilleïs, I, 269). The story is not known to Homer, however; nor is the test of the “fire-bath” (scholium on 16.37), by which Thetis sought to separate the mortal parts from the immortal, mentioned in the Homeric poems.
φεύγοντες, ‘driven in flight.’
151, 152. The protasis occurs, after a repeated apodosis, in l. 166.
‘For now again the foot-soldiers and chariots of the Trojans overtook him.’
μετόπισθε ποδῶν λάβε, ‘seized him by the feet, behind.’

δύ’ Αἴαντες, the two Ajaxes were defending the corpse from behind, during the retreat. In the previous book (P 722 ff., 735) Menelaus and Meriones are said to have been carrying Patroclus on high in their arms; here, perhaps we are to imagine the body laid on the ground again.
θοῦριν ἐπιειμενοι ἀλκήν, ‘clothed in impetuous strength,’ cf. A 149.
For quantity of ultima of κατά and μέγα (l. 160) see § 38.
ἤρατο (preferably written h)/reto), from a)/rnumai.
θωρήσσεσθαι, limiting a)/ggelos h)=lqe, ‘had come as a messenger for his arming,’ ‘had come to bid him arm.’
Note that the ultima of Διός receives the ictus (l. 32); a slight pause must be made after the word.
ἠνεμόεσσαν, § 35, § 159.

ἐπ-ιθύουσι: a participle corresponding with a)muno/menoi (l. 173) might be expected; instead, the appositive form is abandoned and a finite verb introduced. The poem affords several parallels of this construction; they are interesting as showing the poet's attitude toward his work. He is drawing a picture in words, and hurried on by his imagination he neglects strictly logical construction. Cf. l. 537 and note.
ἀνὰ σκολόπεσσι, ‘on the palisade’ of Troy.

σέβας δέ σε κτλ., ‘and let awe come over your heart § 180] at the thought of Patroclus's becoming the sport of Trojan dogs.’ The construction is the same as after nemesi/zomai, accusative and infinitive.
σοὶ λώβη, supply e)/stai.
ᾐσχυμμένος, ‘disfigured.’
ἴω, deliberative subjunctive, § 194.
οὐ ... εἴαε, ‘forbade.’
A remarkable line because it contains no correct caesural pause; one may not occur before ga/r § 14), and *(hfai/stoio pa/r' are inseparable.

On ἄλλου ... οἶδα see § 174 (4).—tou= or o(/teu (relative ‘whose’) might be expected instead of the interrogative τεῦ. But compare a similar instance in Attic prose: h(/dist' a)\n a)kou/saimi to\ o)/noma ti/s (i. e. ‘of the man who’) ou(/tws e)sti\ deino\s le/gein ktl. (Xen. Anab. II, 5, 15.) [The common (but unsatisfactory) explanation of a)/llou ... teu is that the expression has been attracted from the accusative to the case of the following interrogative teu=.]
ὅ = o(/ti.
αὔτως, ‘just as you are,’ i. e. without armor.
Cf. note on 16.43.
Lines 202-231 have been translated by Tennyson under the title “Achilles over the Trench.”
δῖα θεάων, ‘goddess of goddesses.’
αὐτοῦ, the cloud.

καπνός, the smoke implies the presence of flame; cf. the use of ka/pnissan (B 399), ‘lighted fires’; and with the combined radiance (au)gh/, l. 211) of the fire itself and its reflection in the smoke the bright cloud on Achilles's head is compared.
τηλόθεν, to the poet, remote from the island that he is describing, the gleam rises ‘from afar.’
οἳ δέ, ‘the townspeople.’ For the meaning of the rest cf. B 385.
ἄστεος ἐκ σφετέρου, i. e. from their walls and towers.
περικτιόνεσσιν ἰδέσθαι § 211), ‘for their neighbors to see.’
αἴ κέν πως, ‘in the hope that.’
ἀρῆς ἀλκτῆρες, cf. l. 100.
ἀπὸ τείχεος, ‘at a distance from the wall.’ Cf. I 87 and p. 83.

With ἀριζήλη supply gi/gnhtai. A somewhat free version (partly taken from Tennyson's lines) is: ‘and “like the clear voice when a trumpet shrills” on account of life-rending enemies that beleaguer a town.’ The trumpet is blown to warn the townspeople against the foe; so the agency expressed by dhi/wn u(/po is indirect; later writers would here rather use dia/ with the accusative [Monro, Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 204 (3)]. The trumpet was never used in battles of Homeric heroes; apparently the poet drew upon the life of his own day for a striking illustration.
Note the scansion ( § 28, § 70).
How account for the long ultima of a)/ion? § 37.
ὄπα is feminine (cf. A 604); so χάλκεον must here be used as an adjective of two endings.
πᾶσιν ὀρίνθη θυμός, “the minds of all were startled” (Chapman).
δεινόν, ‘terribly,’ with daio/menon (l. 227).

ἀμφί, ‘about,’ used vaguely; a more definite word would be u(po/: cf. the phrase u(po\ douri\ damh=nai (3.436, 4.479, 17.303), ‘be subdued under the spear,’ and u(po\ douri\ pe/rqai (16.708), ‘be sacked under the spear.’ The locative sense ‘around’ is not unsuited to o)xe/essi, however. Translate, ‘beneath their own chariots and spears.’ The situation is illustrated by a quotation from 16.378, 379, where likewise there was great confusion:
u(po\ d' a)/cosi fw=tes e)/pipton prhne/es e)c o)xe/wn, di/froi d' a)nakumbali/azon.

‘And under the axles [of their own chariots] the men fell headlong from the cars, and the chariots fell rattling over.’ Here (18.231) there is the additional idea that the men were transfixed by their own (or possibly one another's) spears in the accident of falling.
λεχέεσσι, same as fe/rtrw| (l. 236).
ἀέκοντα νέεσθαι, ‘to go unwilling,’ i. e. to set before its time. The long third day of battle that began with *l—the twenty-sixth day of the poem—is ending (cf. p. 114).
ὑφ’ ἅρμασιν κτλ., ‘the swift horses that were under the chariots.’ ‘From under,’ a tempting translation, would be u(f' a(rma/twn (cf. u(pe\c o)xe/wn, *q 504), a metrically impossible expression.
This self-called assembly was in the plain (l. 256).
πάρος (Attic pri/n), with infinitive, like Z 348.
