ὀρθῶν δ’ ἑσταότων depends on a)gorh/: ‘and they stood up during the assembly.’ It was no time nor place for sitting, as the custom was in an a)gorh/.
ἑσταότων agrees with a genitive, ‘of them,’ understood.
δέ, ‘although.’
ὅρα (Attic e(w/ra) πρόσσω καὶ ὀπίσσω, cf. A 343.
ἀμφὶ ... φράζεσθε, i. e. periske/yasqe.
δέ=ga/r.
τείχεος, the wall of Troy.
ῥηΐτεροι πολεμιζέμεν, in construction like a)rgale/os a)ntife/resqai, A 589.
One night only—and that just before this twenty-sixth day—had the Trojans spent in dangerous proximity to the Achaean ships, so far as the account in our Iliad informs us (last part of *q).
Supply h(ma=s as subject of αἱρησέμεν.
‘Such is his furious spirit, he will not desire.’
μένος Ἄρηος δατέονται, ‘divide the might of Ares,’ i. e. share the successes and rebuffs of war.
τις, ‘many a man.’
γνώσεται, ‘shall know him’ from sad experience.—ἀσπασίως κτλ., ‘joyfully shall he reach sacred Troy, whoever escapes.’

Τρώων, with pollou/s (l. 271).—αἲ γὰρ δή κτλ., ‘I pray that such words [w(=de, ‘thus,’ as I have said] may be far from my hearing.’ A scholiast neatly paraphrases: ei)/qe dh\ tou=to ou)x o(/pws mh\ (‘not only not’) i)/doimi, a)lla\ mhde\ (‘not even’) a)kou/saimi.
νύκτα μέν has as correlative prw=i d'(e/) (l. 277).

εἰν ἀγορῇ σθένος ἕξομεν, ‘in the gathering place [of Troy] we shall hold back our troops.’— σθένος=du/namin, stratia/n (scholiast). The word is not so used elsewhere by Homer, but the use is not without parallel in Attic poetry.
σανίδες τ’ ἐπὶ τῇς ἀραρυῖαι, ‘and the two-leaved doors that fit upon them.’
ἐζευγμέναι, ‘yoked,’ fastened with bolis (o)xh=es). See Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, p. 105, where the great gate of Tiryns is described.
τῷ δ’ (έ), Achilles, unnamed as before, l. 257.
περὶ τείχεος, ‘for the [city] wall,’ like l. 265.
ἠλασκάζων, intensive form; to be associated with h)la/skousin, B 470, and a)la/omai, ‘wander.’
εἴσω, within the city.
πρίν μιν κτλ., in construction like A 29.
ταῦτ’ (α) ktl., § 121.
Hector disdainfully applies a shameful word, ἀλήμεναι (from ei)/lw), to the retreat proposed by Polydamas (ll. 254, 255).
ἐελμένοι, εἴλω.
μέροπες: note the ictus on the short ultima in spite of the fact that no pause follows, an evident reminiscence of the familiar mero/pwn a)nqrw/pwn A 250, etc.
μυθέσκοντο, ‘used to speak of [the city] as’; with double accusative.
δόμων, genitive of separation after e)capo/lwle, ‘have been lost out of the houses.’
περνάμεν̓ (α), ‘sold,’ in trade; to support the besieged city and pay the allies (cf. note on I 402).
τελέεσσιν = ta/cesin.
ἐγρήγορθε (e)gei/rw), perfect imperative active (probably), second person plural, ‘keep awake.’ The form is equivalent to e)grhgo/rate. Compare pe/posqe (3.99).

To cast a slur on Polydamas, Hector suggests that his counsel betrays over-anxiety about saving his property; and as the course that Polydamas advises will lead only to the destruction of the city and the consequent loss of everything, Hector proposes with fine irony that advocates of this course at once share their goods with the mass of the Trojans, who—rather than the Achaeans—ought to be allowed to enjoy them, if the goods are bound to perish anyway.
τῶν, relative; translate by conjunction (ga/r) and demonstrative: ‘for it is better that every man of them [tw=n] should enjoy them.’
ἐγείρομεν, aorist subjunctive.
παρὰ ναῦφιν, ‘from beside the ships.’
αἴ κ’ ἐθέλῃσι, add ma/xesqai.
κε φέρῃσι, an emphatic future, here contrasted with the optative, ke feroi/mhn, on which less stress is laid. Monro, Homeric Grammar^{2}, § 275 (b).

‘Ares “is our common lord” [Chapman] and often slays the wouldbe slayer.’ Compare Z 339, ni/kh d' e)pamei/betai a)/ndras, with note; and Od. 11.537, e)pimi\c de/ te mai/netai *)/arhs, ‘Ares rages indiscriminately.’ A similar sentiment is found in Cicero, Pro Milone, 21, 56.
With αὐτὰρ Ἀχαιοί the narrative continues the scene described in ll. 231-238; before, the mournful procession was pictured; now the chief figures are evidently in the lodge of Achilles.
ἁδινοῦ ἐξῆρχε γόοιο, ‘led the choking cry of sorrow.’—For ἁδινοῦ see note on B 87.
ὥς τε (always two words in Homer), ‘like.’—For quantity of τε see § 38.
ὕπο, ‘by stealth.’
εἰ, ‘in the hope that.’

ἐν μεγάροισιν, ‘in the home of my father’ (Peleus). Nestor tells (11.765 ff.) how he and Odysseus went to Phthia, in the time before the Trojan war, to enlist warriors; and there they secured not only Achilles, but Patroclus as well; Menoetius, the father of the latter, was likewise in Phthia at the time. This occasion is alluded to also in I 253. Why Patroclus was brought up away from his home, Opus, is told in 23.84 ff. When a young boy, he accidentally killed a companion in a quarrel; and his father brought him, an exile from home in consequence, to Phthia, where King Peleus kindly received him and made him the companion and squire of his own son.
περικλυτὸν υἱόν, ‘his son grown famous.’
ἐκπέρσαντα and λαχόντα (lagxa/nw), with ui(o/n (l. 326).
ληίδος αἶσαν, ‘allotment of booty.’ Evidently it was later than this that Thetis imparted to Achilles his destiny.
ὁμοίην, here ‘the same.’
εἶμ̓ (ι) has future meaning as in Attic Greek.
αὔτως, ‘as you are,’ cf. l. 198.
καμόμεσθα, ‘won with toil.’
πόλι_ς, § 103.
λούσειαν ἄπο, a verb of cleausing, takes two accusatives; cf. 16.667 f. and note.
βρότον, to be distinguished from broto/n.
κηλέῳ, two syllables; similarly, e)nnew/roio (l. 351) must be read with four syllables § 43).
λεχέεσσι, to be thought of as something different from the improvised lexe/essi of l. 233.
ἑα_νῷ, the a (long) proves this to be the adjective, ‘enveloping.’
ἔπρηξας καὶ ἔπειτα, ‘really then you have worked your will.’ Zeus speaks with irony; he was not unaware of the part played by Here, after all; cf. l. 168 and ll. 181-186.

ἦ ῥά νυ κτλ., ‘is it true then, as it seems, that the long-haired Achaeans are your own children?’ i. e. because you care for them as for your own flesh and blood. The idiom r(a ... e)ge/nonto, ‘were all the time, it now appears,’ is familiar: cf. 3.183, 16.33.
μῦθον, here ‘question.’

‘Surely now [me\n (= mh\n) dh/], even a man [kai\ broto/s tis], I suppose [pou], although he is mortal and knows not so many counsels [as I]. is likely to accomplish [his purpose] with regard to a fellow man.’—That ἀνδρί is dative of disadvantage is suggested by the parallel expression. *trw/essi ... kaka\ r(a/yai (l. 367).
πῶς δὴ ἐγώ γ’(ε) belongs to o)/felon (l. 367): ‘why then ought not I.’
ἀμφότερον, adverbial. ‘Both because [indicated by dative] ... and because [ou(/neka].’
That the poet imagines the workshop of Hephaestus on Olympus is shown by ll. 148 and 616.
For some famous works of Hephaestus see note on A 608.
ἑλισσόμενον, ‘bustling.’
σπεύδοντα, ‘busily at work.’
πάντας, ‘in all.’
‘Placed golden wheels beneath the support [or ‘feet’] of them each.’
ὑπό belongs to qh=ken.
πυθμένι is dative after u(po/, locative in origin.

σφ’(ι) with its appositive e(ka/stw| is dative of interest.—A spinning basket for wool, provided with wheels—given to Helen by Egyptian Alcandre—is mentioned, Od. 4.125-135. Such contrivances with wheels date back to the old Phoenicians (according to Helbig, Hom. Epos^{2}, p. 108, footnote 13, who compares among other illustrations I Kings vii, 27-38).
οἱ=au)tw=|.
θεῖον δυσαίατ’ ἀγῶνα, ‘might enter the assembly of the gods.’
θαῦμα ἰδέσθαι, cf. l. 83.
τόσσον, adverbial, ‘so far.’
ἔχον τέλος=tetelesme/noi h)=san. ‘And they were [so far =] almost completed, only the cunningly wrought ears were not yet fixed on.’
‘These he was preparing to fit, and was forging the rivets.’
ἰδυίῃσι πραπίδεσσιν, cf. A 608.
ἀμφιγυήεις, cf. A 607.
384 = Z 253, where see note.
τανύπεπλε, for meaning see Introduction, 20.
πάρος γε κτλ., ‘hitherto, at least, you have not at all been used to visit us often.’
ξείνια [dw=ra], ‘entertainment’ = ceinh/ia, l. 408.
ποσίν, ‘for the feet.’
ὧδε, ‘so,’ ‘as you are,’ with a gesture of hurry, nearly equivalent to ‘at once.’
Hephaestus, in his workshop, very likely does not see Thetis, but shouts out the following reply to Charis.
For δεινή τε καὶ αἰδοίη see 3.172.
ἔνδον, is ‘in my hall.’
395-397. A different account from that given in A 591.
ἴσαν, here from oi)=da, not ei)=mi.
ὅπλα, ‘tools’ of a smith, here.
πέλωρ, ‘monster’ because big and strange in looks.
ἀμφί, adverb § 168), ‘on both sides.’
θύραζε, ‘forth’ from his workshop into the hall (me/garon) where Thetis was; cf. ll. 393, 394.

ζωῇσι νεήνισσιν ἐικυῖαι, ‘like living maidens.’ Yet there is no reason to believe that the poet was familiar with the sculptor's art; quite the contrary, for this had not yet been developed in Greece. (See E. A. Gardner's Handbook of Greek Sculpture, pp. 68, 69.) These golden maidens —like the gold and silver hounds, immortal, that guarded either side of the door of Alcinous's palace (Od. 7.91-94), or like the intelligent ships of the Phaeacians (Od. 8.556-563) that needed neither pilots nor rudders—are simply pictures of the poet's fancy. They belong in the same fairyland with the ‘automatic’ tripods (ll. 373 ff.) and bellows (ll. 468 ff.).
ἀθανάτων δὲ θεῶν κτλ., ‘and they have knowledge of handiwork from the immortal gods.’
ὕπαιθα, ‘at the side of,’ to support his tottering steps.
ἔρρων, not simply moving, but ‘limping,’ ‘moving with difficulty’ or pain. Cf. I 364, 377.
424, 425. The same words were used by Charis (ll. 385, 386).
εἰ τετελεσμένον ἐστίν, ‘if it can be accomplished.’
ἐκ πασέων § 70), ‘more than all goddesses beside.’
ἁλιάων, cf. l. 86.
δάμασσεν, ‘made subject,’ ‘forced to wed.’ Cf. l. 85. The goddess Here assumes the responsibility in 24.59 ff.:
au)ta\r *)axilleu/s e)sti qea=s go/nos, h(\n e)gw\ au)th\ qre/ya te kai\ a)ti/thla (‘nursed’) kai\ a)ndri\ po/ron para/koitin (‘wife’), *phlei=.
πολλὰ μάλ’ οὐκ κτλ., ‘very much against my will,’ because she knew in advance, a scholiast says, the troubles that would follow her marriage.
ἄλλα δέ μοι νῦν, complete with *zeu\s a)/lge) e)/dwken (l. 431).
δῶκε, subject, Zeus.

γενέσθαι τε τραφέμεν τε reminds one of A 251, tra/fen h)d' e/ge/nonto. tra/fen, however, is passive in form, while trafe/men is the second aorist active infinitive, but intransitive and equivalent to the aorist passive in meaning.
τῆς (genitive of cause) ἀχέων, ‘grieving on account of her.’— φρένας ἔφθιεν, like fqinu/qeske fi/lon kh=r, A 491.
πολλὰ κακὰ ῥέξαντα, ‘after he had made much havoc,’ to be translated after *menoiti/ou ... ui(o/n.
τὰ σὰ γούναθ’ ἱκάνομαι, ‘I have come to these knees of yours,’ i. e. ‘I beseech you.’ Cf. A 407, etc.
ἃ γὰρ ἦν οἱ [o(/pla], ‘for the arms that he had.’
δυναίμην, Attic Greek would express the wish with the indicative rather § 202): ei) ga\r e)duna/mhn. ‘Would that I were able to hide him far from horrid-sounding death.’—For ὧδε see w(s (l. 466).
ἱκάνοι, protasis of condition.
ὧδε (l. 464) ... w(s, ‘as surely as.’
οἷά τις, ‘so wonderful that many a man’ shall marvel.

θαυμάσσεται is very likely aorist subjunctive in a relative clause of purpose (not an Attic construction), although, so far as form goes, the verb may be future indicative § 145) as well.—For πολέων (also O 680, etc.) see § 106.
πᾶσαι, ‘in all,’ like pa/ntas, l. 373.
παντοίην ... ἀυτμήν, ‘blasts of every degree,’ i. e. violent or gentle or any grade between.

‘To assist § 211] him now when working fast, and now again after whatever manner Hephaestus desired and the work was being finished’; i. e. and now in turn to accommodate his wish and the demands of the work.

ἐθέλοι and ἄνοιτο are protases of the past general condition. a)/noito, however, is a suspicious form because the initial vowel is short, although it ought to be long; a proposed emendation is a)nw/goi, ‘demanded’ (van Herwerden).—Van Leeuwen, Enchiridium, § 257.

div2.head: The shield of Achilles
div2.p:
In shape, the shield may have been of the Mycenaean type (for which Reichel argues), covering the person from head to foot (Introduction. 23), or it may have been smaller, and round, the well-known later form. The poet says that it was composed of five layers (ptu/xes), but gives no further information as to the material, unless the passage in *u (ll. 270-272) be cited, the genuineness of which was suspected even in antiquity:
e)pei\ pe/nte ptu/xas h)/lase kullopodi/wn,
ta\s du/o xalkei/as, du/o d' e)/ndoqi kassite/roio,
th\n de\ mi/an xrush=n.
‘For five layers the lame god had forged, two of bronze, and two in side, of tin, and one of gold.’

Of whatever value the lines may be, they indicate at least a feeling that the five layers were composed of metal, rather than of the usual material, ox-hide. This has been the prevailing view from ancient times; and indeed metal layers are not out of harmony with Hephaestus's other works: the shield-strap of silver (l. 480), the helmet-plume of gold (l. 612), and the leggings or greaves of tin (l. 613). It is usual to assume that the five layers varied in diameter, the largest lying undermost and the others following in order of size. The smallest was a round boss on the outside of the shield. The edges thus formed five concentric rings, and the central boss was encircled by four zones. It is a shield of this pattern that has suggested to archaeologists the common distribution of the scenes on Achilles's shield into five fields.

Reichel, who gives a new interpretation to a)/ntuc, maintains that the a)/ntuga tri/plaka (ll. 479, 480) is a threefold rounded surface (gewölbte Fläche). This, he thinks, means three layers of bronze of decreasing sizes, which probably covered five layers of hide (l. 481). So he has three concentric fields, instead of five, on which to distribute the scenes. Such a shield of hide covered with bronze more nearly resembles the normal Homeric form: the shield of Ajax, for example, may be compared (note on 16.106). But in many other respects Reichel's views about the shield of Achilles are decidedly antagonistic to those generally received.

It has been debated whether the pictures on the shield are altogether a creation of the poet's fancy, or whether they had a basis in fact. On the whole, the most reasonable conclusion is that actual models of the various scenes did exist and had been seen by the poet—whether Phoenician or Egyptian works of art, or Greek imitations, or, as is not improbable, original Greek works of the Mycenaean type. The technique that the poet had in mind is quite probably that seen in the Mycenaean dagger blades, a bronze plate on which are inlaid figures in gold, electrum (an alloy of gold and silver), and a black enamel. (See Tsountas and Manatt. The Mycenaean Age, pp. 201, 202; Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, pp. 229-232.)

The position of the various pictures on the shield is not clearly indi cated by the poet. The ocean, to be sure, he distinctly locates (l. 608) around the rim; and it is a natural inference that the heaven, earth, and sea (ll. 483-489) occupy the center. Beyond this, however, there is no certain clue. On the three zones between the ocean and the central disk the other pictures are to be arranged—from the center outward, as some contend, or from the ocean inward, according to others. Of chief importance to observe is the antithetical arrangement, not only of different scenes in pairs, but even of different parts of the same scene.
The poet's object is evidently to present a view of contemporary life— of the world as he knew it. Conspicuous by their absence are scenes of the sea and ships.

[Among important or recent works on the whole subject: Helbig, Das homerische Epos^{2}, pp. 395-416; Murray, History of Greek Sculpture^{2}. vol. i. chap. iii; E. A. Gardner, Handbook of Greek Sculpture, pp. 69-72; Reichel, Homerische Waffen^{2} (Wien, 1901), pp. 146-165; A. Moret in Revue archèologique, vol. xxxviii (mars-avril, 1901), Quelques scènes du Bouclier d'Achille et les tableaux des tombes égyptiennes. The last named is interesting for its illustrations.]

ἄντυγα ... τρίπλακα, ‘threefold rim.’ The reference may be to three thicknesses of metal about the rim to give strength; or to a threefold ornament of metal rings or bands about the circumference of the shield (Helbig, Hom. Epos^{2}, pp. 385, 386).
ἒκ δ’ (έ), ‘and from it he let hang’; ba/lle, here rendered freely, is understood.
Ὠαρίωνος, MSS. *)wri_/wnos, ‘of Orion.’
ἥ τ’ αὐτοῦ στρέφεται, ‘which turns in the same place.’
In the knowledge of the Homeric Greeks this northern constellation (Ursa Maior) alone did not set; the other northern stars seem not to have been reckoned.
The city in peace, which is placed in contrast with the city in war (ll. 509-540), contains in itself two opposed scenes: the happy marriage (ll. 491-496) and the trial (ll. 497-508).
γάμοι, εἰλαπίναι, etc., the plural seems to refer here, as often, to different parts of but one object; a marriage, a feast, etc.
ἠγίνευν (a)gine/w) for h)gi/neon, § 42.
πολύς, ‘loud.’
βοὴν ἔχον, cf. note on 16.105.
θαύμαζον, ‘gazed in wonder.’

The trial scene begins. No attempt is made in these notes to set forth all the possible interpretations of ll. 497-508. For further explanations reference may be made to Schömann's Antiquities of Greece, English translation by Hardy and Mann (London, 1880), The State, pp. 27, 28; to Walter Leaf, Journal of Hellenic Studies, vol. viii, pp. 122 ff.; and to Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiquities. pp. 407-409. The whole description of the trial scene is so vague and confused that a question has arisen whether the poet was not trying to describe some actually existing work of art of which he but imperfectly understood the meaning. A similar criticism has been applied to others of the scenes also.
εἰν ἀγορᾷ, ‘in the gathering place.’
εἵνεκα ποινῆς, see notes on I 632, 633.
ὃ μὲν εὔχετο κτλ., ‘the one man claimed that he had made payment in full, but the other denied that he had received anything.’
‘And both were eager to get a decision before a referee.’—The literal meaning of πεῖραρ in this instance is probably ‘end.’
ἀμφὶς ἀρωγοί, literally ‘dividedly helping’ (cf. B 13 for a)mfi/s): ‘divided in approval.’ ‘taking sides.’
γέροντες, ‘elders,’ who formed the council.
There was but one scepter, which a herald put into the hand of the elder who was about to speak his judgment. Cf. A 234 ff., 3.218.— κηρύκων, ‘from the heralds.’
τοῖσι, ‘with these [continuing the plural idea, skh=ptra] then they sprang up and in turn gave their decisions.’
δύω χρυσοῖο τάλαντα, not a very large sum in Homer's time. Cf. note on I 122.

‘To give to him among them [the elders] who should speak the most righteous judgment.’ Probably the two talents were deposited at the beginning of the trial, one by each litigant; they seem to be intended for the elder whose decision prevails.

The probable interpretation of the somewhat confused narrative of the siege scene is as follows: The enemy's army in two divisions (du/w stratoi/, l. 509) is besieging a city; they are considering (1) whether to continue their attacks with the hope of ultimately sacking the city, or (2) whether to propose terms of peace, the condition being, after an ancient custom, equal division of property (l. 511) in the city between besiegers and besieged. The citizens, however, who are quite unwilling to come to terms (l. 513), form an ambush near a stream (l. 521), where the enemy's cattle must come for water. The ambush is successful, they capture the cattle (l. 528) and kill the herdsmen (l. 529). The enemy, who are sitting in council, hear the commotion, and hurry (ll. 530-532) to the spot; whereupon a fierce battle is joined (ll. 533-540).

Probably the poet had in mind an actual picture of a siege, in which the city occupied the center of a group, and the enemy held either side; so he speaks of two armies. See the picture in Dr. A. S. Murray's restoration (History of Greek Sculpture, chap. iii) or Helbig's Plate I (Hom. Epos).
δίχα κτλ., they were divided (di/xa = ‘in two ways’) in counsel.

ἄνδιχα πάντα δάσασθαι. Similarly (X 117-120) Hector debates with himself whether he shall try to make terms with the Greeks by proposing to divide equally between them and the Trojans the property of Troy.
ἔεργεν, cf. I 404.
οἳ δ’ (έ), the townspeople, who were being besieged.
λόχῳ, ‘for an ambush.’
515 ῥύατ’(ο), ‘were defending’ § 142.4, b).
ἐφεσταότες, with a)/loxoi and te/kna, an agreement in sense; for te/kna includes ‘boys.’
οἳ δ’ ἴσαν, ‘and the men of the city were going forth’ into ambush.
ἕσθην (e(/nnumi), third person dual of the pluperfect; cf. e(/sso, *g 57.
ἀμφίς, ‘apart,’ not associated with the fighters (Van Leeuwen).
λαοὶ δ’ ὕπ’(ο), ‘and the men beneath,’ i. e. depicted below the gods, who were of towering stature.
‘And when at length they came where there was opportunity [ei)=ke] for them to lie in ambush.’
εἶκε = Attic e)nexw/rei, ‘it was possible.’
τοῖσι δ’(έ), ‘and for them’—the men in ambush.
ἀπάνευθε ... λαῶν, ‘at a distance from the men’ (in ambush).
δέγμενοι, ὁππότε, ‘biding until,’ like I 191. The flocks and herds were the property of the besieging army.
οἳ δέ, the sheep and cattle.
οἳ μέν, the townsmen who were in ambush.
τά refers to the same cattle as oi(\ de/, now regarded as ‘things.’
τάμνοντ’ ἀμφί [for a)mfita/mnont'(o)], ‘cut off,’ ‘made booty of.’
ἔπι, ‘in charge’ of the cattle.
οἳ δ’(έ), the besiegers, whose cattle were being captured.
πολὺν κέλαδον παρὰ βουσίν, ‘great hubbub over the cattle.’
μάχην must be translated with sthsa/menoi, ‘joining battle’; its position would suggest that it be taken with e)ma/xonto as well, as cognate accusative.

ἕλκε (subject, kh/r), in place of which e(/lkousa might be expected; but the poet is busy picturing the scene in striking phrase; he does not take the trouble to heed logical construction (Cauer, Homerkritik, p. 261). Cf. l. 175 and note.
ποδοῖιν § 172), ‘by the feet.’
ὡμίλευν, subject, the men.

ἐτίθει = e)/teuc)(e) (l. 483), poi/hse (l. 490). It is probable that the series of pictures beginning with this line is intended to illustrate occupations of the various seasons (ll. 541-589). Spring is represented by the plowing (ll. 541-549), summer by the reaping and harvest feast (ll. 550-560), autumn by the vintage (ll. 561-572), and winter by the herding (ll. 573589). The last scene is also marked as belonging to winter by the mention of the ‘noisy river’ (potamo\n kela/donta, l. 576), for in Greece the rivers are swollen only at the end of the rainy season of autumn (Reichel).
τοὶ δέ, ‘and others.’
ἀν’ ὄγμους, ‘along the furrows.’
ἀρηρομένῃ κτλ., ‘and it was like real plowed land, although it was made of gold.’
πέρι, ‘exceeding great’ wonder.
μετ’ ὄγμον, ‘after the swath,’ i. e. ‘in swaths.’
πάρεχον, ‘supplied’ sheaves, to the binders.
The feast is prepared with due reference to the sacrificial side (cf. i(ereu/santes), which is regularly seen in Homeric banquets.

‘[Women] were sprinkling white barley in abundance [on the meat] for the reapers' dinner.’ In the Odyssey also (Od. 14.77) we read that Eumaeus, the swineherd, roasted pork for Odysseus; then he served it, all hot; ‘and he sprinkled white barley’ thereon (o(\ d' a)/lfita leuka\ pa/lunen).
ἀνά, ‘throughout it.’
‘And it [the vineyard] was set [or ‘bristled’] everywhere with poles of silver.’

With κυανέην κάπετον understand e)/lassen, for the meaning of which cf. A 575, I 349.—ku/anos was evidently used like the many-hued gold and the tin and the silver, for inlaying; it has been shown to have been a blue glass paste (cf. Schuchhardt, Schliemann's Excavations, pp. 117, 118).
αὐτήν, the vineyard.
ἀταλὰ φρονέοντες, for meaning see foot-note on Z 400.
φέρον, to the wine vat.
ἱμερόεν, a ‘yearning’ melody, cognate accusative with kiqa/rize. The usual translation is ‘lovely’ tune.

ὕπο, ‘to its accompaniment’; the lyre accompanied his song.—The Linus song was a plaintive melody, upparently widely known in very early times. “Linos is the same as *ai)/linos, the refrain of the Phoenician lament (ai lênu, ‘woe to us’) which was introduced into Greece, where it was supposed to mean ‘Woe, Linos.’ Hence the mythical name, Linos. The lament was sung throughout the Semitie world by the women, ‘weeping for Tammuz’” (Sayee, Ancient Empires of the East, Herodotos, 1-111, p. 168). So much for the origin of the name. The meaning of the song to the Greeks themselves is more important. The Argive story (Pausanias, I, 43, 7; cf. II, 19, 8) ran that Linus was the son of Apollo and Psamathe, daughter of a king of Argos; the boy was exposed by his mother for fear of her father and was torn to pieces by shepherd dogs. The story symbolizes the tender bloom of nature which droops and dies before the glowing heat of Sirius, the dog-star.
571, 572. τοὶ δὲ κτλ., ‘while the others [youths and maidens] stamping the ground in unison accompanied the boy with song and plaintive cry, tripping with their feet.’
χρυσοῖο, genitive of material.
κόπρου, ‘cow-yard.’
λαφύσσετον, irregular for lafusse/thn, imperfect, third person dual.
αὔτως, cf. B 342.
δακέειν, ‘as to biting,’ infinitive of specification. The dogs, refusing to bite, were keeping out of the lions' way.
σταθμούς κτλ., “stables, cottages, and cotes” (Chapman). The cottages were roofed (kathrefe/as), the cotes (shkou/s) very likely not.
χορόν, ‘dancing place.’ Some render by ‘dance.’
ἀλλήλων κτλ., ‘taking one another's hands by the wrist.’
λεπτὰς ὀθόνας, ‘fine garments’ of linen.

εἵατ’(ο), pluperfect of e(/nnumi. The youths' tunics, too, were probably made of linen. It would seem that in the process of weaving, the linen threads were sometimes moistened with oil, to make them pliable and shining. So ‘slightly shining with oil’ means that these garments had not yet lost the impress of their dressing of oil, that they were brandnew.
ἐξ, ‘dangling from.’
ὁτὲ μέν, correlative with a)/llote d'(e/) (l. 602), ‘sometimes’ ... ‘and at other times.’
θρέξασκον, see tre/xw.

ἐπισταμένοισι, ‘cunning.’— The meaning is this: the boys and girls at one time would grasp one another's hands, form a circle, and whirl around like a potter's wheel; at another time they would form parallel lines facing each other; then they would run to meet or perhaps pass through each other's line.
ἐπὶ στίχας, ‘in rows,’ ‘in lines,’ like 3.113.
ἀλλήλοισιν, the connection is obscure: interpreting as a)ntime/twpoi a)llh/lois gigno/menoi (scholium) one may translate: ‘forming [in rows] face to face with each other.’
τερπόμενοι, with o(/milos, agreement according to sense.
μολπῆς ἐξάρχοντος, supply a)oidou=, ‘as the minstrel struck up his song.’
ἧκεν, ‘let fall,’ ‘let flow down.’

κνημῖδας κτλ., ‘greaves of pliant tin.’ So greaves as well as baldric (of silver, l. 480) and helmet plume (of gold, l. 612) and shield were extraordinary and more splendid than commonly. See Introduction, 30.
τεύχεα μαρμαίροντα, Vergil's arma radiantia (Aen. VIII, 616).
This line marks the beginning of the twenty-seventh day of the poem—the fourth day of battle, which is the last that the Iliad contains. The day is not ended until the twenty-second book (X) is done.
ἣ δ’(έ), Thetis.
ἐάσομεν = e)a/swmen.
ἐπεὶ δὴ πρῶτα, ‘since once for all,’ like A 235.
δέξο, § 131.

ὡς ... ὥς, like A 512, 513.—With the sentiment a scholiast compares Od. 16.294 (= Od. 19.13): au)to\s ga\r e)fe/lketai a)/ndra si/dhros, ‘steel alone draws a man to itself,’ i. e. even the sight of weapons fires men. Compare note on 18.34.
οἷ̓ ἐπιεικὲς κτλ., ‘such as 'tis meet for the works of the immortals to be, but for no mortal man to finish.’
μοι, ‘before my eyes,’ or ‘ah me!’ Cf. 18.61.

υἱόν is naturally and simply taken as object of kaddu=sai (katadu=sai) in the next line; like katadu=sa *dio\s do/mon (8.375), ‘entering the house of Zeus.’ Cf. min ... e)/du, l. 16. Some editors prefer to make it divide with nekro/n (l. 26) the function of object of a)eiki/sswsi.
ἒκ δ’ αἰὼν πέφαται (root fen), ‘for his life is slain and fled’ (e)/k).— σαπήῃ, supply nekro/s as subject.
τῷ, ‘for him,’ i. e. ‘from him.’
μυίας, in apposition to fu=la (l. 30), instead of muia/wn, as B 469.
κῆται, probably for an original ke/etai = kei/etai, subjunetive of kei=mai.
αἰεὶ τῷδ’ ἔσται κτλ., ‘always shall his flesh be sound [as now] or even better’ than now; for the gods are all-powerful; qeoi\ de/ te pa/nta du/nantai (Od. 10.306).
ἀποειπών, with ictus on o. § 39. Cf. smerdale/a i)a/xwn (l. 41).
κατὰ ῥινῶν, ‘down through the nostrils.’ For the embalming see note on 16.456.
The sense is: even those that formerly remained behind among the collected ships on this occasion went to the assembly (l. 45).
43, 44. ‘Both those that were pilots and held the rudders of the ships and those that were stewards.’
δέ, ‘although,’ like 18.248.
Diomedes had been wounded by Paris in the foot with an arrow (11.377); Odysseus had been hit by Socus in the side with a spear (11.437).
μετὰ πρώτῃ ἀγορῇ, ‘in the front of the assembly,’ a place of distinction.
56, 57. ἦ ἄρ τι κτλ., ‘as it now appears [a)/r], was this strife [to/de] really [h)=] better for us both, for you and for me, when we two’ etc.
61, 62. τῷ, ‘then.’—ὀδὰξ ἕλον κτλ., ‘would have bitten the immeasurable earth, at the hands of their enemies’; the poet has in mind the throes of death.
ἐμεῦ ἀπομηνίσαντος, cf. I 426.
μέν, ‘to be sure.’
τό, ‘this,’ i. e. the matter of our strife; supply h)=n.
Cf. note on 16.60.
οὐδέ τί με χρή, cf. I 496, 16.721.

ἰαυέμεν, the poet seems to have in mind the boastful words of Polydamas (18.259), when he puts this expression into the mouth of Achilles. —ἀλλά τιν’ οἴω κτλ., ‘but I think many a one will joyfully bend his knees to rest.’ Compare with the idea here expressed 18.270 f. The strain of flight on the Trojans' part is imagined as intense.
αἰψηρήν, adjective in sense of adverb, ‘quickly.’

δῶρα: these are the gifts which were once before (in I) offered to Achilles through Odysseus, and rejected by him. But now (in T) Odysseus, accompanied by the sons of Nestor and other Greeks, has brought them from Agamemnon's lodge to Achilles, in the assembly. The poet enumerated them a few lines before this:
e(pta\ me\n e)k klisi/hs tri/podas fe/ron ou(/s oi( u(pe/sth,
ai)/qwnas de\ le/bhtas e)ei/kosi, dw/deka d' i(/ppous:
e)k d; a)/gon ai)=ya gunai=kas a)mu/mona e)/rga i)dui/as
e(/pt', a)ta\r o)gdoa/thn *brishi/da kallipa/rh|on.
xrusou= de\ sth/sas *)oduseu\s de/ka pa/nta ta/lanta
h)=rx', a(/ma d' a)/lloi dw=ra fe/ron kou/rhtes *)axaiw=n (T 243-248).
Agamemnon then sacrificed and swore a solemn oath that he had not laid hand on Briseis (ll. 249-266). Cf. I 264-276.
εἰς ἀγέλην: Achilles seems to have had a number of horses taken from the enemy, apparently chariot-steeds whose masters he had slain.
ἀμφ’ αὐτῷ χυμένη (xe/w), similar in meaning to *patro/klw| perikei/menon (l. 4).
Πάτροκλε, note the short penult § 4).—μοι δειλῇ κτλ., ‘dearest to my wretched heart.’
δειλῇ of course agrees with moi.—For construction of θυμῷ compare A 24.
ἂψ ἀνιοῦς’(α), ‘on my return’; she has been absent since A 348.
ὥς μοι κτλ., ‘how evil after evil always waits on me!’
ἄνδρα, perhaps Mynes (l. 296); but Homer does not inform us.
μοι μία ... μήτηρ, cf. 3.238.

With kasignh/tous (l. 293) a participle in agreement—like dedai+gme/nous—after ei)=don (l. 292) would be expected; instead the poet breaks off the grammatical sequence (making an “anacoluthon’) and begins a new sentence at this point: οἳ πάντες, ‘they all.’
κλαίειν, to be taken closely with e)/askes (l. 295).
ἄξειν: editors commonly supply ‘Achilles’ as subject of this infinitive and of dai/sein (l. 299); the sudden change of subject is not at all un-Homeric.
λέπαδν’(α), ‘breast-bands,’ broad strips of leather passing about the breasts and shoulders of horses, like collars, and fastened to the yoke. See illustration in the Vocabulary.
ἕσαν, ‘put,’ ‘set,’ commonly taken as aorist of i(/hmi, may also come from e(/nnumi or e(/zw.
ἐφ’ ἵπποιιν, ‘on the chariot,’ as usual.
‘Now bethink yourselves how to save your charioteer in some other [i. e. ‘better’] way’ than you cared for Patroclus.
σαωσέμεν is probably a mixed aorist infinitive § 153). By ‘charioteer’ Achilles means himself, although strictly the word designates Automedon.
ζεύγλης, perhaps the cushion under the yoke to ease the horses' necks. See the Vocabulary.
A reminder of Thetis's words, 18.96.
θεός, cf. note on l. 417.
νῶι δὲ καί κτλ., ‘for we two would race even with the blast of Zephyrus.’ their father, according to 16.150.
θεῷ τε καὶ ἀνέρι, it is the dying Hector who reveals their names: *pa/ris kai\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, X 359.

ἐρινύες κτλ., ‘the Erinyes restrained his voice,’ for, says the scholiast, they are watchful against violations of the law of nature. There is no doubt that Homer has lately been lapsing into fairy-land.
ὅ = o(/ti.
πρὶν Τρῶας ἅδην ἐλάσαι πολέμοιο, ‘until I have given the Trojans quite enough of war’; a(/dhn (originally an accusative) e)la/sai means literally^{4} to drive to satiety.’
See note on T 1.
πεφυζότες, ‘panic-stricken’; cf. fu/za, I 2.
Φοῖβος Ἀπόλλων, who had assumed the likeness of Trojan Agenor (as related 21.600).

αὐτὸς θνητὸς ἐών agrees with the subject of diw/keis (l. 8); θεὸν ἄμβροτον, with the object me (l. 8). ‘And have you not even yet discovered [me = me, an instance of prolepsis] that I am a god?’ asks Apollo in derision.
Another taunting question: ‘really now, are you not at all interested in the battle with the Trojans, whom you have routed?’
Τρώων πόνος = to\ kata\ tw=n *trw/wn e)/rgon (scholium). *trw/wn seems to be objective genitive.
ἄλεν, εἴλω.
τοι μόρσιμος, ‘at your hand doomed to die.’
ἦ κτλ., ‘else surely’ etc.
τίσιν, accusative of ti/sis.
τισαίμην ... παρείη, probably both verbs would be imperfect indicatives in Attic Greek § 207.1), as protasis and apodosis of a present contrary to fact condition.
μέγα φρονέων, ‘in high spirits.’
Note quantity of ultima of σευάμενος.—Regularly two horses draw the Homeric chariot; to one of such a pair Achilles is compared.
τιταινόμενος πεδίοιο, ‘stretching over the plain’ § 171), i. e. galloping at full speed.
λαιψηρά, for laiyhrw=s.
πεδίοιο, as in l. 23.
ώς τ’ ἀστέῤ (l. 26), ὅς ῥα κτλ., ‘like the star that rises in the late summer-time.’
ὀπώρης, genitive of “time within which.”
τέτυκται = e)sti/.

Imitated by Vergil, Aen. X, 273 f.:
Sirius ardor,
Ille sitim morbosque ferens mortalibus aegris.
‘The heat of Sirius—that brings thirst and plagues to wretched men.’
ἀνασχόμενος, object understood, xei=ras.
ἐγεγώνει (from ge/gwna), ‘he called out.’
μοι, dative of person interested: ‘I pray you.’
ἀνέρα τοῦτον, ‘the man yonder,’ your foe.

σχέτλιος, an exclamation: ‘implacable’ (Achilles)! Cf. I 639.— αἴθε θεοῖσι κτλ., a grim wish, the sting lying in o(/sson e)moi/ (l. 42). It amounts to ei)/qe e)xqro\s toi=s qeoi=s ge/noito (scholium).
Lycaon and Polydorus have both been slain by Achilles in the course of the present day's battle.
ἀλέντων (ei)/lw), genitive absolute with *trw/wn.
ἦ τ’ ... ἔπειτα, ‘surely in that case.’
πολλά, a ‘large dowry’; see note on l. 472.
πρὸς δ’(έ), ‘and besides.’ pro/s is an adverb here.—‘Have pity on me, unfortunate that I am [τὸν δύστηνον], while I yet live.’
ἐπὶ γήραος οὐδῷ, ‘on the threshold of old age,’ i. e. at the end of life, when one's race has been run; the threshold from which one steps into death.
ἐπ-ιδόντα, ‘after beholding’ many evils, which are enumerated in the following lines.
ἑλκηθείσας, cf. Z 465.
νυούς, ‘daughters-in-law.’
πρώτῃσι θύρῃσιν, ‘at the front gate,’ the entrance into the courtyard (au)lh/), guarded by great folding doors (qu/rh|sin); also referred to below (l. 71), e)n proqu/roisi.
ἂν (l. 66) ... e)ru/ousin, future indicative § 190).
τύψας ἠὲ βαλών, ‘smiting’ (perhaps with a sword) ‘or hitting from afar’ (as with a hurled spear); so the words are commonly distinguished; cf. note on O 745.
οἵ, ‘these,’ i. e. the dogs.
πέρι, like 16.157.
κ’(ε) (l. 70) ... kei/sont'(αι), § 190.—νέῳ δέ τε κτλ., ‘but for a young man it is in all respects becoming’ etc.
πάντα, subject of e)sti/, to be supplied.
ὅττι φανήῃ, ‘whatever appears.’

κόλπον ἀνιεμένη, ‘undoing the bosom’ or ‘baring the bosom.’ Perhaps with her left hand Hecabe unclasped her peplus at the right shoulder; then with the right hand (e(te/rhfi) she lifted up her breast. Her left breast remained covered. On women's dress see Introduction, 17.
ἑτέρηφι, literally ‘with her other’ (hand).
τάδε, ‘this breast of mine.’
ἐπέσχον, in meaning the same as e)pisxw/n, I 489.
φίλε τέκνον, agreement according to sense, as below (l. 87), qa/los, o(/n.
μηδὲ πρόμος κτλ., ‘and do not stand as champion against this foe.’ Cf. l. 38.
σχέτλιος, cf. l. 41.
οὐδ’ ἄλοχος πολύδωρος, supply klau/setai.—For πολύδωρος cf. note on Z 394.
ἄνευθε ... μέγα νῶιν, ‘very far from us.’
πολλά, for quantity of ultima see § 38.
βεβρωκὼς κακὰ φάρμακ’(α) = Vergil's “mala gramina pastus” (Aen. II, 471).
ἑλισσόμενος περὶ χειῇ, ‘coiling around in his hole,’ cf. A 317.
The speech of Polydamas occurs in 18.254 ff.
ὕπο, ‘during.’
τήνδ’(ε), the night just past.

ἄντην, with an understood e)lqo/nta, agreeing (as does kataktei/nanta) with e)me/, the understood subject of ne/esqai: it would be far better for me to meet Achilles ‘face to face’ and then to slay him and return, or to be slain by him in a glorious struggle.

αὐτῷ may be dative of agent with o)le/sqai (cf. *)axilh=i damasqei/s, l. 55); or it may be taken with e)moi/ (l. 108) in the sense, ‘or myself to be slain.’—The force of κεν is not obvious, for the infinitive does not stand in indirect discourse. The reading may be wrong.
A long protasis begins here and continues through l. 121; there the construction abruptly ends. The poet neglects to supply the apodosis.
ἀντίος ἔλθω, like a)nti/os e)lqw/n, B 185, with genitive.
Ἑλένην καὶ κτήμαθ’ (= kth/mata), objects of dwse/men (l. 117), which is an infinitive in indirect discourse after u(po/sxwmai.

ἥ τ’ ἔπλετο νείκεος ἀρχή, ‘which [i. e. the carrying off of Helen and the treasures] was the beginning of the strife.’ The relative agrees with the predicate noun; its antecedent is the general idea that has preceded, rather than any particular word or words.
117, 118. Ἀτρεΐδῃσιν, indirect object of dwse/men.
ἄγειν expresses purpose.—Before ἅμα δ’ ἀμφίς understand ei) de/ ken u(po/sxwmai, ‘and if I promise that at the same time we will divide the other treasures equally with the Achaeans.’

ἀμφίς means here (as 18.502, B 13) ‘into two [op posed] parts.’ The same sort of proposition for raising a siege was alluded to in 18.511; and perhaps, as a scholiast suggests, the half of the wealth of Troy is the poinh/ which Agamemnon announced that he would fight for (3.290).
Τρωσίν, ‘from the Trojans.’
μετόπισθε, ‘afterward.’
γερούσιον ὅρκον, ‘an oath sworn by the elders’ in behalf of the people.—With e(/lwmai understand ei) de/ ken.
This verse, wanting in the best MS., Venetus A, and others, may have crept in from 18.512.

‘I fear I shall come and supplicate him, while he will not pity me,’ Hector's hurried way of saying, ‘I fear that when I come’ etc., ‘he will not pity me.’ With this use of the independent subjunctive with mh/, implying fear, compare B 195, 16.128, 18.8, and GMT. 261. But according to Kühner-Gerth § 394.4, b), mh\ ... i(/kwmai is a hortatory subjunctive, like du/w. Z 340, i)/dwm)(ai), X 450; the meaning then would be: ‘let me not’ or ‘I will not come and supplicate him, for he will not pity me.’
αὔτως, ‘just as I am,’ i. e. unarmed.
‘By no means may I now chat with him, “beginning at the oak or rock,” as a maid and a lad gossip.’

ἀπὸ δρυὸς οὐδ’ ἀπὸ πέτρης ὀαριζέμεναι is a gnomic expression (paroimi/a) which seems to allude to old folk-stories (e. g. how the first men grew out of trees and rocks). A scholiast interprets it, lhrw=des a)rxaiologi/as dihgei=sqai, which amounts pretty nearly to ‘make silly gossip over ancient stories.’ Some prefer to interpret the words literally of a maid and a young shepherd talking ‘from an oak or rock’ where they are sitting.
εἴδομεν (i. e. ei)dw=men), cf. Z 340 and § 193.
Πηλιάδα μελίην, cf. 16.143 f.
φοβηθείς, ‘in flight.’

Cf. Verg. Aen. XI, 721 ff.:
quam facile accipiter saxo sacer ales ab alto
consequitur pennis sublimem in nube columbam,
comprensamque tenet pedibusque eviscerat uncis.
‘As easily as the falcon, bird of augury, from his high cliff overtakes in flight a dove soaring in the clouds, and seizes and holds her, and rends her with his crooked talons.’
ὀξὺ λεληκώς (la/skw), ‘with shrill cry.’
ταρφέ’(α), ‘again and again.’
ἐρινεόν, mentioned Z 433.
They ran along the wagon-road under the city-wall; yet the road seems to have been somewhat distant from the wall.
For quantity of ultima of ἀναΐσσουσι see note on B 465.
θέρεϊ, ‘in the summer.’
ἐπ’ αὐτάων ... ἐγγύς, ‘near by them.’
With φεύγων supply o(\ me/n, i. e. Hector

ποσσίν, ‘in the foot-race.’ Cf. Verg. Aen. XII, 764 f.:
neque enim levia aut ludicra petuntur
praemia, sed Turni de vita et sanguine certant,

said of the struggle between Aeneas and Turnus.
No trivial prize is play'd, for on the life
Or death of Turnus, now depends the strife.—Dryden.
τό is demonstrative, agreeing with a)/eqlon. A free rendering is ‘there.’
ἀνδρός limits a)/eqlon, a prize “in grateful honour of the mighty dead” (Pope). The allusion is to funeral games.
δαμάσσομεν, for meaning cf. 16.438.
Τριτογένεια: this epithet, best rendered ‘Tritogeneia,’ was not quite understood by the Greeks themselves. See note on B 103.
θυμῷ πρόφρονι, ‘in earnest.’
The poet who describes this race can hardly have thought of the heroes as armed with the big, heavy shields.
ὄρεσφι = e)n o)/resi or dia\ o)re/wn.
Homer uses dia\ with accusative where Attie Greek uses the genitive. Cf. note on B 57.
ἀλλά, ‘yet’ the dog.

194-196. ‘And as often as he made for the Dardanian gate, to dash before it [i. e. ‘to take refuge’] under the well-built towers, in the hope that’ etc. o(rma/w with the genitive is illustrated also in 4.335, *trw/wn o(rmh/seie, ‘make for the Trojans.’—It is possible, however, to understand ἀίξασθαι as complementary infinitive, so that the construction becomes, ‘and as often as he started to rush before the Dardanian gates’; then pula/wn would limit a)nti/on.—For Δαρδανιάων see note on B 809.
οἱ, ‘from him.’
‘Just so often Achilles headed him off [parafqa/s] before [propa/roiqen] he escaped, and drove him back [a)postre/yaske] to the plain.’
ποτὶ πτόλιος, ‘on the side of the city,’ i. e. on the inside.

Cf. Verg. Aen. XII, 908-914:
Ac velut in somnis, oculos ubi languida pressit
nocte quies, nequiquam avidos extendere cursus
velle videmur, et in mediis conatibus aegri
auccidimus, non lingua valet, non corpore notae
sufficiunt vires, nec vox aut verba sequuntur:
sic Turno, quacumque viam virtute petivit,
cuccessum dea dira negat.
And as, when heavy sleep has clos'd the sight,
The sickly fancy labours in the night:
We seem to run; and destitute of force,
Our sinking limbs forsake us in the course:
In vain we heave for breath; in vain we cry:
The nerves unbrac'd their usual strength deny,
And on the tongue the faultering accents die:
So Turnus far'd, whatever means he try'd,
All force of arms, and points of art employ'd,
The fury flew athwart, and made th' endeavour void.—Dryden.
δύναται, supply tis.
ὅ ... τόν ... ὅ, ‘the one’ ... ‘the other’ ... ‘the other.’
ὅ, Achilles; τόν, Hector; οὐδ’ ὅς, ‘nor the latter’ (Hector).
‘How would Hector have escaped death’—not ultimately, of course, but—‘even up to this time unless’ etc.?
ἀνένευε, ‘nodded “no.”’
ἕλκε δὲ μέσσα λαβών, ‘and taking them [ta/lanta, the balances] by the middle, he raised them up.’ The heavier fate was the doomed one.
ᾤχετο, subject, ai)/simon h)=mar, i. e. kh/r.
217. νῶι ἔολπα ... οἴσεσθαι κτλ., ‘I think that we two shall carry off great glory’ etc.
πεφυγμένον γενέσθαι, cf. Z 488.
220 μάλα πολλὰ πάθοι, ‘should give himself ever so much trouble.’
ἠθεῖ’(ε), cf. Z 518.

στέωμεν, second aorist subjunctive of i(/sthmi. A preferable spelling would be the regular sth/omen § 149), with h pronounced short, as in dh/ios often; some MSS. in fact read ste/omen. The form in the text must be pronounced with synizesis.
γνωτῶν, ‘brothers,’ as in 3.174.
νοέω φρεσί = e)n nw=| e)/xw.
ὅς, irregularly lengthened.
ς’(ε) ... fobh/somai, ‘will flee from you.’
ἕλοιμι, in sense of ‘slay’; its passive is a(loi/hn.
θεοὺς ἐπιδώμεθα (e)pi-di/dwmi), ‘let us take the gods to ourselves’ as witnesses: ‘let us make’ them ‘our’ witnesses.
ἁρμονιάων, used only here in the figurative meaning, ‘compact.’
φιλή-μεναι, § 131.
ἕτερον, ‘either you or I’; cf. E 288, 289.

παντοίης κτλ., cf. Matthew Arnold's Sohrab and Rustum:
Speak not to me of truce, and pledge, and wine!
Remember all thy valour; try thy feints
And cunning!
δαμάει, future § 151).
ἠλεύατο, ἀλέομαι.
οὐδ’ ἄρα πώ τι ... ἠείδης, ‘and after all, it seems, you do not know’ etc. Cf. note on 3.183.
ἠείδης, § 136.10.
ἦ τοι ἔφης γε, ‘to be sure [or ‘although’] you thought you did.’ Cf. 16.61, 3.215.

ἐπίκλοπος ... μύθων, ‘deceitful of speech’; with τις, ‘a man of cunning words.’ You think you can frighten me by your bold speech so that I shall run, as before; and then you may transfix me as I flee; but you shall not (l. 283); I will face you squarely now (l. 284).
ἰθὺς μεμαῶτι (moi), ‘as I press straight on’ to meet you.—do/ru is understood with ἔλασσον.
εἴ τοι ἔδωκε θεός, in ironical reference to ll. 270 f., where Achilles boasts of Athene as his ally.
ὡς ... κομίσαιο, for construction see note on 18.107.
οὐδ’ ἄλλ̓ ἔχε μείλινον ἔγχος: what had become of his second spear, if he carried one, the poet does not say. See note on 16.477.
In 11.32-35 Agamemnon's shield is described; ‘and on it were twenty bosses of tin, all white.’ In this description there is a suggestion as to the meaning of λευκάσπιδα.
ἦ γάρ κτλ., ‘long since, it seems, this must have been the pleasure of Zeus’ etc. The comparative φίλτερον means that this doom of Hector ‘rather’ than any other fate was the pleasure of Zeus.
‘But [only] when I have done some great deed and one for men hereafter to learn of.’ Cf. B 119.
How may one account for the quantity of τό? § 37.
ἀλείς, ‘gathering himself together,’ from ei)/lw.
πρόσθεν ... κάλυψεν, for meaning compare note on E 315.
τετραφάλῳ, see Introduction, 33.
ἃς ... ἵει ... θαμείας, ‘which [plumes] Hephaestus let fall thick’ etc.
ἀπέλαμπ’(ε), supply se/las, ‘radiance,’ as subject—unless the verb be used impersonally.
ὅπῃ εἴξειε μάλιστα, to find ‘where it [xrw/s] would best give way’ to his spear. Or the verb may be used impersonally (cf. 18.520), ‘where there was the best opportunity.’
This difficult line seems to contain two expressions, parallel in meaning, either of which may be eliminated without affecting the sense:
(a) tou= de\ kai\ a)/llo me\n e)/xe xro/a xa/lkea teu/xh, ‘now bronze armor protected his body in other parts’ [literally ‘as for the rest’].
(b) tou= de\ kai\ to/son me\n e)/xe xro/a xa/lkea teu/xh, ‘now bronze armor protected nearly all [literally ‘so far protected’] his body.’
Construction (b) has been explained in a note on 18.378; it occurs also in 4.130. The combination of the two is found again in 23.454.
φαίνετο δ’(έ), subject, xrw/s: ‘but his flesh was exposed’; we say, ‘he was exposed.’—ᾗ κληῖδες κτλ., ‘where the collar-bones part the neck from the shoulders.’
λαυκανίην, ‘at the gullet,’ may be regarded as an appositive to au)xe/n'(a) (l. 324). This construction has been from ancient times recognized as difficult.
ἵνα τε κτλ., Vergil's qua fata celerrima (Aen. XII, 507).
ὄφρα κτλ., the purpose is not that of the spear (meli/h, l. 328), but of the fate (moi=ra, l. 303) that directed it.
333, 334. τοῖο δ’ ἄνευθεν κτλ., ‘while distant from him I—his avenger, far mightier [than you]—was left behind at the hollow ships.’
με (l. 342) ... lela/xwsi (lagxa/nw), ‘make me to share in,’ ‘may give me my portion’ of fire. For Homeric burial customs see note on 16.456.
γούνων, cf. l. 338.

346-348. ‘Would that anger and rage drove me—even me—to slice your flesh and eat it raw, for what you have done me, as surely as there is none that will ward the dogs from your head!’ For the construction compare 18.464-466, with notes.
στήσως’(ι) (i(/sthmi), ‘weigh.’
οὐδ’ ὣς κτλ., ‘not even at this price’ shall your mother place you on a funeral bed.
πάντα, agreeing with se understood.
προτι-όσσομαι, ‘I gaze upon’ you.
τοί τι θεῶν μήνιμα, ‘a cause of wrath against you on the part of the gods.’
θεῶν, subjective genitive. The sense is, consider lest my death shall stir the gods to wrath against you.
Cf. note on 16.857.
πλησίον ἄλλον, cf. B 271.
μαλακώτερος ἀμφαφάεσθαι, is ‘softer to handle.’
τις, ‘many a man.’
ἐπεί, first in the line, in spite of the short initial syllable § 36).
κακὰ πόλλ’ ... ὅς’ οὐ, ‘more evils than.’
εἰ δ’ ἄγετ’(ε), cf. note on A 302.
καὶ Ἕκτορος κτλ., the genitive absolute here expresses concession.
ἄκλαυτος, ‘unwept,’ in the ceremonial way.
The subject of καταλήθοντ’(αι) is indefinite: “they,” i. e. ‘the dead.’ qano/ntes.
μήδετο, with two accusatives, ‘devised ... for.’
ποδῶν limits τένοντε, ‘the tendons of both feet.’
ἐξῆπτεν, ‘attached thereto.’
μάστιξέν ῥ̓ ἐλάειν, supply i(/ppous as subject of the infinitive, which is intransitive, ‘he whipped his steeds to a run.’
τοῦ δ’ ... ἑλκομένοιο, with koni/salos, ‘and from him as he was being dragged a cloud of dust arose.’
καλύπτρην, see Introduction, 21.
κωκυτῷ ... οἰμωγῇ, datives of manner and means, ‘were overcome with wailing and lamentation’; the former is used of the women, as the scholiast says, the latter of the men.
τῷ is neuter: ‘and it was quite like to this, as if’ etc. The sense is: such cries of grief were heard as would be raised if all beetling Troy were blazing in fire from the citadel down.

κόπρον, ‘dirt’ or ‘dust.’ The expression kulindo/menos kata\ ko/pron has many ancient parallels, e. g. Jeremiah vi, 26: “O daughter of my people, gird thee with sackcloth, and wallow thyself in ashes.” Micah i, 10: “In the house of Aphrah roll thyself in the dust.”
σχέσθε, ‘hold off.’
λίσσωμ’(αι), § 193.
τοιόσδε, ‘such as I,’ ‘as gray as I.’
τῶν, genitive of cause. Compare Hector's words to Andromache, Z 450-454.
ou(= ... a)/xos, ‘grief for whom’ (objective genitive).
ὡς ὄφελεν, what sort of wish? § 203.
τῷ κε κορεσσάμεθα, ‘then we should have satisfied ourselves,’ ‘have had our fill.’
ἁδινοῦ κτλ., see note on 18.316.
βείομαι, probably parallel with be/omai. See note on 16.852.
δειδέχατ’(ο), for the form see I 224 and 671.
Ἕκτορος limits pe/pusto § 174.1).
δίπλακα πορφυρέην, cf. 3.126.
So when Euryalus's mother heard of his death (Verg. Aen. IX, 476), excussi manibus radii, ‘the shuttle fell from her hands.’
ἴδωμ’(αι), for subjunctive see § 193.
ὅτιν’(α) = Attie a(/tina § 124).
451, 452. ἐν δέ μοι κτλ., ‘and in my own breast my heart bounds up to my mouth.’
αἲ γὰρ ἀπ’ οὔατος κτλ., cf. note on 18.272.

μιν καταπαύσῃ ἀγηνορίης ἀλεγεινῆς, lest he ‘have checked him from his woful valor.’ Andromache uses a)legeinh=s with reference to herself, meaning th=s e)moi\ luphra=s (scholium), ‘that causes me distress,’ because it carries Hector into danger.
τὸ ὃν μένος κτλ., ‘yielding in that mighty spirit of his to none.’— μένος is accusative of specification.
δέσματα is a general word, to which a)/mpuka (l. 469), etc., are in apposition. Apparently the poet gives here the complete head-dress of an Homeric woman.

ἄμπυκα seems to indicate the same as stefa/nh (cf. 18.597), a metal diadem, especially of gold. Helbig, explaining differently from Studniczka, illustrates kekru/falon and plekth\n a)nade/smhn from Etruscan monuments, suggesting that the former was a high, stiff cap, around which was wound the twisted band (plekth\ a)nade/smh), both useful and decorative (Das homerische Epos^{2}, pp. 219-226).
κρήδεμνον, see Introduction, 21.
Ἠετίωνος, see Z 395.

ἕδνα, gifts of cattle, etc., originally paid by the suitor to the bride's father, to win his bride. In the course of the Homeric age—centuries long—the practice of buying the bride, which is here distinctly referred to, underwent a change, as did many other ancient Homeric customs. It is certainly true that the Homeric poetry continued into a time when the old custom was abandoned and that of historic Greece the rule; that is, into a period when, so far from having to purchase his bride, the suitor received a dowry along with her at the time of marriage. To the older period belongs the adjective a)lfesi/boiai (18.593). But to the new custom there are distinct references in X 51,
polla\ ga\r w)/pase paidi\ ge/rwn o)noma/klutos *)/alths,
and I 147 f., e)gw\ d' e)/pi mei/lia dw/sw polla\ ma/l), o(/ss) ou)/ pw/ tis e(h=| e)pe/dwke qugatri/.
(Cf. Cauer, Homerkritik, pp. 187-195.)
ἀτυζομένην ἀπολέσθαι § 212) ‘dazed unto death,’ i. e. so that she was like one dead.
ἰῇ ... αἴσῃ, ‘for one and the same portion,’ or ‘doom.’
νήπιος αὔτως, cf. Z 400.
φύγῃ, ‘survives’; subject, the child Astyanax.
τοι, remote dative of the person interested, ‘you know he will always have toil and distress hereafter.’
ἀπουρήσουσιν, § 63.3.
πάντα, ‘completely,’ adverbial.
‘Pulling one by the cloak, and another by the tunic.’

494, 495. ‘And among them, when they are touched with pity, one puts a cup to his [i. e. the boy's] lips for a little time, and moistens his lips, to be sure, but does not moisten his palate.’ For meaning of e)pe/sxen cf. l. 83 of this book and I 489; for the tense see § 184.
οὕτως, for meaning cf. 18.392, w(=de.

With this line the description of the orphaned boy returns to Astyanax. From l. 487 to l. 499 the description has been of a general character, and is certainly inapplicable to any probable situation of Priam's grandson Astyanax, even if he should lose his father. Aristarchus was for removing these lines altogether.
ἂν ... πάθῃσι, ‘he shall suffer,’ § 192.
ὄφελος, for construction cf. ph=ma, *g 50.
εἶναι, ‘that they may be.’

div1.head: Book 24 (Ω)
div1.p: It is in the evening of the thirty-eighth day of the poem that Priam comes to ransom Hector.

div2.p: ἔν = e)/ndon.
μιν, Achilles.
εὗρ’(ε), subject, Priam.
480, 481. ‘And as when dense blindness of heart seizes a man, so that he slays a fellow in his fatherland and comes to the land of strangers.’
ἀμῦναι expresses purpose.
ἰῆς ἐκ νηδύος, of Hecabe (Hecuba).
καὶ αὐτός, ‘even alone.’
αὐτόν, supply me.

χεῖῤ = xei=re: ‘to take to my lips the hands of the man that has murdered my sons.’ Compare l. 478. Others understand xei=r) = xei=ra (or read xei/r) = xeiri/), and translate: ‘to reach [with] my hand to the mouth [or ‘chin’] of the man’ etc., comparing A 501.
ἐλυσθείς, ‘rolled up.’ “Low on earth” (Pope).
κατακεῖσθαι, ‘to sleep,’ undisturbed.
‘For no good comes of’ etc.
κακῶν, supply e(/teros me/n, ‘the one.’
ἐάων, § 99.
‘To whomsoever Zeus gives of these, when he has mingled them’ (i. e. the good and the bad gifts).
τερπικέραυνος, § 59.—On this story of the jars is perhaps founded the Epimetheus-Pandora myth, that appears first in Hesiod, Works and Days, ll. 69-104.
ἐπ’(ί), ‘extending over,’ ‘among.’
εἶναι, imperfect infinitive, ‘were.’
‘All the territory that Lesbos bounds’ (e)nto\s e)e/rgei).
ἄνω (limiting e)e/rgei) = ‘upward,’ from the south, Lesbos being a southern boundary.
καὶ Φρυγίη καθύπερθε, ‘and Phrygia on the east,’ according to a scholiast; the poet “bounds the kingdom of Priam on the south by Lesbos, on the east by Phrygia, and on the north by the Hellespont.”

τῶν, the inhabitants of the region just defined, genitive (here only) with keka/sqai: ‘among people of this region you used to rank first, they say, in wealth and sons.’—On κεκάσθαι cf. ei)=nai (l. 543).
πρὶν καὶ κακὸν κτλ., cf. A 29. For the subjunctive cf. § 191.
σὺ δὲ τῶνδ’ ἀπόναιο, ‘and may you have joy of this’ (ransom).
ἔασας, ‘spared.’
Bracketed because missing in many MSS., and evidently added by somebody who misunderstood the meaning of e)/asas (l. 557) and thought the sense must be somehow completed.
σέ, an instance of anticipation (prolepsis): ‘I know that a god led you hither.’ Cf. note on B 409.
ἐάσω, in meaning like e)/asas, l. 557.
καὶ ἱκέτην κτλ., ‘even though you are a suppliant.’
κήρυκα, Idaeus, crier of the aged king (toi=o ge/rontos).
δοίη, subject, Achilles.
καὶ τῶνδ’(ε), ‘even of these treasures,’ in an offering to the dead.
ἔνθεν, ‘from which.’
τοίχου τοῦ ἑτέρου, see note on I 219.
τῇ περ κτλ., ‘although her twelve children’ etc.
τεκέειν, understand Leto as subject.

614-617. These lines look like a later addition to the story just recited; for nothing has previously been said which would lead one to believe that Niobe herself was turned to stone; in fact the point of the whole recital lies in the statement that Niobe forgot her sorrow enough to eat food (l. 613). And how could a stone eat food? as a scholiast pertinently suggests. The Alexandrians (Aristophanes, Aristarchus) rejected the lines altogether.

A later myth does make Niobe herself one of those turned to stone. The scholiast, repeating her story, adds: “So Zeus took pity on Niobe who was weeping over such a great misfortune and changed her to stone, as even up to the present time she is seen by all on Phrygian [th=s *frugi/as] Sipylus, shedding fountains of tears.” Pausanias (2d century A. D.) was acquainted with this Niobe, and repeats the story of the tears (I, 21, 5; VIII, 2, 3), evidently alluding to a stream of water trickling down over a face of natural rock. But it seems to be hardly possible to-day to identify “with any approach to certainty or even probability” such a Niobe as he describes. The (formerly) so-called Niobe of Mt. Sipylus is really a sculpture representing “Mother Plastene,” i. e. Cybele [cf. Frazer, Pausanias's Description of Greece (London, 1898), vol. iii, pp. 552-555].
ἐρρώσαντο, here ‘dance’ § 184).
θεῶν ἒκ κήδεα πέσσει, ‘she nurses her god-given sorrows.’
ὅσσος ἔην οἷός τε, ‘how tall and how handsome he was.’
λέξον, root lex, ‘make me to lie down,’ ‘give me a bed.’

With this long wakefulness of Priam a scholiast compares the vigil of Odysseus, who, while piloting his raft, went without sleep for seventeen days, and then swam with the aid of a life-buoy (Leucothea's veil) for three days continuously (Od. 5.278, 279, 388 ff.).
αἰθούσῃ, see notes on l. 673 and Z 243.—The lodge of Achilles grows in grandeur, as the poet proceeds. It is described as if furnished like the Homeric prince's palace, in many respects.
The τάπητας were spread on the r(h/gea (cf. note on 16.224); on these Priam was to sleep, with woolen blankets to draw over him (kaqu/perqen e(/sasqai).
λέξο, intransitive; compare the transitive le/con, l. 635.
εἰ ... δή, ‘since really,’ like A 61.
ῥέζων is equivalent to the protasis of a condition.
κεχαρισμένα θείης, ‘you would do welcome things,’ ‘you would gratify me.’
κε goes with qei/hs.
ἐέλμεθα, εἴλω
τηλόθι δ’ ὕλη κτλ., ‘and the wood is far to bring.’
δαινυῖτο, present optative, formed without thematic vowel.
ἐν προδόμῳ δόμου: this expression locates the ai)/qousa of l. 644 immediately before the entrance to the large room of Achilles's lodge.
οὔ νύ τι κτλ., ‘have you not the least fear of trouble [kako/n]. [to judge] by the way that you yet sleep’?
εἴασεν, ‘spared,’ as before.
σεῖο κτλ., ‘and for your life,’ genitive of price with doi=en a)/poina.
παῖδες τοι κτλ., ‘those sons [of yours] left behind.’

On the morning of the thirty-ninth day of the poem Priam comes to Troy, with Hector's body. For nine days preparations for the burial are making and wood for the pyre is hauled. The next two days are occupied with Hector's burial and the funeral feast. (Cf. note on A 8.) The Iliad ends with the words (l. 804) w(\s oi(/ g' a)mfi/epon ta/fon *(/ektoros i(ppoda/moio.

div3.p: The rhythm of the Greek hexameter depends on the time occupied in pronouncing successive syllables, and is quite independent of word accent. It resembles, therefore, modern music rather than English poetry. There is, indeed, a regular recurrence of metrically stressed syllables § 8), but rhymed syllables are rare and perhaps accidental.
A short syllable contains a short vowel; this may be followed by a single consonant, either in the same word or in the next.
A syllable may be long either by nature or by position:
1. By nature, if it contains a long vowel or a diphthong. E. g. h)xh/, teuxeu/sh|.
2. By position, if its vowel, although naturally short, is followed by two (or three) consonants or a double consonant (ζ, ξ, ψ).

φ, χ, and θ do not have the value of double consonants. E. g. in A 10, nou=son a)na\ strato\n w)=rse kakh/n, o)le/konto de\ la_oi/, the final syllable of a)na/ and the penult of o)le/konto are long by “position.”
It does not matter whether the two consonants are both in the same word with the short vowel or not. One may end the word, and the other begin the next; or they may both begin the next word.

Although a mute and a following liquid generally have the value of two consonants ( § 3.2), and in combination with a preceding short vowel regularly make a long syllable, it occasionally happens that such a syllable is short if the liquid is λ or ρ. E. g. the ultima of ptero/enta is not lengthened in the often repeated line, A 201, etc., kai/ min fwnh/sa_s e)/pea ptero/enta proshu/da_. Cf. 3.414, sxetli/h, of which the first syllable is short.

Each verse contains six feet, corresponding to bars in music; and each foot, except the last, consists of one long syllable followed by two short ones, or of two long syllables. Two short syllables are equivalent in value to one long.
A foot is thus indicated, graphically: -uu or --; or in musical notation, if a long syllable be represented by a quarter note, one quarter and two eighths, or two quarters.
The sixth foot always consists of two syllables; and these may be both long, or one long (the first) and one short.

The first syllable of each foot is emphasized in oral reading.Emphasizing the first syllable is a classroom technique; modern scholars no longer recommend this. --Perseus This stress of the voice is called ictus (Latin for ‘blow,’ ‘beat’ in time); it can be indicated with an accent mark. The syllable that receives the ictus is called the thesis (Greek qe/sis, a ‘setting down,’ as of the foot in marching); the rest of the foot —either one long syllable or two short syllables—the arsis (Greek a)/rsis, a ‘lifting,’ as of the foot in marching).
Roman writers referring these terms to the falling and rising inflection of the voice used them in exactly the reverse way. Some modern books continue the Roman use.

The foot that consists of a long and two short syllables is called a dactyl. Two long syllables in one foot compose a spondee. One long and one short syllable, found only in the sixth foot § 7), make a trochee.
The whole verse (e)/pos) is called dactylic hexameter; sometimes, from its subject, heroic hexameter.

In the first five feet the poet used dactyls or spondees at his pleasure, but dactyls seem to have been preferred in certain places, e. g. in the third foot, and in the fourth foot before the bucolic diaeresis § 19). The fifth foot, in particular, is generally a dactyl; yet here too a spondee is not uncommon; such lines are called spondaic lines, and are said to occur, in Homer, in the proportion of one to eighteen. They are much less frequent in Vergil.
Lines containing no dactyls are very rare.

Pauses.—If a word ends within a foot (i. e. if the foot is cut in two), the interruption is called caesura (Latin for ‘cutting’). If the end of a word coincides with the division between two feet (i. e. with the bar of musical notation), the coincidence is called diaeresis (Greek diai/resis, ‘division’).

It is at these points, after a caesura or a diaeresis, that the voice may pause in reciting a verse. But unless a caesura or diaeresis coincides with a natural pause in sense, it is generally neglected; where such a coincidence does occur, however, the principal caesura or principal diaeresis is said to be found. Every verse contains at least one pause—almost always a principal caesura.

Following is a metrical scheme indicating the commonest position of the principal caesura and diaeresis:
-w -w -|u|u -w | -w -x
The sign *l denotes a rest equivalent to one short syllable.
A caesura can not occur before enclitics or other words that can not begin a sentence (ga/r, de/, a)/ra, etc.), or after proclitics.
If a caesura occurs after the thesis of a foot, it is called masculine; if in the arsis, that is, between two short syllables, it is called feminine.

The third foot generally contains the principal caesura. The feminine caesura is more frequent than the masculine in this foot, the proportion between the two being approximately 4 to 3 (based on La Roche's figures). For examples of the feminine caesura see B 400-410; of the masculine, A 1 and 8.
A not uncommon pause is the masculine caesura of the fourth foot. E. g. A 3 (after yuxa_/s) and A 7 (after a)ndrw=n).
Such verses (indicated in § 17) often have a pause after the thesis of the second foot also. E. g. A 106, ma/nti kakw=n, ou)/ pw/ pote/ moi to\ krh/guon ei)=pas, or -u u- | - - uu - | - -uu -u.

Diaeresis is not so important as caesura in constituting a pause. The principal diaeresis, when it occurs, is commonly found between the fourth and fifth feet. This is known as the bucolic diaeresis, because it was a favorite with the bucolic poets, of whom the most famous was Theocritus (third century B. C.). How significant it is in Homer may be seen from the fact that the narrative sometimes comes to a complete stop at this point, and a new subject is introduced, as in A 348 and 430.

Less common than the bucolic diaeresis is the one that sometimes occurs between the first and second feet. E. g. A 32, a)ll' i)/qi mh/ m' e)re/qize saw/teros w(/s ke ne/hai., or - uu | - uu-u u-uu - u u-u.
A caesura that was almost always avoided by the Greek epic poets is the feminine caesura of the fourth foot. But compare B 479,
*)/arei+ de\ zw/nhn, ste/rnon de\ *poseida/wni, -uu - -- | -- u u---u.

To accustom the ear to the rhythm of the Greek dactylic hexameter it is advisable to read the lines aloud from the very beginning of the study of Homer. The natural flow of the hexameter, in perfect time, soon becomes a matter of instinct and requires little conscious foresight.

Lines 1 and 2 of Book I (A) are scanned:
mh=nin a)/eide qea\ *phlhi+a/dew *)axilh=os
ou)lome/nhn, h(\ muri/' *)axaioi=s a)/lge' e)/qhke,
-u u-u u- --uu- uu-u
-uu- - -u u-- -u u-u
(For -ew pronounced as one syllable see § 43.)

Lines 43-47 of A thus:
w(\s e)/fat' eu)xo/menos, tou= d' e)/klue *foi=bos *)apo/llwn,
bh= de\ kat' *ou)lu/mpoio karh/nwn xwo/menos kh=r,
to/c' w)/moisin e)/xwn a)mfhrefe/a te fare/trhn:
e)/klagcan d' a)/r' o)i+stoi\ e)p' w)/mwn xwome/noio,
au)tou= kinhqe/ntos: o(\ d' h)/i+e nukti\ e)oikw/s.
- uu -uu- - -uu -u u--
- u u ---u u-- -uu- -
- --u u- --uu- u u--
--- u u-u u -- -uu-u
-- ---u u -uu -u u--
The caesura of line 46 is slight; observe the bucolic diaeresis. For long -α_ of fifth foot see § 33, and for short -oi of third foot see § 25.1.

Important to observe: (a) Elisions are indicated by the apostrophe § 40) and need give no further concern. (b) When, at the beginning of a word, a breathing is written over the first of two consecutive vowels (as in o) i stoi/), the vowels are of course pronounced as separate syllables.

Hiatus (Latin for ‘gaping’) occurs when a word ending in a vowel immediately precedes another which begins with a vowel. It may be avoided, of course, by elision, as e)/fat'(o) eu)xo/menos. It is chiefly found under the following conditions:

1. If the first of the two words ends in a long vowel or a diphthong which is regarded and used as a short syllable. This shortening of a final long vowel or diphthong in the arsis, before an initial vowel of the following word, is very common. E. g.
A 14, e(khbo/lou )/*Apo/llownos
A 15, xruse/w| a)na\ … (-ew| is pronounced as one syllable; cf. § 43).
3.164, ou)/ti/ moi ai)/ti/h e)ssi/: qeoi/ nu/ moi ai)/tioi/ ei)sin
a. Final -ai and -oi, though short in determining word accent, are metrically long except under the condition just noted.
2. If the first word ends in -i (dative singular of third declension) or -u. E. g. B 6, *)agamemnoni ou)=lon. *w 387, su/ e)ssi. But many such instances (e. g. A 393) must be referred to § 25.3.
3. If the first word is followed by a natural pause ( § 16, § 19, 20). E. g.
(a) Feminine caesura of third foot:
A 27, h)\ nu=n dhqu_/nonta | h)\ u(/steron au)=tis i)o/nta.
(b) Masculine caesura of third foot:
A 114, kouridi/hs a)lo/xou, | e)pei\ ou)/ e(qe/n e)sti xerei/wn.
(c) Bucolic diaeresis:
B 3, a)ll' o(/ ge mermh/rize kata\ fre/na | w(s *)axilh=a.
(d) Diaeresis after first foot:
I 247, a)ll' a)/na | ei) me/mona/s ge ktl.
After the formula αὐτὰρ ὅ at the beginning of a line hiatus is several times found (as in A 333), although there is actually no pause in sense.
4. If the first word ends with the thesis of a foot, even when no natural pause occurs at that point. E. g. A 30,
Hiatus is not regarded when elision has already taken place. E. g.
A 2, mu_ri/) *)axaioi=s a)/lge) e)/qhken.

Hiatus seems to occur in some places where it really did not exist in the original words of the poet. This is because he or his predecessors pronounced an initial letter, usually digamma (v), which later disappeared (cf. § 61). E. g.
A 7, *)atrei+/dhs te va/nac ktl.

div3.head: Shortening of long syllables
div3.p: In accordance with the principle of § 25.1, even a long vowel or a diphthong within a word is sometimes shortened in the arsis of a foot, before another vowel. E. g. B 415
Not infrequently such a vowel or diphthong is written short in the text, if the meter requires it. So two spellings of the same word may be found. E. g.

ne/as (A 487), nh=as (A 12). u(o/s (A 489), ui(o/s (A 9). *)/areos (T 47), *)/arhos (B 110). w)ke/a (B 786) for w)kei=a. e(/atai (3.134), h(/at'(ai) (B 137). *phle/os (16.203), *phlh=os (I 147). o)loh=|s (X 65), o)loih=|si (A 342). ke/at'(o) (24.610), kei/ato (11.162).
Even before a single consonant, a vowel originally long is sometimes shortened in the arsis. E. g. *)Apo/llwn 1.43, 1.14, 2.344, 2,348, 6.320, 1.15.
The vowel thus shortened (cf. § 30) may be written short, giving rise to two spellings of the same word (cf. § 29). E. g. me/n, mh/n (and ma_/n). Similarly a)ta/r and au)ta/r.
δέ used as a continuative ‘then’—including “de/ in apodosis”—is equivalent in force to a weakened dh/. Whether the two words are really identical in origin, however, is disputed.

div3.head: Lengthening of short syllables
div3.p: A short final syllable is sometimes used for a long syllable in the thesis of a foot if a metrical pause follows. E. g. A 19, A 153.
Not rarely the ictus itself seems to lengthen a short final syllable, even when no pause follows. E. g. A 45, B 39, B 169.
Compare A 342, B 233, etc.
Initial syllables of words that could not otherwise be introduced into the hexameter are sometimes lengthened by the ictus. E. g. A 265.
The vowel thus lengthened is often written long in the text. E. g.

A 2, ou)lome/nhn (Attic o)lome/nhn). A 155, bwtianei/rh| (bo/skw, ‘feed,’ and a)nh/r). A 252, h)gaqe/h| (a^)ga-, ‘very’). B 77, h)maqo/entos (a^)/maqos, ‘sand’). B 89, ei)arinoi=sin (e)/ar, ‘spring’). B 448, h)ere/qontai (a^)ei/rw, ‘raise’). B 460, doulixodei/rwn (dolixo/s, ‘long’).
Compare ei)n a)gorh=| (I 13) for e)n a)gorh=|.
The initial syllable of the first foot is sometimes lengthened apparently by the ictus alone. E. g. 3.357, dia/. X 379, e)pei/.

In many instances where a short syllable seems to be used for a long, closer examination shows that it is really long by position. The value of a consonant (especially digamma) often remains, even when the letter itself has disappeared from the text. E. g. A 416. So too 3.2, 230, etc.

Whether the initial consonant of w(s, ‘like,’ was v or y is uncertain. At any rate, it had disappeared in the Homeric age; its value was retained, however, in formulas like the one quoted, which were inherited from older time.
A short final vowel may make a long syllable when the next word begins with a liquid
λ, μ, ν, ρ—or digamma, or sigma. E. g. A 233.

These same consonants § 38) are sometimes found written double, within a word, lengthening a preceding short syllable on which the ictus rests. E. g. A 173, e)pe/ssutai. A 278, e)/mmore. A 420, a)ga/nnifon for a)ga/-snifon. B 170, e)usse/lmoio. B 452, a)/llhkton. *g 34, e)/llabe. T 35, a)po[vv]eipw/n.
A 7, *)axilleu/s, but A 1, *)axilh=os. A 145, *)odusseu/s, but A 138, *)odush=os. The longer spellings of the last two words may be original.

div3.head: Elision
div3.p: Final vowels that are superfluous to the meter are elided before words beginning with a vowel, in the following instances, and the elision is marked by an apostrophe:
1. -α^, -ε, -ο, of the various parts of speech. E. g. A 2, mu_ri/)(a), a)/lge)(a) (= Attic a)/lgh). A 23, q'=te. A 32, m)(e). A 33, e)/fat'(o). A 52, ba/ll)(e) = e)/balle.
2. -ι^. E. G. B 132, ei)w=s)(i). Except the final -i of peri/, ti/ and its compunds: ὅ τ’ stands for ὅ τε, never for o(/ ti. E. g. A 244, o(/ t'(e). Cf. § 123.7.
3. -αι of various verb endings. E. g. A 117, bou/lou)(ai). A 546, e)/sont'(ai). B 137, h(/at'(ai).

4. -οι of the dative singular of personal pronouns. E. g. A 170, s)(oi). Perhaps 3.235, kai/ t'(oi). I 673, m)(oi). The context proves that the dative of the pronoun is intended in the first and third examples.

div3.head: Contraction
div3.p: Very many forms that would be contracted in Attic Greek are found uncontracted in the text of Homer. E. g. A 1, a)/eide (= Attic a)=|de). A 8, cun-e/hke (= Attic sun-h=ke, from sun-i_/hmi). A 30, *)/argei+. A 49, a)rgure/oio (= a)rgurou=). A 76, e)re/w (= e)rw=).
Besides the familiar contractions of Attic Greek, the MSS. show a peculiar one: eu for eo. E. g. A 37, meu (Attic mou). I 54, e)/pleu (for e)/pleo).

div3.head: Synizesis
div3.p: Allied to contraction is Synizesis (Greek suni/zhsis, ‘settling together’). This occurs when two neighboring vowels, regularly pronounced separately, must be pronounced as one syllable, to suit the meter. E. g. A 1, -ew (of *phlhia/dew) must be pronounced as one syllable (but cf. § 68). So too A 15, -e/w| (of xru_se/w|). A 18, qeoi/. A 131, dh\ ou(/tws. A 340, dh\ au)=te. A 540, dh\ au)=. For the last three examples the MSS. read, respectively, d' ou(/tws, d' au)=te, d' au)=, readings which perhaps had better be retained, if d'=de/=dh/ § 31).

div3.head: Crasis
div3.p: Crasis (Greek kra=sis, ‘mingling’) occurs when a final vowel or diphthong is contracted with a vowel which begins the next word. In Homer as now written it is rare. E. g. A 465, ta)=lla (= ta\ a)/lla). B 238, xh)mei=s (= kai\ h(mei=s). Z 260, kau)to/s (=kai\ au)to/s). T 413, w)/ristos (= o( a)/ristos).

tou)/neka (A 96, etc.) for tou= e(/neka is regarded by some editors as an example of crasis; by others it is written tou/neka, as if for tou= )neka (e(/neka) juxtaposed. So ou(/neka (A 11, etc.) is explained both ways.

div3.head: Apocope
div3.p: By Apocope (Greek a)pokoph/, ‘cutting off’) is denoted the loss of a final vowel before a word beginning with a consonant. No apostrophe marks the omission. The chief Homeric instances are a)/n, ka/t, pa/r, and a)/r (for a)na/, kata/, para/, and a)/ra). E. g. A 143, a)/n. A 8, a)/r.
a)/n and ka/t suffer euphonic changes before certain consonants. E. g. 16.726, a)\m po/non. B 160, ka\d de/. *p 106, ka\p fa/lar)(a). 18.24, ka\k kefalh=s. In composition: E 343, ka/b-balen.

div3.head: Syncope
div3.p: The suppression of a short vowel within a word is called Syncope (Greek sugkoph/, ‘cutting short’). E. g.
A 13, qu/gatra for qugate/ra. A 202, ti/pt'(e) for ti/ pote. A 275, a)poai/reo for a)poaire/eo.

div3.head: Some important particles
div3.p: 1. ἄρα (also found as a)/r' , a)/r, r(a, r('), ‘as may be believed,’ ‘of course,’ ‘as it seems,’ ‘so,’ ‘then,’ etc.
2. νυ(ν), an enclitic, ‘now’ (inferential), ‘then,’ ‘pray,’ etc. Homer uses the temporal nu=n also.
3. κε(ν), an enclitic, equivalent to Attic a)/n (cf. § § 189 ff.).

div3.head: N movable
div3.p: -ν movable is found not only before words beginning with a vowel, but also before consonants if a long syllable is required by the meter. E. g. A 77.

div3.head: Doubling of certain consonants
div3.p: 1. π is found doubled in the relatives o(ppo/te, o(/ppws, o(ppo/teros, etc. o(po/te and o(/pws also occur, as in Attic.
2. τ may be doubled in o(/t(t)i.
3. ς may occur double in to/s(s)os, o(/s(s)os, me/s(s)os, and other words.
4. An etymological reason very often exists for the double consonant, as may be illustrated in the case of double sigma.
Double sigma of the following words results from the retention of a final sigma of the stem: A 42, be/les-sin. A 82, tele/s-sh|. A 83, sth/qes-sin.

On the analogy of verbs like tele/s-sh| (the stem teles- appears in the noun te/los), although without a similar etymological reason, are formed futures and aorists such as: A 153, maxesso/menos. A 54, kale/ssato. A 76, o)/mosson. A 100, i(lassa/menoi.
Double sigma of the following words arises from the assimilation of a lingual mute to the following sigma: A 368, da/ssanto (dat-santo). A 537, sumfra/ssato (sun-frad-sato). B 44, possi/ (pod-si).
Many of these words (§ § 52-54) have epic forms with one sigma also.

Many double sigma forms in Homer are familiar as double tau forms in Xenophon: A 34, qala/sshs. A 80, krei/sswn. A 483, diaprh/ssousa, Attic diapra_/ttousa. B 51, khru_/ssein. B 87, melissa_/wn, Attic melittw=n. B 440, qa=sson.

div3.head: Neglect of euphonic change
div3.p: In some words, before μ, the mutes δ, θ, and others are retained unchanged. E. g.
A 124, i)/dmen, Attic i)/smen. B 341, e)pe/piqmen.

div3.head: Metathesis of letters
div3.p: Some words containing ρ have a vowel, usually α, either preceding it or following it, at the pleasure of the poet and the demands of the meter. The transfer of order is called Metathesis. E. g. A 25, kratero/n, A 178, kartero/s. A 225, kradi/hn, B 452, kardi/h|.
terpike/raunos (A 419, etc.) is probably in its first part derived from tre/pw (by metathesis) and means ‘hurler of the thunderbolt.’

div3.head: Digamma
div3.p: The letter digamma, v, which belonged originally to most—if not all—Greek alphabets, means literally double gamma, from its form v. Its value was that of the English w; when vocalized, it became υ. When epic poetry began to flourish, it was a living sound; but in the progress of the ages during which the Iliad and Odyssey were transmitted, it seems to have disappeared from the Ionic dialect; and when at last these poems were written down, no sign was used to indicate a sound with which the scribes themselves were possibly unacquainted. Nevertheless traces of the letter survive in lengthened syllables and in instances of hiatus which otherwise would be irregular; compare § 27, § 37, 38.

div3.head: Initial Digamma
div3.p:
Full lists of words that once were spelled with digamma, with or without other lost consonants, may be found in large grammars and lexicons. The following illustrative list is selected from instances in A and B; the words are grouped in order of roots or stems:
1. (e))va/ndane, h(/ndane (A 24), vhdu/ (B 270). The original spelling was svad-: cf. Lat. suāvis, Eng. ‘sweet.’
2. va/lis (B 90).
3. va/nac (A 7), vana/sseis (A 38).
4. va/stu (B 803). Cf. Lat. Vesta(?).
5. viva/xw: vhxh/essa (A 157).
6. ve (A 406), voi (A 104), veqen (A 114), etc., pronoun of third person; vh=|sin (A 333), etc., from vo/s, possessive pronoun of third person; also e(voi=si (A 83), etc., from e(vo/s. There were original forms in sv-: cf. Lat. suus.
7. veiarinh=| (B 471) for vearinh=|. ve/ar=Lat. vēr.
8. ve/qnea (B 87).
9. vei/kosi (B 748), e)vei/kosin (A 309), Lat. vīgintī.
10. ve/kaqen: veka- thbele/ta_o (A 75), etc.
11. ve/kasta (A 550).
12. vekw/n: a)-ve/kontos (A 301).
13. ve/lpomai: e)pi-ve/lpeo (A 545), e)ve/ldwr (A 41). Cf. Lat. voluptās, etc.
14. vei/lw: ve/lsai (A 409).
